ALTHOUSE -- In Hamburg, Route 1, on the 29 inst., HENRIETTA S. (nee Savage) ALTHOUSE, aged 88 years.
  Services from the Burkey Funeral Home, Hamburg, Friday, 2 p.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Thursday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Henrietta S. Althouse
 
Hamburg, June 30 -- Henrietta (Savage), widow of Howard H Althouse, died in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Harry S. Moser.  Hamburg R. D. 1. aged 88 years.  She was a daughter of the late John and Ellnora E (Coller) Savage, and was born in Bern Township.
  Surviving are three children, Ella M. wife of Allen A Baker, Reading; John R., of Bern Township, and Katie M., wife of Harry S. Moser, with whom she lived; a grandchild an a great-grandchild.
  Funeral services will be held Friday at 2 o'clock in the Burkey Funeral home, this place, with the Rev. Dr. Dallas R Krebs officiating.  Burial will be made in the Laureldale Cemetery.

ALTHOUSE - In Bern township, on the 29th inst., Howard H. Althouse, aged 30 years.
  The relatives and friends of the deceased, also the members of the Ringgold band, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his father-in-law, Samuel Savage, in Bern township, on Wednesday morning at 9 o'clock.  Services and interment at Epler's church.

Howard H. Althouse, a well-known member of the Ringgold band, died at his home near Leinbach's tavern, of consumption, aged about 27 years.  A widow and several children survive him.  Deceased formerly resided at 610 Thorn, this city, but moved into the country a short time ago for the benefit of his health.  He was an accomplished musician and played 1st clarionet in the Ringgold band.

Mrs. Catherine Bechtel, died on the 12th, aged 54y 5m 5d, she was the widow of Christian Bechtel who died lately in Cumru Twp., this county.
 
Verstarb â€“ am 12ten dieses, in einem Alter von 54 Jahren, 5 Monaten und 5 Tagen, Frau Maria Catharina Bechtel, hinterlakene Witine
 
Verstarb = Died
Am 12th dieses = on this 12th
In einem alter von 54 jahren, 5 monaten und 5 tagen = in an age of 54 years, 5 months, and 5 days
Frau Maria Catharina Bechtel = Mrs. Maria Catharine Bechtel
hinterlakene Witwe = widowed widow
des mrzlich verstorbenen Christian Bechtel = of the recently deceased Christian Bechtel
Von Cumru Taunschip, dieser Caunty = from Cumru Township, this County

BECHTEL -- In West Yellowstone, Mont., on Sept 28, CHARLES H., son of the late Frederick R and Esther (nee High) Bechtel, aged 72 years, 2 months and 24 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral service without further notice from F.F. Seidel's Funeral Chapel 117 North Fifth Street on Thursday at 11 a.m.  Interment in Sinking Spring Cemetery.

Christian Bechtel, an old and wealthy resident of Cumru Twp., this county, died on the 1st, aged about 62 years.
 
Starb -- Am [iften] dieses, Christian Bechtel, in einem Alter von [ohngesahr] 62 Jahren, ein alter und hoch geschazter Einwohrier von Cumru Taunschip, in dieser Caunty
 
Google Translate
Starb = Died
Am [iften] dieses = At the end of this or At this time
In einem = in one or on the first
In einem alter von [ohngesahr] 62 jahren = in an old age of 62 years
Ein alter und hoch geschazter einwohrier = an old and upscale dweller
Von Cumru Taunschip = from Cumru Township
In dieses Caunty = in this county

BECHTEL -- On the 11th inst., CLARA E. (nee Savage), widow of John H. Bechtel aged 87 years.
  Services from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St., on Tuesday at 11 a.m.  Internment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Clara E. Bechtel
 
Mrs. Clara E. (Savage) Bechtel, 87, widow of John H. Bectel, 924 Madison Ave, died this morning in Community General Hospital.   She was a native of Reading, a daughter of the late Enoch and Helen (Ritz) Savage, and was a member of Epler's Evangelical and Reformed Church.
  Surviving are a daughter, Florence E., widow of Floyd W. Fett, with whom she resided; seven grandchildren, 22 great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren; also a sister, Sallie I., widow of Peter Miller, Reading.
The Henninger Funeral Home is in charge of the arrangements.

BECHTEL -- At Fritztown, Lower Heidelberg township, on the 5th of June, Mrs. Elizabeth Bechtel, widow of Daniel Bechtel, in the 82d year of her age.
  The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, at Fritztown, on Wednesday at 10 o'clock a.m.  Interment at Sinking Spring burying ground.  Services at the church.

Emma A. Bechtel
 
  Mrs. Floyd Fett, of 924 Madison Ave., was notified yesteray of the death of her aunt, Emma A. Bechtel, in the Lutheran Home, Philadelphia.  Miss Bechtel, the last of her family, was a daughter of the late Frederick R. And Esther (High) Bechtel.  She was a member of Trinity Lutheran Church.
  Services Friday at 11 a.m. In the Lutheran Home.  Burial in Sinking Spring Cemetery.

BECHTEL -- In Brookside, on the 20th inst., ESTHER R. widow of Fred. R. Bechtel, aged 80 years, 7 months and 3 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, in Brookside, Saturday at 10:30 a.m.  Services at the house.  Interment private in Sinking Spring cemetery.  Please omit flowers.

Mrs. Esther R. Bechtel
 
  Esther R., (nee High), widow of Frederick R. Bechtel, died of the infirmities of old age on Monday, at her residence, in Brookside, aged 81 years.  Deceased, who was a member of the First Reformed Church, was bedfast for the last five weeks.  She is survived by these children:   Charles H., Yellowstone Park, Montana; John H., Reading; Emma A. and Sarah E., at home; besides two grandchildren and three great grandchildren.  Undertaker Auman took charge of the remains.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Dies in House In Which he was Born
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
DIES IN HOUSE IN WHICH HE WAS BORN
 
Frederick R. Bechtel of Brookside, Passes Away.
 
Frederick R. Bechtel, aged 80 years, 2 months, and 27 days, died at 7 p.m. Wednesday, at the Bechtel homestead, Brookside, in which he was born, after a lingering illness. He was a son of Christian and Julia (nee Reese) Bechtel, both deceased, and was born Sep. 17, 1830. Although his ill health extended over a period of several months, during which time he was able to be about the house and to walk about the yard on pleasant days without assistance, his will power was so great that he was confined to his room less than a week. Mr. Bechtel spent his entire life on the farm on which he was born, with the exception of a few years , when , as a young man, he lived in Reading. He never took an active part in politics, but served several terms as a Director of the schools of Cumru township. He was a lifelong member of Trinity Lutheran Church, this city, and for many years was a teacher in the Sunday school. Mr. Bechtel is survived by his widow, Esther (nee High), and two sons and two daughters, Charles H Bechtel, Lake, Idaho; John H. Bechtel, Reading; Emma A. and Sarah E. Bechtel, at home.

BECHTEL -- In Brookside, on the 14th inst., FREDERICK R. BECHTEL aged 80 years, 2 months, and 27 days.
Funeral strictly private from his late residence, Brookside, on Wednesday at 10:30 a.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Sinking Spring cemetery.

Starb -- in der Nacht von 17ten Dieses, in Cumru Taunschip, John Bechtel, im Alter von 67 Jahren, 2 Monaten und 14 Tagen.
 
Died - at night on this 17th, in Cumru Township, John Bechtel, at the age of 67 years, 2 months, and 14 days.

Fell and Injured Back
 
  John H. Bechtel, conductor of one of the fast freight trains on the Harrisburg division slipped and fell, severely injuring his back.  He resides at Allentown.

BECHTEL -- In Bern Township, on the 27th inst., JOHN H. BECHTEL, aged 78 years.
  Services from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St., on Thursday at 1:30 p.m.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Friends may call Wednesday evening, 7 to 9.

John H. Bechtel
 
  John H. Bechtel, 74, former planing mill operator, died yesterday at his home, Bern Township, Reading R.D. 2.  He was born in Reading, son of the late Frederick R. And Esther (High) Bechtel.
  For 17 years he operated the Neversink Planing Mill and for 15 years prior to 1932 when he lost his eyesight he was superintendent for Arthur Dives, operator of the Shillington Heights Planing Mill.  He was a member of the Reformed denomination, Isaac Hiester Lodge 660, F. And A.M. And Reading Lodge 115, B.P.O. Elks.
  Surviving are his widow, Clara E. (Savage); daughter, Florence, wife of Floyd W. Fett; sister, Emma, of Philadelphia; seven grandchildren.  Funeral services will be held Thursday at 1:30 p.m. At the Henninger Funeral Home, the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Roth, officiating.

BECHTEL -- On Monday night, the 3rd inst, Julia Ann Bechtel, in the 87th year of her age. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her son Fred. R Bechtel, in Cumru township on Saturday Oct 8th at 9 o'clock to proceed to Sinking Spring Cemetery.

Sarah E. Bechtel
 
  Sarah E. Bechtel, 70, a former resident of this city, died in the Lutheran Woman's Home, Germantown, Philadelphia.  She was a daughter of the late Fred R. And Esther (High) Bechtel, and formerly lived at 1319 Lancaster Ave.
  In 1938 she entered the Lutheran home with her sister, Emma A.  Besides the sister, a brother, John H., of Bern Township, survives.  Funeral services will be held Monday at 1 p.m. In the Scheidt Memorial Chapel, Germantown.  The body will then be brought to Trinity Lutheran Chapel, where services will be held at 3:30 p.m., the Rev. Dr. Hermann F. Miller officiating.  Interment will be made in Sinking Spring Cemetery.

Starb -- am letzten Samstag, in Cumru Taunschip, Christian Bechtel, im Alter von [ctwa] 53 Jahren
 
Died -- last Satuday in Cumru Township, Christian Bechtel, aged 53 years.

On the 24th inst., in this city, HORACE BERTOLET, aged 34 years and 9 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, 8th Street below Franklin, without further notice.  To proceed to Charles Evans Cemetery.

DIES IN 94TH YEAR
 
DEMISE OF THE MOTHER OF DR. JOHN M. BERTOLET.
 
   Mrs. Adaline B. Frey died of the infirmities of age at 7:30 o'clock Sunday morning at her home at Freemansville, Cumru township.  Her age was 93 years and 19 days.  Deceased was the mother of Dr. John M. Bertolet, 1333 Perkiomen avenue.  Mrs. Frey came from a family noted for their longevity, nearly all her brothers and sisters who preceded her in death having passed the four-score-year mark.  Her mother, Mrs. John (Thomas) Miller of Warwick, Chester county, died at the age of 96 years.  Mrs. Frey possessed many sterling traits.  Her death is mourned by hosts of friends.
  Deceased was twice married.  Her first husband was the late Horace DeTurk Bertolet, associated with the Reading Railway Company for many years.   He invented a number of appliances used on the company's locomotives and other motive equipment.  Her second husband was the late Franklin B. Frey.
  Deceased was one of the oldest members of the First Baptist Church.
  She was a past president of the Women's Relief Corps, G.A.R., a charter member of the Ladies' Aid Society, Sons of Veterans and of the Veteran Temple, Order of Pocohontas.
  Besides Dr. Bertolet, deceased leaves another son, Harry O. Frey of Freemansville, with whom she resided; two daughters, Mrs. E.E. Bower and Mrs. E.F. Mehary, both of Philadelphia, and one brother, James Victor Miller, Warwick, Chester county.
  Undertaker Auman took charge of the remains.

BLACK - On the 18th day of February, CLEMENTINE F. (nee Fett), widow of Paul R. Black, formerly of 938 Madison Ave., Reading, age 80 years.
  Memorial services in Holy Spirit Lutheran Church, Wednesday at 2 p.m.  Interment in St. John's German Lutheran Church Cemetery.  No viewing.  Please make contributions to Holy Spirit Lutheran Church, 4th & Windsor Sts, Reading, PA, 19601.

Clementine F. Black
 
  Clementine F. Black, 80, formerly of 938 Madison Ave., died Friday at 4:20 p.m. in Kutztown Manor, where she had resided for three years.
  Her husband, Paul R. Black died Sep 3, 1976.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late Floyd and Florence (Bechtel) Fett.
  Black was employed 50 years as a registered nurse, the last 15 years of those at Berks Heim before retiring in 1990.
  She was a 1837 graduate of Reading High School and a 1940 graduate of Reading Hospital School of Nursing.
  Black was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church, Reading.
  Surviving are a daughter, June A. (Black) Wert, Lenhartsville, and three sons:  Michael P., Laureldale; David L., Reading; and Philip L., Pennsauken, N.J.
  Other survivors include two sisters, Gene (Fett) May, Whitfield, and Marjorie (Fett) Rettgers, Dillsburg, York County.
  There are also seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
  Memorial services will be Wednesday at 2 p.m. In Holy Spirit Church.  Burial will be in St. John's German Lutheran Church Cemetery, Reading.  Bean Funeral Homes & Cremation Services Inc., Reading, is in charge of arrangements.

Michael P. Black
 
  Michael P. Black, 62, Laureldale, died April 23, 2007, in the emergency room of St. Joseph Medical Center, Bern Township.
  He was the husband of Wanida M. (Shade) Black.
  Born in Miami, he was a son of the late Paul and Clementine (Fett) Black.
  He was employed for 30 years as a materials handler by Agere Systems, Muhlenberg Township, retiring in 2002.
  A graduate of Reading High School, he was a Navy veteran of the Vietnam War.
  He is also survived by a daughter, Tara L. Gerhard, Laureldale.
  Other survivors include two brothers, David Black, Reading, and Phillip Black, in New Jersey;  and a sister, June Wert, Lenhartsville.
  There are also three grand-children:  Brittany, Ashely, and Courtnee Seidel.
  Memorial services will be Saturday at 1:30 p.m. In Milkins Funeral Home Inc., 4914 Kutztown Road, Temple, with the Rev. Charles E Fair officiating.   Burial will be private.  The family will receive friends Saturday one hour prior to service in the funeral home.
  Contributions may be med to the American Diabetes Association, 501 N. 17 St, Suite 212, Allentown, PA  18104.

BLACK - On the 2nd inst., PAUL R., husband of Clementine (nee Fett) Black, of 938 Madison Ave., age 58 years.
  Services from the Theo C. Auman Inc., 247 Penn St. Tuesday 1 p.m.  Interment in St. John's Lutheran Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening, 7 to 9.  Chandler Lodge 227 will conduct services Monday at 8 p.m.

Paul R. Black
 
  Paul R. Black, 58, of 938 Madison Ave., died today at 8:20 a.m. in his residence.
  Born in Alabama, the son of the late Mr. And Mrs. William Black, he was last employed as a carpenter, working out of Carpenter's Local 492, Reading.
  He was a Marine Corps veteran of the Korean War, and a member of Carpenter's Local 492, NOR-MI Lodge 253, F&AM in Florida, and a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church.
  Surviving are his widow, Clementine (Fett) Black; three sons, Michael P. and Phillip L., both at home; and Private David L., Army, Ft Bliss, Tex.; and one daughter, June A., at home.
  Also one brother, William C. Gadsden, Ala. And one sister, Mrs. Onsell McKnight, Daytona Beach, Fla.
  Theo. C. Auman, Inc. Has charge of arrangements.

FRANK BOWENS DIES
 
  Frank Bowens, 67, died suddenly at []:30 a.m. Monday.  Funeral Service will be held at Lebanon Baptist church near Effingham at 10:30 o'clock this morning conducted by the Rev. Leland Powell [].  Mr. Bowens is survived by his wife, one son and one daughter.  Jonny Bowens and Essie Bowens, [] also survive.  Mrs. Ethel Maxwell of [], Mrs. [] [] of West Columbia, and Mrs. Ida Howell.

Mrs. Letha Deas
 
  Mrs. Letha Deas, 67, of Ferndale section of North Charleston, died at 3 p.m. Friday in the Medical College Hospital after a brief illness.
  Funeral services will be conducted at 1:30 p.m. Sunday in Ferndale Baptist Church.  Committal services directed by Walers Funeral Home of Florence, will be conducted at 4 p.m. at the graveside in Lebanon Cemetery near Effingham by Rev. J.W. Hunter.
  Mrs. Deas, the former Miss Letha Carnell of Florence County, was a daughter of the late Willie E. and Ida Barnes Carnell.  She was a member of Ferndale Baptist Church of N. Charleston.
  Surviving are the widower, Theodore Deas of North Charleston, two daughters, Mrs. Linwood Wiggins of Myrtle Beach and Mrs. Jessie Barrinean of Florence; and three grandchildren.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Obtained from the Florence County, S.C. library
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Abner Broach, aged 90 years and three days, died at the residence of his son, J. E. Broach, in Farrs Bay township, Darlington county, September 12th 1879, of dropsy and debility.
  Born and raised in Darlington county, he resided for a time in Marion county, west of Pee Dee.  For years, a consistent member of the Baptist Church.  He was the father of 17 children, 12 of whom survive him.

Wesley A. Broach, Darlington Dies; Many Survivors
 
  Darlington, April 8 -- (Special) -- Wesley A. Broach, well known Darlington man whose survivors include nearly 300 children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, and great great grandchildren, died at his home on Pearl street here this morning.  He had been ill for the past two months.
  Mr. Broach was a member of a family of five generations.  He was born and reared in Florence county, but made his home in Darlington for some time.
  Surviving are five sons and three daughters, John, James, Ervin, Richard, and Nathan Broach, all of Florence County; Mrs. Annie Player, St. Stephens, Mrs. Hattie Hudson, Camden; Mrs. Maggie Dixon of Darlington. Also survived by two step children, E.D. McElveen and Mrs. Nellie Thornwell of Florence County.  Also 61 grandchildren, 184 great grandchildren, and 8 great great grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be held Friday afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Elim Baptist church in Florence county.  Rites will be conducted by the Rev. Lester Altman.  Burial will take place in the church cemetery.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Death Comes to Mrs. Wesley Broach
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
DEATH COMES TO MRS. WESLEY BROACH
 
Mrs. Wesley Broach, 80, died yesterday morning at her home in Tans Bay section.  The funeral services will be held this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at Elim Baptist Church with interment in the church cemetery.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: From the Florence County, South Carolina Library
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Funeral Services Mrs. Wesley Broach
  Funeral services for Mrs. Wesley Broach, 80, who died at her home in the Tans Bay section, were held from the home Christmas afternoon in Elim Baptist Church cemetery.  The services were conducted by the Rev. M. B. [?].  Pallbearers were S. W. Broach, David Broach, Irby Broach, Sammy Broach, Roland Dixon, and Andrew Dixon.

Mrs. Beatrice Carnell
 
  Mrs. Beatrice Carnell, of Route 1, Pelion, died Saturday.
  Plans will be announced by Thompson Funeral Home of West Columbia.

Curtis T. Carnell
 
  Curtis T. Carnell, 69, of 291 Camp Ground Road, Dillsburg, died Saturday, May 18, at the Carlisle Hospital.
  He was the husband of Lora E. Smith Carnell.
  Born March 15, 1922, in Florence, S.C., he was the son of the late William and Nellie Langston Connell.
  Mr. Carnell was a retired welder from Farriers Fabricating Co. In York.  He was a former employee of the former Pennsylvania Railroad.  And he was an Army veteran of the 24th Infantry Division of World War II.
  He is survived by two sons, Donald C. Carnell of Clearwater, S.C., and Richard L. Carnell of Harrisburg; four daughters, Linda M. Carnell of Dillsburg, Vivian L. Happel of Orlando, Fla., Susan E. Noll of Biglerville, and Elizabeth A. Shaulas of Gardners; a brother, Wilbur B. Cornell of Hinesville, Ga.; and 10 grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. Tuesday at the Cocklin Funeral Home, 30 N. Chestnut St., Dillsburg, with the Rev. Ross Reider, pastor of the New Love in Christ Church in Harrisburg officiating.  Interment will be in the Dillsburg Cemetery.
  Friends may call from 7 to 9 p.m. Monday at the funeral home.

Curtis T. Carnell
 
  DILLSBURG -- Curtis T. Carnell, 69, of 291 Camp Ground Road died yesterday in Carlisle.
  He was a retired welder from Farriers Fabricating Co. York, and a former employee of the former Pennsylvania Railroad;  and an Army veteran of World War II.
  Surviving are his wife, Lora E. Smith Carnell; two sons, Donald C. Carnell of Clearwater, S.C., and Richard L. of Harrisburg; four daughters, Linda M. of Dillsburg, Vivian L. Happel of Orlando, Fla., Susan E. Noll of Biglerville, and Elizabeth A. Shaulas of Gardners; a brother, Wilbur B. Cornell of Hinesville, Ga.; and 10 grandchildren.
  Services will be held at 11 a.m. Tuesday in the Cocklin Funeral Home.  Burial will be in Dillsburg Cemetery.
  Viewing will be from 7 to 9 p.m. Tomorrow at the funeral home.

MRS. FRANK CARNELL
 
  WINNSBORO -- Mrs. Duma Mozell Odom Carnell, 77, wife of Frank Carnell, died Wednesday in a Winnsboro hospital.
  Born in Barnwell County, she was a daughter of the late Jefferson M. And Mamie Dykes Odom.  She was a retired employee of UniRoyal Inc.
  Surviving are her husband; three daughters, Mrs. Odell Porter, Doris Carnell and Vernice Carnell of Winnsboro; a son, Johnny Carnell of Columbia; and a brother, Byron Odom of West Columbia.
  Plans will be announced by Pope Funeral Home.

JOHN F. CARNELL
 
  WINNSBORO -- John Frank Carnell, 83, died Thursday at his home.
  He was born in Florence County, a son of the late Willie and Elsie Carter Carnell.  He was a retired employee of Uniroyal and a World War I veteran.
  Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. J.O. Porter and Doris and Vernice Carnell of Winnsboro; a con, Johnnie Carnell of Columbia; a brother, Melvin Carnell of Columbia; seven grand children and 10 great-grandchildren.
  Plans will be announced by Pope Funeral Home.

Melvin F. Carnell, Sr.
 
  Melvin Fanuel Carnell Sr., 88, of 216 Megill Drive, Pelion, died Saturday.
  Born in Florence, he was a son of the late William L. And Elsie Carter Carnell, and was married to the late Beatrice Spence Carnell.  Formerly of Baltimore, he was a retired paint contractor and a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.
  Surviving are daughters, Lottie Levinson of Baltimore and Peggy Feugere of Fullerton, Ga.; sons, Melvin F. Carnell, Jr. Of Pelion, and Fred and Martin Carnell, both of Baltimore.
  Services will be held at 11 a.m. Tuesday at the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints of West Columbia, with burial in Royal Pines Cemetery of Winnsboro.  The family will receive friends from 7 to 9 p.m. Today at Thompson Funeral Home of West Columbia.

Death of Mrs. Mary Christ Aged 91.
 
  Mrs. Mary Christ, residing on South Ninth street, this city, died yesterday at her residence, aged 91.  She was the widow of Mr. Thomas Christ, a soldier of the war of 1812 and the daughter of Mr. Reese, a Revolutionary soldier.  Mrs. Peter Cullen is grand-daughter of Mrs. Christ.

CHRIST -- In this city on the 6th inst., of dropsy, Mrs. Mary M. Christ, aged 91 years.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, 272 South Ninth street, on Saturday, Feb 9th at 3 o'clock p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment at Aulenbach's cemetery.

Frank Comstock, Retired Farmer, Dies at Age 87
 
  Frank Comstock, 87, Glen More, widower of Elsie (McLaughlin) Comstock, died Friday in Forest Manor Nursing Home, Glen More.
  Born in Warwick Township, he was a son of the late Frank and Mary Ann (Stauffer) Comstock.
  He resided and farmed most of his life in Wallace Township.
  He was a member of the Fairview Presbyterian Church, Glen More; a charter member of Glen More Fire Co., and a supervisor in Wallace Township for 30 years.
  Surviving are a son, Kenneth R., Glen More, a grandson and three great-grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be at 1:30 p.m. Wednesday from Fairview Church.
  The Rev. Dr. Erwin W. Zinger, pastor, will officiate.
  Interment will be in the church cemetery.
  A viewing will be from noon to 1:30 p.m. Wednesday.
  The Ralph W. Ralston Funeral Home, Downingtown, is in charge of arrangements.

COMSTOCK -- On Friday, May 15, 1970,
  Frank Comstock, husband of the late Elsie (McLaughlin) Comstock, of Glen Moore, Pa., age 87 years.  Relatives and friends are invited to the services from Fairview Presbyterian Church of Glen Moore, on Wednesday, May 20 at 1:30 p.m.  Interment in the adjoining cemetery.  Friends may call at the church Wednesday afternoon from 12 noon to 1:30 p.m.

William D. Cornell
 
Funeral services for William Buck Cornell, 53, were held at 4 p.m. Wednesday in the Amanda Pentecostal Holiness Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dallas Hatchell, Burial was in the Willow Creek Cemetery near Evergreen.
 
Mr. Cornell, a farmer of the Evergreen community, died Monday after an illness of three weeks.  He was a veteran of World War I.
 
He was born in Florence County, Aug. 20, 1890, a son of the late Willie Cornell and Ida Barnes Cornell.
 
Surviving are two sons, Wilbur C. Cornell of Savannah, Ga., and Curtis T. Cornell of Dillsburg, Pa.; one daughter, Mrs. Miriam White of Savannah, Ga.; two sisters, Mrs L.A. Reddick of Florence and Mrs. Letha Dees of Charleston, two half brothers, Franklin Cornell of Winnsboro and Melvin Cornell of Columbia;  also 13 grandchildren.
 
Stoudemire Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

William B Cornell
 
  William Buck Cornell, 82, of Florence, R 3, died at 9:30 p.m. Monday at a local hospital after an illness of three weeks.  The Florence County farmer, a veteran of World War I, is survived by two sons, Wilbur B Cornell, Savannah, Ga., and Curtis T Cornell, Dillsbury, Pa.; a daughter, Mrs. Miriam White, Savannah, Ga.; two sisters, Mrs. L.A. Reddick of Florence and Mrs. Letha Dees, Charleston; 13 grandchildren.  Two half-brothers, Franklin Cornell of Winnsboro and Melvin Cornell of Columbia also survive.
  Funeral arrangements will be announced later.  Stoudenmire Funeral Home is in charge.

William B. Cornell
 
Funeral services for William Buck Cornell, 63, will be held at 4 p.m. today in the Amanda Pentecostal Holiness Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dallas Hatchell, Burial will be in the Willow Creek Cemetery near Evergreen.
 
Pallbearers will be J.B. Lamb, Foster Hill, Monroe Hill, Ham Hayes, Charles Powell and Clifton Hewitt.
 
Mr. Cornell died at 9:30 p.m. Monday at a local hospital after an illness of three weeks.  He was a farmer of the Evergreen Community and a veteran of World War I.
 
He was born in Florence County, Aug. 20, 1890, a son of the late Willie Cornell and Ida Barnes Cornell.
 
Surviving are two sons, Wilbur B Cornell of Savannah, Ga., and Curtis T. Cornell of Dillsburg, Pa.; a daughter, Mrs. Miraw White of Savannah, Ga.; two sisters, Mrs L.A. Reddick of Florence and Mrs. Letha Dees of Charleston, two half brothers, Franklin Cornell of Winnsboro and Melvin Cornell of Columbia;  also 13 grandchildren.
 
Stoudemire Funeral Home will have charge of arrangements.

Midway - Gwendolyn Miriam Conner , 70, died Tuesday, July 5, 2005 at her residence after a short illness.
 
Mrs. Conner was a native of Duval County, Florida who had lived in Liberty County since 1992, having moved here from Savannah. Gwendolyn was born April 7, 1935 to Wilbur Cornell and the late Marie Leece Cornell. She was a member of the Midway United Methodist Church, the Midway United Methodist Women and the Midway United Methodist Happy Hearts, Gwendolyn was a Home Maker who loved to Crochet.
 
Survivors: husband of 51 years, Jim Franklin Conner of Midway; daughter and son-in-law, Theresa Ann and David J. Carlevale of Tampa, Florida; son and daughter-in-law, Jim Franklin and Donna Conner of Saraland, Alabama; father, Wilbur B. Cornell of Hinesville; sisters and brothers-in-law, Marie and Brian Plough of Hinesville and Sonia and Eddie Turner of Mt. Vernon, Texas; several nieces, nephews and her beloved Yorkie Baby, Cinnamon Sugar; three granddaughters and one grandson.
 
Visitation: The Family will receive friends Wednesday, July 6, 2005 at the Thomas L. Carter Funeral Home from 5:00 until 7:00 p.m.
 
Services: Funeral services will be held Thursday, July 7, 2005 at 11:00 a.m. at the Midway United Methodist Church with the Revs John Walker and Wayne DeFore officiating, burial will follow in the Church Cemetery.
 
Pallbearers: Charles Conner , Joe Conner , James Conner , John Henderson, John Sharpe and Michael Plough.
 
Remembrances: Midway United Methodist Church.
 
Thomas L. Carter Funeral Home

Glen Rose man killed
 
  A Glen Rose man was killed Monday night after his motorcycle struck a car on State Highway 144 South.
  Gregory Charles Cornell, 40, a laid-off engineer from Comanche Peak nuclear plant, died of head injuries, said highway patrol trooper Dub Gillum.   
  Gillum gave an account of the 7:45 p.m. accident that occurred near Flip Stop convenience store.
  Cornell was southbound on State Highway 144 South on a 1984 Harley-Davidson motorcycle.  James Roger Shackleford, 39, a Granbury auto mechanic, was southbound ahead of Cornell in a 1969 Ford LTD.  Shackleford slowed down to turn into a private drive.  As Shackleford started to turn, Cornell attempted to pass his vehicle in the northbound lane.  Cornell's motorcycle then struck Shackleford's car in the rear.  Cornell was thrown from the motorcycle and died when his head struck the pavement.  Shackleford's car went off the road after impact and struck a fence.
  Cornell was wearing a helmet at the time of the accident, but it didnâ€™t save his life, said Gillum.  The helmet, which Gillum described as a bowl-style helmet, was not Department of Transportation (DOT) approved.
  A sample of Cornell's blood was taken to determine if alcohol was a factor in the accident, Gillum stated.
  No citations were filed, Gillum reported, adding the investigation is continuing.
  Cornell's body was transferred to Georgia yesterday for burial, Gillum said, adding he is survived by a wife, a 4-year-old son and a 1-year-old daughter.

Mrs. M. W. Cornell
 
  HARTSVILLE -- Mrs. Maggie Woodell Cornell died Saturday night in a Charlotte, N.C. Hospital.
  Funeral services will be conducted at 2 p.m. Monday in the chapel of Brown - Pennington Funeral Home by Rev. LeRoy Collias and Rev. Choate.  Burial will be in Magnolia Cemetery.
  Mrs. Cornell was born in a Columbus County, N.C., a daughter of the late John and Mollie Sellers Woodell.  She had lived in Charlotte, N.C. For the past four years.
  Surviving are two daughters, Mrs. Grover (Becky) Kimrey of Charlotte, N.C., and Mrs. Carey (Dollie) Gardner of Bethune:  two brothers, Tate Woodell and D. Woodell, both of Whiteville, N.C.; and 22 grandchildren.
  Friends may call at the funeral home.

R.E. Cornell
 
HARTSVILLE, Oct 12--Robert E. Cornell, 87, died early today at his home here following a heart attack.  He was born and reared in Florence County and was a retired employee of Sonoco Products Company, having worked there for 26 years.  Funeral services will be conducted in the Emmanuel Baptist Church Sunday at 3 p.m., by Dr. James B Little and the Rev. Henry Lamb.  Burial will follow in Magnolia Cemetery.
 
Survivors include his widow, the former Margaret Anne Woodell; three step children, Mrs. Manuel Jackson and Mrs. Becky Kimsey of Hartsville and Mrs Dollie Gardner, Bethany;  one brother, William Cornell, Florence County; two half brothers, Marvin and Franklin Cornell, Florence county; two sisters, Mrs. Laney Reddick and Mrs. Letha Bowers, Florence county.

MRS. ESTHER DECK
 
  The funeral of Mrs. Esther Deck was held this morning from the late home.  361 North Fifth Street.  Interment occurred at Hamlin.  D.A. Frantz was the undertaker.

Starb -- am letzten Sonntag Morgen, Abraham Deturk, ein alter und geschatzter Burger von Oley Taunschip, dieser Caunty
 
Died - on the last Sunday morning, Abraham Deturk, an old and valued citizen of Oley Township, this County

DETURCK, Philip, an old resident of Oley Twp., this county died some weeks ago, and some days later his brother, Johannes DETURCK died, an old resident of Exeter Twp., this county.
 
Verstarb, von etlichen Wuchen, Philip deTurk, ein alter Einwohner von Oley Taunschip und etliche Tage darnach deser Bruder, Johannes deTurk, ein alter Einwohner von Exeter Taunschip, beyde von dieser Caunty.
 
Died, of several diseases, Philip DeTurk, an old resident of Oley Township and several days after his brother, Johannes DeTurk, an old resident of Exeter Township, both by this County.

Fett
 
Florence D. Fett, 85, formerly of 1204 Delaware Ave., died Saturday at the Daybreak Lodge nursing home, 2801 W. Sixth St., after a long illness.  Mrs. Fett was a secretary for the Du Pont Co. Before retiring 20 years ago.  She was active in the Altar Society of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wilmington.  Her husband, Harold J., died many years ago.  She is survived by a sister, Anna W. Douglas, also living in the Daybreak Lodge.  Services will be tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 at the Chandler Funeral Home, 2506 Concord Pike.  There will be no viewing.  Entombment will follow in Wilmington and Brandywine Cemetery.

FETT - On the 27th inst., FLORENCE E. widow of Floyd W. Fett of 1914 Palm St., age 77 years.
 
The Rev. Dr. Frank E. Radcliffe will officiate at services from the Theo. C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlors, 247 Penn St., Monday at 1 p.m. Interment in Forest Hills Memorial Park. Friends may call Sunday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Florence E. Fett
 
Mr. Florence E. Fett, 77, of 1914 Palm St., died this morning at 7 o'clock in Holy Spirit Hospital, Camp Hill, where she was a patient for one month.
 
Born in Reading, the daughter of the late John C. and Clara E. (Savage) Bechtel, she was preceded in death by her husband, Floyd W. Fett. She was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church.
 
Surviving are three daughters: Clementine, wife of Paul R. Black, Reading; Marjorie, wire of Robert E. Rettgers, Dillsburg, and Gene, wife of George E. May, Whitfield.
 
Services will be on Monday at 1 p.m. in T.C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlor, Rev. Dr. Frank E. Radcliffe officiating. Burial will be in Forest Hills Memorial Park.

SELECTED MAN WEDS
 
TAKES BRIDE FOUR DAYS BEFORE ENTERING THE SERVICE
 
  Amid a shower of rice and good wishes, Mr. And Mrs. Floyd W. Fett left Monday night on their honeymoon trip to Atlantic City, Wilmington and Philadelphia.
  Mr. Fett must be back by Thursday evening as he is one of the selected me who leave on Friday for Camp Meade.  Mrs. Fett is a daughter of Mr and Mrs. John H Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich street.  Her father is manager of the Neversink Planing Mill Co.
  The couple were married at the home of the bride, Rev Gustav R Poetter officiating.  After a repast served to the immediate families, Mr. And Mrs. Fett left on their short honeymoon trip.  They will visit Mr Fett's brother, Harold Fett, cashier of the Mutual Life Insurance Co., Wilmington, and well known in this city.  The couple will spend a day with Mrs. Fett's sister, Mrs. Raymond Wilson, Philadelphia.  On their return the bride will make her home with her parents until Mr. Fett's return.
  It was the plan of the couple to be married Wednesday, but the receipt of the pink card changed their schedule.  Mr. Fett is a printer.

PRINTER-SOLDIER CLAIMS A BRIDE
 
Floyd W. Fett, Under Marching Orders, Weds Miss Florence E. Bechtel
 
  The call to service for the contingent men who will leave for Camp Meade on Friday of this week has claimed another bridegroom in Floyd W. Fett and Florence E. Bechtel, of 229 West Greenwich street.
  The wedding took place at the home of the bride Monday afternoon.  It was a private ceremony, performed by Rev. G. R. Poetter.  The bride wore a traveling suit and carried a corsage bouquet of Killarney roses and lilies of the valley.  They departed on the evening train for Philadelphia to attend a theatre party and will spend a few days in that city on a honeymoon, returning to Reading on Thursday.  The bride may accompany her husband to Camp Meade on Friday.
  Mr. Fett is a son of Mr. And Mrs. John L. Fett, of 1022 Buttonwood street, and has been an efficient printer in the employ of the Telegram and New-Times for several years.  His star will go into the service flag of these papers.  The bride's parents are Mr. And Mrs. J. H. Bechtel.
  The engagement of Miss Ethel A. Lewis, daughter of Mr. And Mrs. Joseph H. Lewis of 822 North Sixth street, and Sergeant Donald B. Keller, son of P. H. Keller, of Colorado, now stationed at Co K., 313th Infantry, N. A., at Camp Meade, has been announced.

Fett Named Potentate
 
Others are Elected At Annual Meeting of Rajah Temple
 
  Floyd W. Fett, advertising representative of the Reading Eagle Times was elected illustrious potentate of the Rajah Temple, Mystic Shrine, last night to succeed Clarence E. Hess of Tamaqua.
  P.C. Fritz Williams of Reading was elevated from assistant rabban to chief rabban - the position vacated by Fett - which puts him next in line for the potentate's post.
[â€¦]
  Fett and Williams were appointed representatives to the Imperial Council in Atlantic City, N.J., in July.
  Fett, the new potentate, has been active in civic organizations for many years and has been a key figure in the establishment of the American Business Club's cerebral palsy clinic in the Charles S. Foos School
  A report by Giles showed that the Temple debt has been decreasing rapidly and that some time in 1954 the Temple will be completely debt-free.
  The Temple membership now exceeds 6,100 and is the highest in more than 25 years, Hetzog reported last night to approximately 700 attending members.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: F.W. Fett Funeral Set For Thursday
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
F.W. Fett Funeral Set for Thursday
 
The funeral of Floyd W. Fett, Reading Eagle-Times advertising salesman and former potentate of Rajah Temple, will be held on Thursday, it was announced. Fett, who was widely known for his Masonic activities as well as in the publishing field, succumbed to a heart attack, on Saturday at his home, 924 Madison Ave. The Rev. Dr. Frank E. Radcliffe will officiate at the funeral service at 1 p.m. in the T.C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlors. Burial will be made in Forest Hills Memorial Park.

FETT - On the 20th inst., FLOYD W. FETT, aged 65 years. Services from the Theo C Auman, Inc. Funeral Parlors. 247 Penn St., Thursday at 1 p.m. Interment in Forest Hills Memorial Park. Friends may call Wednesday evening, 7 to 9.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Floyd W Fett, Local Adman, Dies at 65
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Floyd W. Fett, Local Adman, Dies at 65
 
FLOYD W. FETT
 
Floyd W. Fett, 65, veteran advertising man, former publisher and a past potentate of Rajah Temple, died from a hear attack at 4:15 p.m. yesterday at his home, 924 Madison Ave.
 
He had been under the care of a physician since suffering a heart attack about one year ago, but recently was in apparently good health and on Friday performed his usual duties as a display advertising salesman for the Reading Eagle-Times.  He spent yesterday at home.
 
Early in the afternoon he complained of severe heart pains and went to bed.  Members of the family summoned his physician, but he was dead when the doctor arrived.
 
He was a native of Reading, a son of the late John L and Kathryn B. (Lebo) Fett, and was a veteran of WWI, serving with a U.S. Army unit.
 
Fett in early life was a printer, but left that work to enter the advertising field as a representative of department stores.
 
Later he became publisher of the Reading Shopping Bulletin, a weekly publication, and continued in that position for some years.  He was a display advertising salesman for the Reading Eagle-Times during the last four years.
 
He was widely known for his activities in the Masonic Order and in 1954 was potentate of the Rajah Temple of the Shrine.  In May of that year he was elected to a term as president of the Pennsylvania State Shrine Assn.
 
He was one of 16 applicants for the position of Reading postmaster to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Walter A. Ringler.  In July, 1952, he was declared one of three elligible for the position.
 
Fett was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church; Isaac Hiester Lodge No. 660, F&AM; Reading Consistory and Rajah Temple, and at his death was secretary of the Pennsylvania State Shrine Assn.  He was for many years an active member of Reading Typographical Union No 86 and maintained his membership after his withdrawal from employment as a printer.
 
Surviving are his widow, Florence E (Bechtel) Fett; three daughters; Clementine, wife of Paul R Black, Opa-locka, Fla; Gene C., wife of George E. May, Reading and Marjorie E. wife of Robert E. Rettgers, Laureldale;  also eight grandchildren.
 
T.C. Auman Inc., funeral directors, are in charge of the arrangements.

Sergt. Harold Fett, 1022 Buttonwood street, with the medical corps stationed at Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., was honorably discharged from the hervice.  He will resume his position with the Mutual Life Insurance Co., at Wilmington, Del., May 1.  Mr. Fett is visiting his parents, Mr. And Mrs. John Fett.  He was in the service for 14 months.

Harold J. Fett
 
  Harold J. Fett, 48 of Orange, N.J. And former resident of this city, died in the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J.  He was a son of the late John L and Catharine (Lebo) Fett and was a manager of the Mutual Life Insurance Company office in Newark, N.J.
  Surviving are his widow, Florence (Douglass) Fett, and a brother, Floyd W. Fett, of this city.  Funeral will be private on Saturday.

FETT -- At West Orange, N.J., on Tuesday, June 30, 1942, Harold J., beloved husband of Florence Douglas Fett, 74 Winding way, West Orange.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services at Grace Episcopal Church, Main Street, Orange, on Friday, July 3, at 2 p.m.  Interment at the convenience of the family.  Please omit flowers.

Harold J. Fett, Insurance Manager
 
West Orange Man Headed Newark Agency of Mutual Life of New York
 
  Harold J. Fett of 74 Winding way, West Orange, manager of the Newark agency of the Mutual Life Insurance Co. of New York, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair.  Mr. Fett, 49, had been employed by the Mutual 34 years, a manager since 1926 and in charge of the Newark office since 1939.  He had been ill since February after an operation.
  Mr. Fett was born in Reading, Pa., April 24, 1893.  When he was 15, he was hired as a clerk by the Mutual in his home city.  In 1913 he was sent to Wilmington, Del., and in 1918 he entered the Army.  On his discharge in May 1919, he returned to the Mutual in Wilmington.
  In 1924, Mr. Fett was made super-intendent of agents in Newark, and after service in other cities briefly was made Newark manager.  He was a member of the Life Insurance Trust council of New Jersey, the Life Insurance Underwriters Association of Northern New Jersey and the Life Insurance General Agents and Managers Association of Northern New Jersey.  He was a Mason an had been active in the affairs of Grace Episcopal Church, Orange.
  Mr. Fett leaves his wife, Mrs. Florence D. Fett, and a brother Floyd of Reading.
  The funeral will be conducted in Grace Church at 2 P.M. Friday by Rev. Lane W Barton, the rector.  Burial will be in Rosedale Cemetery.

FETT - In this city, on the 15th inst., JOHN L. Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the Miller Funeral Home, 48 N. 4th St., Wednesday at 2 p.m. Interment in German Lutheran Cemetery. Friends may call Tuesday evening.

JOHN L. FETT
 
  John L. Fett died from complications this morning at his home.  311 North Ninth street.  He was a native of Germany and came to his country 48 years ago.  The last 16 years he was foreman in the tinsmith department of the Textile Machine Works.  Mr. Fett was a member of the Lutheran denomination.  He was for years an active worker in the Democratic party and was also prominent in German societies.  He was president of the German singing societies of Pennsylvania and for 10 years was president of the Reading Liederkranz, retiring from this office one year ago.
  Deceased was the last of his parents' family, a brother having died two years ago.  There survive his widow, Kathryn B. (Lebo) Fett; two sons, Harold J. Fett, Rochester, N.Y. and Floyd W. Fett, Reading, and three grandchildren.  Funeral Director C.I. Miller is in charge.  Interment will be made in the German Lutheran Cemetery on Wednesday.

LIEDERKRANZ NOMINATIONS
 
  The following officers were nominated, with no opposition, for election next month at the monthly meeting of the Liederkranz, held at its home on Chestnut street below ninth:  President, John L Fett; ...

MRS. KATHRYN B. FETT
 
Kathryn B. (Lebo), widow of John L. Fett, died last evening at the home of her son, Floy Fett, 924 Madison avenue. She was a daughter of the late William and Miranda (Zerbe) Lebo. Surviving are two sons, Floyd, with whom she resided, and Harold J. Fett, Rochester, N.J., and three grandchildren. Funeral services Thursday at 2 p.m. at the Lutz Funeral Home, the Rev William A. Fluck officiating. Interment in St. John's Lutheran cemetery.

FETT - In this city, on the 21st inst., KATHRYN B. (nee Lebo), widow of John L. Fett. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the Lutz Funeral Home 2100 Perkiomen Avenue, Thursday at 2 p.m. D.S.T. Interment in St. John's German Lutheran Cemetery. Friends may call at the Funeral Home Wednesday evening, 7 to 9.

Jacob Fies
 
Molltown, Dec 18 -- Jacob Fies, 72, who resided with his son, Leroy, at this place, died yesterday in the Reading Hospital.
  He was a son o the late Henry and Mary (Breneiser) Fies.  He was a member of the Lutheran congregation of Schwarzwald Church, Camp 230, P.O.S. Of A., St. Lawrence, and Modern Woodmen, of Reading.  His wife, Sarah N. (Miller) preceded him in death 25 years.
  Surviving are a daughter, Alberta, wife of Earl Deysher, Pottstown; two sons, Leroy J., with whom he resided, and Chester M., Hyde Villa; five grandchildren and four brothers, John and Alfred, Reading; William Turbotville, and Walter Lancaster.
  Funeral Wednesday, 1:30 p.m., from the Lutz funeral home.  Interment in St. John's Cemetery, Gibraltar.

FIES -- In Molltown, on the 17th inst., JACOB B. FIES, aged 72 years, 3 months, 21 days.
  Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the Lutz Funeral Home, 2100 Perkiomen Ave., Wednesday, 1:30 p.m.  Interment in St. John's cemetery, Gibraltar.  Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Jacob B. Fies
 
Sarah N., wife of Jacob B. Fies, died at her residence, near Lorane, at 5:30 a.m. today, of a complication of diseases, after an illness extending about a year, aged 42 years, 10 months, and 5 days.  She is survived by her husband and three children, Alberta, Chester M. and J.  Leroy, at home.  Her parents, James V. and Mary Miller, St. Peters, Chester County; two sisters, Ida, wife of John Turbot, Reading, and Mrs. Joseph Loomis, Spring City, and two brothers, Morris Miller, Coatesville, and Theodore S. Miller, McKees Rock, also remain.

FIES -- In Exeter, on the 23d inst., SARAH ANN, wife of Jacob Fies, aged 42 years, 10 months, and 5 days.
 Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, near Lorane, Monday at 1 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in St John's cemetery, Gibraltar.

Edward L Frees
 
  Edward L. Frees, 815 Douglass street, died suddenly last evening at his home, aged 58 years.  Dr. S.B. Glick, coroner, issued a certificate of death due to a heart attack.
  He was a son of the late Millard and Sallie (Lessig) Frees, and was born in this city.  He was employed as a flagman by the Reading Company, having a continuous record of 42 years of service.  He entered the employ of the Reading at the age of 16.  He was a member of the First E.C. Church Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, P. & R. Relief Association.
  Surviving are his widow, Rose V. (Hayden); five sons, William, Pottsville; Millard, Edward, Harold and Melvin, all of this city; three sisters, Ida M. Frees; Alice, wife of Matthew Fleischman, both of Reading; Florence, West Reading, also two grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be held Friday at 2 o'clock at the Henninger Funeral Home, the Rev. A.W. Cooper officiating.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

FREES -- In this city, on the 27th inst., EDWARD L., husband of Rose V. (need Hayden) Frees, 815 Douglass Street, aged 58 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 North Fifth Street, on Friday at 2 p.m.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery, Friends may call Thursday evening at the Funeral Home.

FREY -- Fell asleep Sunday, June 7, ADALINE B FREY, in her 94th year.
  Relatives and friends and all organizations of which she was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the mortuary parlors of Theodore C Auman, Thursday, June 11, at 9 a.m. 247 Penn Street, city.  Entombment in Memorial Mausoleum.  Remains can be viewed on Wednesday evening at the residence.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Son of Joe L Friar and Laney Carnell Friar Reddick
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Joe D. Friar
 
  Joe Davis Friar, 51, farmer of the Effingham section of Florence County, died at 10:30 p.m. Monday in a local hospital after a brief illness.
  Funeral services will be conducted at 3 p.m. Wednesday in Willow Creek Pentecostal Holiness Church by the Rev U.T. Baldwin pastor; the Rev. B. E. Parnell pastor of Amenuel Pentecostal Holiness Church of Lake City and the Rev. D. F. Hatchell, pastor of Swansea Pentecostal Holiness Church.  Burial will follow in the Garden of Memories, formerly the Old Willow Creek Methodist Church Cemetery.
  Serving as active bearers will be Winston Matthews, Hoyt Yarborough, W.C. Baxley, W.C. Barnhill, Bunno Lee and Leonard Broach.
  Mr Frier, a lifelone citizen of Florence County was born Dec 25, 1903, a son of the late Joe and Laney Carnell Friar Reddick, both of Florence County.  He was a member of Lebanon Free Will Baptist Church of Effingham, but had attended Willow Creek Pentecostal Holiness Church for the past several years.
  Surviving are his widow, Mrs Bessie Broach Friar and one adopted daughter, Elizabeth Stone Friar, both of Effingham; three half sisters, Mrs. Thad Hicks of Scranton, Mrs. Robert Hillson of Charleston, and Mrs. Frank Simpson of Las Vegas, Nev.; one brother, J.L. Friar of Florence; four half-brothers, Manton Reddick of Effingham, Robert Reddick of Georgetown, Lee Reddick and Willie Reddick, both of Charleston.  The body of Mr. Friar will be taken to the church at 2 p.m. To remain there after the services.
  Waters Funeral Home is in charge of the arrangements.

Franklin B Fry died at his residence, 110 South 9th, aged 47 years.  Deceased had been suffering with valvular affection of the heart, cause by inflammatory rheumatism, to which he had been subject during the last few years, and was confined to his room for 2 months.  He was born in this city and his father was at one time proprietor of the Union house.  Mr. Fry was a cabinetmaker by occupation and was at one time in the employ of Charles Henninger, but for some years worked fro G.S. Herbine.  Deceased was well known and leaves a large number of friends.  He served during the war and was a member of Post 16, G.A.R.  Mr. Fry leaves a widow and 2 sons, Harry O. Fry and Frank Fry, Jr.  Mrs. Fry was formerly the widow of the late Horace T. Bertolet, and 4 step-children also survive.

FREY -- In this city, on Monday morning, Aug 12, 1889.  Franklin B Frey.
  The relatives and friends and also McLean Post No. 16, G.A.R., and the members of the Rainbow Fire Co., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, 110 South Ninth Street, on Friday, Aug. 16th at 2 o'clock p.m.  Interment at Charles Evans cemetery.

An Aged Lady's Life
 
Mrs. Hannah Fry, who will celebrate her 91st Birthday tomorrow -- the Mother of 9 children -- Sheared Sheep and Spun Wool in Her Younger Days
  Birdsboro:  In these days of hurry and scurry, disregard for the rules of hygiene and other regulations that conduces to longevity, one scarcely hears of the survival of a resident beyond the three score and ten limit.  Should there perchance be one who reached the age of "four score years," such person is regarded as one specially favored by Providence, and the dwellers in the neighborhood flock to see him or her and listen to the recital of long ago happening and endeavoring to learn the secret of their drawn out lease of life.
  Birdsboro feels proud of the distinction of having a dweller in its midst who has withstood the tempestuous sea for the unusual period of more than 90 years.  This person is Mrs. Hannah Fry, who on Monday next, Sept. 23, will celebrate the 91st anniversary of her birth.  The history of this old lady is a very interesting one and her memory reaches back to the war of 1812.
  Mrs. Fry was born September 23, 1804, in Robeson, about 1 1/2 miles from the Plow church.  Her father was Jacob Seibert, a thrifty farmer, who prided himself upon the constant find condition of his land and his successful raising of stock.  Her mother's name was Catharine, and she was the daughter of Jasper Wolf, who also was a farmer living near Beckersville.  When a girl, Mrs. Fry attended the Plow school, a short distance from her father's house; but the frequent necessity of her remaining at home to assist her mother in the housework, dairy, etc., deprived her of the means of acquiring much if an education, and her knowledge of books is very limited.  She feels the loss of advantages in this direction exceedingly, as she could employ her time in reading, were she better skilled in the art.
  She was married to Peter Fry, of Robeson, who was then a school teacher and afterwards worked at the stone-mason trade.  He died 22 years ago and Mrs. Fry no makes her home with Mrs. Charles Painter, her granddaughter, on Mill st., this borough.  After the death of her husband, she states, that many of her friends advised her to marry a second time, but she disdained their counsel, thinking that she had had trouble enough in one experience.  She kindly cautioned your representative against taking a matrimonial step and assured him that she make a point of similarly discouraging all her young friends.
  Mrs. Fry had 3 brothers, John, Jacob, and Abram, all of whom are now dead after reaching ages varying from 60 to 70 years.  Her sisters, of whom she had 3, were Kate, who was first married to Isaac Glass and after this death to Isaac Witman; Betsy, married to Geo. Blankenbiller, and Mary, who was never married.  All these are now dead, the last named having passed to her rest last August, aged 80 years.
  Mrs. Fry has in her possession a certificate that is written in German and decorated with many colored drawings as a border, and is filled out as follows:
  "Mrs. Hannah Fry, daughter of Jacob Seibert and his wife Catharine (Wolf), was born in Robeson township, Berks county, September 23, 1804, a three o'clock in the morning.  Baptized in infancy in the Plow church by Rev. John Plott.  The sponsors were Casper Wolf and wife, Catharine."
  The writing is in a very good hand, and distinct, while the certificate, with the exception of a few breaks where the folds are, is in a very good state of preservation.
  The old lady was a regular attendant upon the services at the Plow church for many years, but did not become a member of any congregation until she came to reside in Birdsboro.  She then decided to identify herself with St. Mark's Lutheran church here, and was confirmed by the pastor, Rev. Z. H. Gable, on Saturday afternoon, April 29, 1983, and has since been a consistent communicant and attended service whenever able to do so.  Many are the interesting reminiscences of life of this aged lady and in relating some of them she spoke of the FALLING OF THE STARS in the month of August, 1833.  She had gotten up very early in the morning to prepare breakfast for her husband, who intended to walk to Birdsboro, where he was employed up the mason work of the large grist mill building now operated by Reigner & Focht.  The heavens were full of shooting stars and the sight was one she will never forget.  It caused her much alarm and in describing what she thought was the "world coming to an end." she said:  "The stars fell like snow-flakes, some appearing to touch the earth."  She was afraid to permit her husband to leave for his work, and it was not until daylight appeared that her courage returned and she granted him her consent.
  In those days there was no watchmaker nearer than Reading and the residents of the rural districts were obliged to await the periodical visits of an itenerant clock repairer to have their time-pieces cleaned and adjusted.  It happened that this wandering mechanic came into the neighborhood the day following the phenomenon of the "falling stars" to whom Mrs. Fry related what she had seen in connection with it and expressed her superstitious fears of its being an ill-omen.  The visitor, who was a German, dispelled her anxiety by explaining that "the stars at certain times fall to the earth to clean themselves."
  She was a lover of horseback riding and in this manner made weekly trips to the country store with butter and eggs and brought back groceries needed for the household.  In her girlhood days wheat and rye were mixed together as a substitute for coffee, and was regarded as a great luxury.  Her father raised a great many sheep and before she was married she was obliged to assist in shearing them and to spin the wool into cloth.  She took great pleasure in the work and became quite an adept in spinning both the flax and wool.  She used to knit all the stockings for the household, and after her marriage made in this way all the hosiery required for their own family, thinking it but a trifling task to finish a pair of long-leg stockings in two days, besides doing the entire work about her kitchen and dairy.
  Mrs. Fry's stories of deep snows, heavy rains, high water,  husking parties, apple-butter stirrings, etc., are of such unusual happenings to the youth of today that she is never at a loss to secure an audience to listen to her interesting recitals of all those events of her early life.  Her first experience of the novelty of riding upon a railroad train was when she came from Joanna to Birdsboro upon the Wilmington & Northern a short time after that line was opened for traffic.  She has not quite dispossessed herself of her timidity for railroad travel and still prefers the "good old way" of driving.
  For many years Mrs. Fry has been addicted to the habit of smoking and inadvertently indulges in "a whiff to solace her," and can rarely be found without her pipe.  She acquired the habit when she was quite young, having been advised to smoke to relieve the quinsy, to frequent attacks of which she was subject.  When she is now feeling well she has no desire for her pipe, but says "that as long as her health is good and she knows anything she wants access to pipe and tobacco."
  The story she tells of the sickness occasioned by her attempt to smoke is interesting and laughable in the extreme.  In the whole history of her long life she never tasted liquor but once and then was persuaded to do so by some friends just to see what it was like.  Her story is, that it took the skin off her tongue and her sick so that she resolved never to take it again.  A short time ago she refused to take brandy at her physicians advice when she was ill, but some was put into milk and the taste so disguised that she was unaware of having taken it.  She had per picture taken years ago in the shape of a daguerreotype, which was stolen from her house and never recovered.  In later years some photographs were taken by Charles A Saylor of Reading, to which her features still bear a strong resemblance.
  About 2 years ago Mrs. Fry received her second sight, and is not able to sew and read without the aid of spectacles.  She is not fully acquainted with nature's strange law of providing a "second sight." and states that the reason she does not use glasses is because she cannot get any to suit her eyes and that of the many pairs she has tried in the past 2 years none are equal to giving her the satisfaction that her natural eye serves her.  She is very observant and there is little going on about her that she does not notice and fully perceive.  She is very fond of children and is much beloved by the young folks where she resides, who are ever ready and willing to do her a service.
  During her lifetime she has suffered but little from sickness and always preferred trusting to nature's sway rather than enlist the advice and aid of a physician for said she:  "I never had much faith in doctors."
  At the present time, all things considered, she is in the enjoyment of excellent health, has a good appetite, sleeps well and seldom complains of any suffering.
  Her memory is still true, her hearing acute and her strength of limb and nerve comparatively good, though she uses a cane to aid her in walking about the premises.  She is an exceptionally good talker, has a pleasant voice and is also a most attentive listener, drinking in every word and perceptibly reasoning out all that is said to her.  Her great age could never be divined from her appearance, for her features are quite clear cut and her skin reasonably free from the wrinkled and shrunken condition that characterizes the general effect of "Father Time's" cruel hand.  The greater part of the time this pleasant weather, is spent by her in the large rocking chair in the shade upon the front porch where she reaps much enjoyment from watching the passing vehicles and in frequent short talks with the passers-by, numbers of whom are well acquainted with her and invariably stop to speak a kind word of recognition and compliment her upon her good health, etc.
  She has a remarkably sweet disposition and is kindly affectionate toward all, especially so to her granddaughter, Mrs. Painter, with whom she lives, and whom she dearly loves.  She is ever ready to praise the offices of good that Mrs. Painter has bestowed upon her and expresses it as her greatest desire that she should be allowed to pass the residue of her existence near her side, and within the sound of her voice.
  Mrs. Fry's matrimonial life was blessed with 9 children, of which 1 succumbed to an attack of measles when 5 years old, and 2 others lived until they were upwards of 50 years.  Six still survive - 4 boys and 2 girls.  Of the boys, Bently and Jacob reside in Birdsboro, Heber at Joanna, and John at Beckersville, while of the daughters, Mrs. Robert Westley lives at Joanna and Mrs. Lot Buckwalter at Reading.
  Her descendants number many, there being no less than 77 great-grandchildren and 4 great-great-grandchildren.  The old lady has of a truth "grown old gracefully," and her present comparative sprightliness augurs the enjoyment of more years upon earth, surrounded by kind friends who will spare no pains to make her pathway one of ease to the end of life.

Death of Mrs. Peter Fry, Aged 93 Years.
Feb 14 - Hannah, widow of Peter Fry, died at the residence of her niece, Mrs. Charles Painter, Mill St. on Sunday night.  Deceased was ill for nearly a year with the weakness incident to old age and pass away peacefully.   She was 93 years of age and up to the time of her last illness, had been remarkably free from any ailment during her long life.  She was beloved by all who knew her and her many friends greatly enjoyed her companionship and she passed many an hour in reciting the varied experiences of her early days.  Her children who survive are Heber, of Joanna; John, of Beckersville, Jacob of Birdsboro; Mrs. Robert Westley, Joanna, and Mrs Charlotte Buckwalter, of Reading.  Her funeral will be held form the residence of Charles Painter, Mill st., Thursday morning, Feb 17, at 9:30, to proceed by carriages to the Plow church, when services will be conducted by Rev Z. H. Gable.  The arrangements will be in charge of Director A. E. Mauger.

Feb. 17. -- The funeral of Mrs. Hannah Fry took place from the residence of Charles Painter, Mill st.   Short services were held at the house by Rev. Z. H. Gable, after which the friends proceeded by carriages to the Plow church, where further services were held and a sermon preached.  Interment in the cemetery adjoining the church.  The remains were attired in a black dress and lay in a walnut casket, having silver-plated handles and plate inscribed "At Rest."  The bearers were chosen from among the neighbors of the deceased.  Raymond Mohr & Son were the funeral directors.

Mrs. Hannah Fry, widow of Peter Fry, died at the residence of her niece, Mrs. Charles Painter, Birdsboro, on Sunday night.  Deceased was ill for nearly a year with the weakness incident to old age and passed away peacefully.  She was 93 years of age and up to the time of her last illness had been remarkably free from any ailment during her long life.  Her children who survive her are Heber, of Joanna; John, of Beckersville; Jacob, of Birdsboro; Mrs. Robert Westley, of Joanna, and Mrs. Charlotte Buckwalter, of Reading.

Mrs. Henry Fry
 
  Rebecca V.R., widow of Henry Fry, of Lancaster, died while on a visit to her son, William H. Fry, at Whitehall, Ill., on Saturday, in the 76th year of her age.  She was the last of her family.  Mrs. Fry is survived by her sons, William H. Fry, of Whitehall, Ill.; John C. Fry, of Lenhart, Kas., and Mrs. Clara C. Zahm, of Lancaster.  For many years Mrs. Fry was a resident of Lancaster and a consistent member of St. Paul's Memorial Reformed church.  Undertaker Francis F. Seidel will have charge of the funeral.

FRY -- At Whitehall, Illinois, on the 16th inst., REBECCA V.R., widow of Henry Fry, aged 75 years, 9 months and 10 days.
  Due notice of the funeral will be given.

Douglas Frye
Warrenville - Mr. Douglas L. "Doug" Frye, 71, of Warrenville, SC, husband of Mildred Walker Frye and the late Shirley L. Frye, entered into rest peacefully on Wednesday, November 22, 2017, in the comfort of his home.
Born in California, a son of the late Franklin and Inez McManus Frye, he grew up in Clearwater Beach, FL, until making Aiken County, SC, his home in 1971. He was a very dedicated and active member of Bath First Baptist Church and retired from Bill Vernon Chevrolet, where he was a Paint and Body Technician. Doug enjoyed woodworking, watching birds, hunting, fishing and was an avid Braves fan.
In addition to his wives and parents, family members include his children and their spouses, Robert Mike'l and Valerie Sanford, Graniteville, SC, Jimmy Ray and Stacy Sanford, Saluda, SC, Dana and Eddie Parish, Hephzibah, GA and the late Eddie Frye, siblings, Linda Smith, OH and Geri Trueblood, FL; grandchildren, Ninette, Mike'l, Kyle, Caity, Jeffery, Joshua, Jeremy and the late Andie and six great-grandchildren.
The family will greet friends on Sunday, November 26, 2017, from 2 until 4 o'clock at Hatcher Funeral Home and Cremation Svc., 3464 Jefferson Davis Hwy., Graniteville, SC. A Celebration of Life Service will be held on Monday, November 27, 2017, at 2 o'clock at Bath First Baptist Church, Bath, SC. Pastor Herb Sons will officiate. Interment will follow in Langley Cemetery, Langley, SC. Doug will be placed in the church at 1 o'clock on Monday.
It has been requested by the family, that memorials be made to Solomon's Project at Bath First Baptist Church P.O. Box 240 Bath, SC 29816. (www.bathfbc.org)
Visit www.HatcherFuneralHome.com to share memories and leave a message of hope and encouragement for the family.

Mr. Eddie Frye
 
Supply Room Clerk
 
WARRENVILLE -- Mr. Eddie F. Frye, 24, of 112 Hill and Dale Drive, died Monday, July 18, 1994 in Aiken.
  The funeral will be at 11 a.m. Saturday at Hatcher Funeral Home, with the Rev. Roland Smith officiating.  Burial will be in Sunset Memory Gardens, Langley.
  Mr. Frye, a native of Clearwater, Fla., was a supply clerk with Carlisle Tire and Rubber Co. and a Baptist.
  Survivors include his mother, Naomi Smith Elliot, Chiefland, Fla.; his father, Douglas L. Frye, Sr. Warrenville; his stepmother, Shirley Quackenbush Frye, Warrenville; his maternal grandmother, Dorothy Smith, Safety Harbor, Fla.; his step-grandmother, Eunice Quackenbush, Warrenville; three brothers, Douglas L. Frye, Jr., Bessemer, Mik'l Sanford, New Ellenton, and Jimmy Sanford, Warrenville; and three sisters, Deborah Gregory, Gallatin, Tenn., Della McGuire, Hudson, Fla., and Dana Crook, Warrenville.
  Pallbearers will be Bo Quackenbush, Stanley Quackenbush, Kevin Gregory, Mark Quackenbush, Roger Henry, Randy Quackenbush; and Larry Gregory Jr.
  Friends may call at the residence or from 7 to 9 p.m. Today at the funeral home.

Mr. Eddie Frye
 
Supply Room Clerk
 
WARRENVILLE -- Mr. Eddie F. Frye, 24, of 112 Hill and Dale Drive, died Monday, July 18, 1994 in Aiken.
  The funeral will be at 11 a.m. Saturday at Hatcher Funeral Home, with the Rev. Roland Smith officiating.  Burial will be in Sunset Memory Gardens, Langley.
  Mr. Frye, a native of Bessemer, Ala., was a supply clerk with Carlisle Tire and Rubber for two and a half years, and was a Baptist.
  Survivors include his mother, Naomi Smith Elliot, Chief land, Fla.; his father, Douglas L. Frye, Sr. Warrenville; his stepmother, Shirley Quackenbush Frye, Warrenville; his maternal grandmother, Dorothy Smith, Safety Harbor, Fla.; his step-grandmother, Eunice Quackenbush, Warrenville; three brothers, Douglas L. Frye, Jr., Bessemer, Mik'l Sanford, New Ellenton, and Jimmy Sanford, Warrenville; and three sisters, Deborah Gregory, Gallatin, Tenn., Della McGuire, Hudson, Fla., and Dana Crook, Warrenville.
  Pallbearers will be Bo Quackenbush, Stanley Quackenbush, Kevin Gregory, Mark Quackenbush, Roger Henry, Randy Quackenbush; and Larry Gregory Jr.
