SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Washington County Georgia Newspaper Clippings, Vol II, Tad Evans, pg 72
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription: Until Thursday last, we did not know of the death of out highly esteemed old countryman, Capt. James Gainer.  He bade adieu to the cares on earth on the 16th ult., beloved by the whole county.  He was perhaps one of the oldest citizens of the county, having resided here from boyhood.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Washington County Georgia Newspaper Clippings, Vol II, Tad Evans, pg 71
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription: Departed this life in Washington County, on the 16th day of July, 1869, Capt. James Gayner, in the 87th year of his age.  He was born in the State of North Carolina, was brought by his parents to this county when a small boy, where he continued to live until the day of his death, highly respected and beloved by all who knew him.  It can be truly said of him, that he was an honest man.

HENRY M. GASKINS
 
  FLORENCE -- Henry McLaurin Gaskins, 89, a retired motel owner-operator, farmer and businessman, died Friday in a local hospital.  The funeral will be at 4 p.m. Sunday in Stoudenmire-Dowling Funeral Home.  Burial will be in Mount Hope Cemetery.
  Mr. Gaskins was born in Lake City, a son of Bryant A. Gaskins and Mary Jane Evans Gaskins.  He was a graduate of Georgia College of Commerce and was a former member of Liberty Baptist Church near Lake City and was a member of First Baptist Church of Florence.
  Surviving are his wife, Lula Langston Gaskins and a sister, Nellie Atkinson of Florence.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: From the Florence County, South Carolina Library
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Lula L. Gaskins
  FLORENCE -- Lula Langston Gaskins, 82, of 1305 Clarendon Ave., died Saturday morning, July 20, 1996, at her residence after an illness.
  Funeral service will be at 4 p.m. Monday in the Stoudemire-Dowling Funeral Home chapel.  Burial will follow in Mount Hope Cemetery.
  Mrs. Gaskins was born in Florence County, a daughter of the late Fleetwood and Anna Nunnery Langston.  She was a retired motel owner and operator and was a retired nurse.  She was a graduate of the Saunders Memorial Hospital School of Nursing.  Mrs. Gaskins was a member of the First Baptist Church in Florence and a former member of the Liberty Baptist Church near Lake City.
  She was preceded in death by her husband, Henry McLaurin Gaskins, who died in 1993 and by a son, Henry Milton Gaskins, who died in 1976.
  Surviving are a daughter, Lula Von Morris Baxley of Effingham;  four grand-children, three great-grandchildren, three great-great-grandchildren and a number of nieces and nephews.
  The family will receive friends from 7 to 9 p.m. Today at the funeral home.

MRS. HENRY A. HAGEMAN
 
  Sallie (Lebo) Hageman, wife of Henry A. Hageman, 1034 Green street, died at 8:55 p.m. Monday in the Reading Hospital.  She was aged 63 years.  She was a member of St. Luke's Lutheran Church and besides her husband, is survived by one son, Paul, of this city, and two grandchildren; a sister, Mrs. John L Fett, of this city, and a brother, of Toledo, O. Funeral Director Miller removed the remains to her home.

Mrs. Henry A. Hagenman
  The funeral of Sallie, wife of Henry A. Hagenman, took place from her residence, 1034 Green street.  Rev. W.A. Fluck officiated at the house.  Under the direction of Funeral Director Miller interment was made in Trinity Lutheran cemetery.

HAGEMAN -- In West Reading, on the 2d inst., SALLIE, wife of Henry A Hagenman, aged 62 years, 11 months, 13 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 1034 Green St. Friday afternoon, 1:30.  Services at the house.  Interment in Trinity Lutheran Cemetery.

Henry A. Hagemann
 
  Henry A. Hagemann, 85, died last night at his home, 1034 Green St.  He was a retired employee of the Carpenter Steel Company.  Surviving is his widow, Rose Hagemann.
  Funeral Saturday afternoon at [?] from the Gibson Funeral Home where services will be conducted by the Rev. Maynard C. Hallock.  Interment in St. John's Lutheran Cemetery.

HAGEMANN -- On the 18th inst., HENRY A HAGEMANN aged 85 years.
  Services from the gibson Funeral Home, 1501-03 N 11th St. Saturday 1:30 p.m.  Interment in St. John's Lutheran Cemetery.  Friends may call Friday evening 7 to 9.

Mrs. Corinne Hargett
 
  WAYNESBORO, Ga. -- Mrs. Corinne McNeely Hargett of Waynesboro died Monday in a Burke County hospital.
  The funeral services was to be held at 3 p.m. Today in DeLoach Funeral home Chapel with the Rev. Robert Wagnon officiating.  Burial was to be in the Bethany Methodist Church cemetery near Girard, Ga.
  A native of Jefferson County, she had lived in Waynesboro 31 years and was a nurse.  She was a member of the Bethany Methodist Church.
  Survivors include one sister, Mrs. R.C. Sasser, Savannah, Ga.
  Pallbearers were to include Lamar Heath, Edward Heath, Ashley Heath, Thomas McNeely, Donald Self, and Larry Tyndal.
  Honorary pallbearers were to include the nursing staff of the Burke County Hospital.

A. Hartenstine Sr.
 
  Abram Hartenstine Sr., 86, of 2611 Summit Ave., Broomall, a retired carpenter and Broomall resident 50 years, died suddenly Saturday at home.
  Retired only three years, he was born in Pine Swamp, Pa., and was the husband of the late Sarah Jane Hartenstine.
  Surviving are four sons, William of Rosemont, Percy, at home, Burton of Broomall and Abram Jr. Of Larchmont; three daughters, Mrs. William Miller of Broomall, Mrs. Ivy Campbell of Larchmont and Harriet, at home; a brother, David of Valley Forge; a half-brother, Frank Comstock of Glenmore; 9 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.
  Services were Tuesday at his home with burial in Marple Presbyterian Churchyard.

BERTHA HARTENSTINE
 
  Funeral services for Bertha (Boyer) Hartenstine were held yesterday at 2:30 at the Valley Forge Baptist Church by the Rev. William C. Blatt, pastor of Otterbein United Brethren Church, Mont Clare.  Burial was in the adjoining cemetery.  Pallbearers were Ralph Phillips, Roy Hildebrandt, Joseph Ravis, George Nixon, Albert Ritchards and George Ritchards.

HARTENSTINE -- In Valley Forge, Pa., on August 15, 1947, Bertha (Boyer), wife of David B. Hartenstine, aged 71 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services at Valley Forge Baptist Church, on Tuesday afternoon August 19, 1947, at 2:30 p.m.  Interment in adjoining cemetery.  Friends may call at the A.C. Bishop Funeral Home, 310 Main Street, on Monday evening, from 7 to 9 o'clock.

MRS. BERTHA HARTENSTINE
 
  Mrs. Bertha Boyer Hartenstine, wife of David B. Hartenstine, died early last night at her home in Valley Forge, following a lingering illness.
  Daughter of the late Mordica and Ann Whitaker Boyer, she was born in East Nantmeal township, where she lived on a farm until her marriage.  Since 1917 she resided in Valley Forge, where Mr. Hartenstine is employed by the Park Commission.
  Mrs. Hartenstine was a member of the Otterbein Evangelical United Brethren Church, Mont Clare; also the following lodges: P.O. Of A. Lodge 272, Valley Forge; Lady Eagles of Phoenixville; Order of Lady Owls, Norristown Nest 1644, and Tuesday Afternoon Club, Valley Forge.
  In addition to her husband she is survived by two brothers, Horace Boyer, Pottstown, and George Y. Boyer, of Lansdale, and a sister, Mrs. Sarah Halterman, of Pottstown.
  Funeral services will be held at the Valley Forge Baptist Church on Tuesday, at 2:30 p.m., with burial in the adjoining cemetery.  Friends may call Monday night at the A.C. Bishop Funeral Home, 310 Main Street.

HARTENSTINE -- In Brentwood, Md. on the 8th inst., CLARENCE H. HARTENSTINE, aged 54 years.
  Services [...] Miller Funeral Home, 48 N. 4th St, on Wednesday at 2 p.m.  Interment in Pine Swamp Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening.

Clarence H. Hartenstine
 
Clarence H. Hartenstine, 54, died yesterday in his home in Brentwood, Md.  Born in Pottstown, he was a machinist for the U.S. Navy.  He was a son of the late Jacob S and Ida (Miller) Hartenstine and was a member of Lodge 62, F and A.M. Reading Consistory, Scottish Rites Masons and the Methodist denomination.
  Surviving are his widow, Daisy F. Althouse Hartenstine; a step-daughter, Pearl, wife of Martin White, Brentwood, and two sisters, Mary, widow of Walter Ringler, and Laura, widow of Capt. I.B. Rettgers, both of Reading.
Services Wednesday at 2 p.m. in the Miller Funeral Home, the Rev. Charles S Kerr officiating.  Burial in Pine Swamp Cemetery.

HARTENSTINE -- On the 16th inst., DAISY (nee Althouse) widow of Clarence HARTENSTINE.
  Services from Miller Funeral Home.  48 N. 4th St., Saturday, 11 a.m.  Friends may call Friday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Daisy Hartenstine
 
  Funeral arrangements have been completed for Mrs. Daisy (Althouse) Hartenstine, 50, widow of Clarence Hartenstine, of 225 N. Front St., who died yesterday in the Reading Hospital.
  Services will be conducted Saturday at 11 a.m. In the Miller Funeral Home.  Burial will take place in Bern Church Cemetery.
  Mrs. Hartenstine was a daughter of the late Morris and Mary Alice (Pauley) Althouse and was a member of the evangelical and Reformed Church.  Her husband died last March.  Surviving is a daughter, Pearl, wife of Martin White, Blandonsburg, Md.

Mrs. Daisy F. Hartenstine
 
  Mrs. Daisy F. Hartenstine, 50, of 225 N. 4th St., died this morning in the Reading Hospital.  Arrangements for the funeral have not been completed pending the arrival of relatives from Maryland.

D.B. Hartenstine Dies in Hospital
 
  David B. Hartenstine, 84, widower of Bertha (Boyer) Hartenstine, Valley Forge, died Tuesday at the Phoenixville hospital.
  He was born at Pine Swamp, Warwick township, where he lived until 1917 as a farmer.  He then moved to Valley Forge where he worked at the park until a year ago when he retired because of illness.
  Mr. Hartenstine is survived by a half brother, Frank Comstock, Glen Moore, and a number of nieces and nephews.
  He was a member of Mont Clare United Brethren church, Valley Forge chapter 150 Patriotic Order Sons of America, Lodge 272, Valley Forge Patriotic Order of Americans.
  Funeral services are Friday at 2 p.m. From the Bishop Funeral home, Phoenixville.  Burial will be in Valley Forge Baptist cemetery.

HARTENSTINE -- in Phoenixville Hospital on Tuesday, June 28, 1960.  David B., husband of the late Bertha (Boyer) Hartenstine, aged 84 years.  Relatives and friends and members of all organizations with which he was affiliated are invited to attend funeral services at the Bishop Funeral Home, 310 Main St., Phoenixville on Friday July 1, at 2 p.m.  Interment in Valley Forge Baptist Cemetery.  Friends may call at the funeral home on Thursday evening, 7 to 9.

Death of Mrs. Jacob B. Hartenstine
 
  Elizabeth Jane Nicols, wife of Jacob B. Hartenstine, died at the residence of her husband, No. 407 Walnut street, Thursday, of chronic heart troubles, aged 56 years, 8 months, and 12 days.  The deceased was afflicted for over two years, during which time she was confined to her home.  She was the mother of 8 children, only two of whom survive:  Horace Hartenstine, at home, and Mrs. Bertha Ludwig, No 691 South Street.  Deceased was the daughter of Anna Nichols, of Phila, and the late Jacob Nicols.  She leaves 5 brothers and one sister:  Ellias, of Pottstown; Lewis, Phoenixville; Isaac, Port Kennedy; Jacob D., Maurice F. And Mrs. Mary Cloud, of Phila.  Mrs. Hartenstine was a member of the First M.E. Church.  Funeral on Monday, November 10, at 10:30 o'clock.

Funeral services for HARRY W. HARTENSTINE, 77, of WILMINGTON, DEL., and a native of Warwick township, will be conducted at 8 o'clock tonight in his residence with further services in Pine Swamp Evangelical church at 2:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.  Burial will be made in the cemetery adjoining the church.
  Mr. Hartenstine died Friday in Wilmington General Hospital.  He suffered a stroke the past Monday.
  He was a son of the late Heber and Mary A. Hartenstine and lived in Wilmington for the past 28 years where he worked as a textile worker.
  Among the survivors are a brother Howard, 839 South street, Pottstown, and a half-brother, Frank Comstock, of Glen Moore.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Three Men Buried in a Mine
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Three Men Buried In a Mine
 
CAVE IN AT THE IRON MINE AT FALLS OF FRENCH CREEK -- ONE MAN KILLED
 
  The iron mine at Falls of French Creek, Warwick township, Chester County, operated by E. & G. Brooke, of Birdsboro, this county, was the scene of an accident on Monday, the 15th inst., which resulted in the death of one man, and the slight injury of two others.  On the afternoon of that day, while Eber Hartenstine and two fellow miners were at work at the bottom of the shaft, by some unknown means about twenty tons of ore, rocks and earth were precipitated from the other side of the mine, burying in the debris the three men.  Several hours were spent in rescuing them, and when they were discovered, it was found that they all had sustained severe internal injuries, though those of Mr. Hartenstine were the most serious.  The last named gentleman was carried to his home at Pine Swamp, Warwick township, where he lingered in great agony until Tuesday evening when he died.  The other two whose names have not been learned, have nearly recovered from the effects of the accident.
  Eber Hartenstine, the victim of the accident, was about 35 years of age and leaves a wife and several children.  He was a brother of Mr. Jacob Hartenstine, of Pottstown.

LOSES HIS LIFE BY DROWNING
TRAGIC END OF A READING AVIATOR
 
Herbert Hartenstein, of this city, a quartermaster in the naval air service of the United States government, met death in a most tragic manner on Monday, when the seaplane in which he, with others, was making a practice flight over the bay at Chatham, Mass., enveloped in a tailspin and fell.  Hartenstein and Lieut. Charles L Ostridge of Watertown, Mass., were drowned, while a third member of the crew.  Everett P. Welsh, was rescued by another seaplane.
  This information was received by his wife, Mrs. Laura Hartenstein, 1017 Oley street, by telegraph.  The message follows:  "Chatham, Mass., May 19.  While making a practice flight over the bay here at 11 a.m. Monday, a naval seaplane in which Quartermaster Herbert Hartenstein was an occupant enveloped into a tailspin and fell, causing the death of Quartermaster Hartenstein."
  Another telegram followed, which informed the widow that members of the coast guard made unsuccessful efforts to resuscitate the Reading man, who was the first recovered.  The body of Lieut. Ostridge, of Watertown, Mass., who was drowned in the same accident, is still lost at sea.
Sorrow Follows Happiness
  The telegram informing Mrs. Hartenstein of the death of her husband arrived at their modest little home shortly after the wife had finished reading a letter of happiness received from her husband.  Hartenstein, in the letter, stated that he expected his discharge from the air service early in July and that he was going to return to Reading.  The wife is heartbroken and said:  "I gave all I had."  As her three-year-old son clung to her apron the stricken wife, wrought up over the news, explained through sobs how her husband met his death.
  On Dec. 31, 1917, Hartenstein enlisted in the Naval Reserve Corpse at Philadelphia.  After receiving his preliminary training at a station there, he was transferred to Pensacola, Fla., where he remained until February, 1918.  In the early part of March, he was assigned to a naval air service unit and embarked for France.  He saw active service in foreign waters and was later attached to a patrol crew which moved between Brest and Bordeaux.
Following the signing of the armistice he, with his unit, left France for the States, arriving here Nov. 24, 1918.  He spent Thanksgiving Day visiting his wife and little son in Reading.  Upon his return to duty, he was reassigned to a patrol crew along Pelham Bay, N.Y.  In March he was removed to Chatham, Mass., where he was stationed for patrol duty.
  The visit to his relatives in this city on Thanksgiving Day was a surprise.  None had heard of his safe arrival from overseas and when he entered his home on Oley street, his wife and parents were for a time speechless.
  Blue Star Changed to Gold.
  Upon the front door at the Oley street home, hangs a good size silk service flag bearing one blue star in the field of white.  "That star will be replace by a gold one, " she said, "and will hang on that door form some time to come.  He never cared for the display, but it was the only way in which we could demonstrate our admiration for his bravery and patriotism."
Quartermaster Hartenstein was 24 years old.  He was the son of Mrs. Thomas F. Torpey (nee Miller) and the late Jacob Hartenstein.  He was born at St. Peter's, Chester county.  His father died when he was very young.  Hartenstein received his education at Girard College, Philadelphia, and came to Reading at the age of 16 years.  He was a plumber and Steam fitter in the employ of I.D. Mohn & Co., while in this city.
  Deceased was a member of St. Peter's Methodist Church.  Camp 678, POS [unreadable].

AVIATOR's BODY ARRIVES
 
The body of Quartermaster Herbert Hartenstein, of this city, connected with the naval service of the United States government, who met death in a most tragic manner on Monday, when the seaplane in which he, with others, was making a practice flight over the bay at Chatham, Mass, enveloped in a tailspin and fell, arrived in Reading, via the Reading Railway.  The remains left the naval academy at Chatham, Mass., at 5 p.m. Tuesday.  Undertaker Auman, who has charge of the funeral arrangements, met the body and removed it to the deceased's home at 1017 Oley street, from which place the funeral will likely take place.  No date has been set for the funeral, although it is expected to take place Friday or Saturday.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: A Reading Man Believed to Have Drowned
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
A READING MAN BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN DROWNED
 
Chatham, Mass.  May 19 -- Lieut. Charles L. Ostridge, of Reading, Pa., and Quartermaster Herbert Hartenstein, of Watertown, were believed to have lost their lives when a naval seaplane fell into the ocean off Orleans today.  Members of the Orleans coast guard crew and others who went out from the air station here, could be seen through classes several hours after the accident, apparently working over the men with a pulmotor, and officials still entertained hope that they might be alive.  Ensign Everett P. Welsh, a third member of the seaplane crew, was rescued by another machine and brought to the station hospital in a serious condition.
  The men were making a practice flight, and observers said that the machine apparently went into a tail spin.

HARTENSTINE -- In Pottstown on October 28, Howard W., husband of the late Katharine R. (Renninger) Hartenstine, aged 75 years, 3 months and 16 days.  Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend funeral services Friday, Oct 31, at 2:30 P.M., in the Wolfendale funeral home, 466 North Franklin street.  Interment in Edgewood Cemetery.  Friends may call Thursday evening from 7 to 8:30 o'clock.

A resident of Pottstown for the past 65 years, HOWARD W. HARTENSTINE, 75, died early yesterday morning in his home, 839 SOUTH STREET.
  Born in Pine Swamp, Mr Hartenstine, a son of the late Hebert and Mary Ann (Seivard) Hartenstine, was an iron worker by trade.  He was the husband of the late Katharine R. (Renninger) Hartenstine.  He was of Methodist faith.
  Surviving him are the following children:  Mrs. Mamie A Francis and Elsie M., wife of Linwood Hadley, Los Angeles, Calif.; Charles J., East Orange, N.J., and Nellie R., wife of Harry Stubby, Philadelphia.
  Three brothers, David, Devon; Daunt Pine Swamp, and Abraham, Broomall, also survive him, as well as four grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be conducted Friday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock in a funeral home at 466 North Franklin street.  Burial will take place in Edgewood cemetery.

Jacob B. Hartenstine
 
Jacob B. Hartenstine died on Saturday at the residence of this granddaughter, Mr. Earle Herpst, 228 Price street, aged 75 years, 4 months and 22 days.  Death was caused by complications which developed 10 years ago when he was struck by a trolley car.  Since that time he was unable to do any work.  He was a puddler for years for the Pottstown Iron Co. And later was in the brick making business with L.B. Reifsnyder.  One daughter, Mrs. Edgar Ludwig, of this borough, survives.  He was a member of Searles Memorial M.E. Church.  The funeral will be held from the funeral parlors of Harvey C. Wilson on Wednesday afternoon at 1 o'clock.

Jacob B. Hartenstine, who is engaged in the brick business on South st., and wife, celebrated the 25th anniversary of their marriage by entertaining a large number of friends at their residence, No. 407 Walnut st.  The evening was spent in a pleasant manner, and a fine supper added to its enjoyment.  Griessenger's band discoursed choice music.  Mr. Hartenstine, just 25 years ago, was married to Miss Eliza Nicolls, of Uwchland, Chester County, by the late Rev. Jesse B. Knipe, of that locality.  They shortly afterwards moved to this borough and resided here ever since.  Mr. Hartenstine is a widely known and representative citizen and a consistent member of the First M. E. Church.

THE LATE JACOB S. HARTENSTINE.
 
Jacob S. Hartenstine, 788 Lincoln avenue, who died of typhoid fever, is survived by a widow and four young children:  Mary, Herbert, Laura and Clarence.  He was a son of the late Heber Hartenstine, who was killed by accident in the iron ore mines at Falls of French Creek.  A brother of deceased, Howard W. Hartenstine, resides in Pottstown.  Deceased was a member of Saratoga Tribe of Red Men, and of the Foresters of America.  Funeral on Tuesday next at 8:30 and interment at Pine Swamp cemetery, Warwick township, Chester county.

FUNERAL OF JACOB S. HARTENSTINE
 
  The funeral of J. S. Hartenstine took place from his late residence, 788 Lincoln Ave.  Brief services were held at the house by Rev. W. H. Ford, pastor of the First M. E. Church after which the cortege moved to the burial ground connected with the Pine Swamp United Evangelical Church, in Warwick township, Chester county.  Funeral Director Gilbert had charge.

JONATHAN C. HARTENSTINE,
 
70, husband of Elma (Smith) Hartenstine, died at his home in LINE LEXINGTON, Bucks county, yesterday morning at 1:30 o'clock following an illness of one week.  He was bedfast one day.
  Born in Pine Swamp, son of the late Heber and Mary Seivard Hartenstine, he lived in West Chester and Coatesville, and late resided for five years at North Wales until two months ago.  He was a farmer by occupation.
  Surviving besides his wife are a son, Thomas A. Line Lexington; a son, Lawrence L, Whitford; a foster son, Merrill Bones; two brothers, David, Valley Forge, and Abraham, Broomall;  a half-brother, Frank Comstock, Glen Moore RD, and one grandchild.
  Funeral services will be conducted in a Parkerford memorial home Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock, with interment in St. Andrew's cemetery, Ludwig's Corner.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription: HARTENSTINE -- On Tuesday, April 13, 1948.  Jonathan C. Hartenstine, husband of Elma (Smith) Hartenstine, aged 70 years.  Relatives and friends are invited to services at the White Memorial home, Parkerford, on Friday at 2 p.m.  Interment St. Andrews cemetery, Ludwig's Corner.  Friends will be received at the memorial home Thursday evening 7 to 9.

Mrs. H. W. Hartenstine
 
  Pottstown.  Dec. 14 -- Katharine R. (Renninger), wife of Howard W. Hartenstine, 839 South street, this borough, died yesterday, aged 75 years.  She was a native of Bechtelsville, a daughter of the late David and Mary (Fronheiser) Renninger.  She was a member of the Lutheran denomination of Hill Church.
  Surviving are her husband, four children, Mrs. Mary A Francis, Los Angeles, Cal.; Charles J Hartenstine, East Orange, N.J.; Nellie R. Hartenstine, Philadelphia; Elsie M., wife of L.J. Hadley, Los Angeles; four grand-children, a sister, Mrs. Annie Miller, Reading, and a brother, Harrison Miller, Bechtelsville.
  Funeral Thursday at 11 a.m. from the home.  Interment in Edgewood Cemetery.  Funeral director William E. Wolfendale, this borough, has charge.

Mrs. John W. Peplau
 
  Services for Mrs. Laura E. Hartenstine Peplau, who died Sunday night in her residence at 1246 Church St., will be held Friday at 1:30 p.m.
  The Rev. Paul J Hoh will officiate in the Cramp Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in Charles Evans Cemetery.
  The wife of John W Peplau, she was born in Reading a daughter of the late John and Mary (Yoh) Yohn.
  Employed by Luden's Inc., before retiring in 1956, she was a member of St. John's Lutheran Church, and its Ladies Aid Society.
  In addition to her husband, she is survived by a son, Clarence L. Hartenstine, Reading; six grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

HARTENSTINE -- On Thursday, November 19, 1973, Alma (Smith) Hartenstine, wife of the late Jonathan C. Hartenstine, R.D. #1, Pennsburg, Pa. age 82 years.  Relatives & friends are invited to attend the services from the White Memorial Home, Parkerford, Pa. On Tuesday December 4 at 1 a.m.  Interment in St. Andrew's Episcopal Cemetery, Ludwig's Corner.  Friends may call at the funeral home on Monday evening from 7 to 8:30 p.m.

Alma Hartenstine Dies at Age 82
 
  M. Alma (Smith) Hartenstine, 82, widow of Jonathan C. Hartenstine, Pennsburg RD 1, died Thursday morning in Grand View Hospital, Sellersville.  Her sister, Mrs. Deborah E. (Smith) Loomis, Glen Moore, died Wednesday.
  A patient since Nov. 9, she was ill three years.
  Born in East Nantmeal Township, she was a daughter of the late Allen T. And Lizzie (Miller) Smith.
  She lived in Pennsburg 10 years and previously lived in Line Lexington.
  She was a graduate of the former Union High School, East Nantmeal, and West Chester State Teacher's College.  She taught in the East Nantmeal Township schools.
  She attended St. Peter's Lutheran Church, North Wales.
  Surviving are two sons, Thomas A., with whom she lived; Lawrence, Frazier; a foster son, J. Merle Bones, West Point; eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.
  Funeral services will be 11 a.m. Tuesday from White Memorial Home, Parker Ford.
  Interment will be in St. Andrew's Episcopal Cemetery, Ludwig's Corner.
  A viewing will be 7 to 8:30 p.m. Monday at the funeral home.

COMESTOCK -- In Wilmington, on the 28th inst., MARY A., widow of Frank Comestock, aged 89 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of her son, Harry Hartenstine, 58 Rockford Road, Wilmington, Del., Saturday evening.  Services Sunday at 2 p.m. In the Evangelical Church, at Pine Swamp, Chester county.  Interment in adjoining cemetery.

MRS. MARY A. COMSTOCK
 
  Pottstown, Jan. 29 (Special).  -- Mary A., widow of Frank Comestock, died Thursday at the home of her son, Harry Hartenstine, 58 Rockford Road.  Wilmington, Del., aged 89 years.  Her first husband, Heber Hartenstine, and second husband, Frank Comestock, both preceded her in death.  There survive these children:  Harry Hartenstine, with whom she resided in Wilmington; Howard Hartenstine, this place; Abraham Hartenstine, Broomall, Delaware county; David Hartenstine, Valley Forge; Jonathan Hartenstine, Downingtown, and Frank Comestock, Glen Moore.
  Funeral services Saturday evening at the home of her son in Wilmington.  Further services Sunday, at 2 p.m. In the Evangelical Church, at Pine Swamp, Chester county.  Interment in the adjoining cemetery.  In charge of Funeral Director U.G. Mauger, of Warwick.

MRS. MARY A. COMSTOCK
 
  Pottstown, Jan 29 (Special) -- Mary A., widow of Frank Comestock, died Thursday at the home of her son, Harry Hartenstine, 58 Rockford Road, Wilmington, Del., aged 89 years.  Her first husband, Heber Hartenstine, and second husband, Frank Comestock, both preceded her in death.  There survive these children: Harry Hartenstine, with whom she resided in Wilmington; Howard Hartenstine, this place; Abraham Hartenstine, Broomall, Delaware County;  David Hartenstine, Valley Forge; Jonathan Hartenstine, Downingtown, and Frank Comestock, Glen Moore.
  Funeral services Saturday evening, at the home of her son in Wilmington.  Further services Sunday at 2 p.m. In the Evangelical Church at Pine Swamp, Chester county.  Interment in the adjoining cemetery, in charge of Funeral Director U.G. Mauger of Warwick.

Elizabeth Hottenstein
died of gangrene of the foot, at the Country Home, aged 80 years.  She was a native of Douglassville and was admitted to the institution in 1903.  She was never married.  No relatives are known to survive.  Jos. Kelso will take the remains in charge.  Undertaker Mauger removed the body and interment will be made in Pine Swamp Cemetery.

Mrs. John W. Peplau
 
  Services for Mrs. Laura E. Hartenstine Peplau, who died Sunday night in her residence at 1246 Church St., will be held Friday at 1:30 p.m.
  The Rev. Paul J Hoh will officiate in the Cramp Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in Charles Evans Cemetery.
  The wife of John W Peplau, she was born in Reading a daughter of the late John and Mary (Yoh) Yohn.
  Employed by Luden's Inc., before retiring in 1956, she was a member of St. John's Lutheran Church, and its Ladies Aid Society.
  In addition to her husband, she is survived by a son, Clarence L. Hartenstine, Reading; six grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

TORPEY -- On the 20th inst., IDA (nee Miller) TORPEY, aged 80 years.
  Services from Theo. C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlors.  247 Penn St., Tuesday, 1 p.m.  Interment in Pine Swamp Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. Ida Torpey
 
  Mrs. Ida (Miller) Torpey, 80, widow of Thomas Torpey, of 1017 Oley St., died this morning in the Reading Hospital.  She was the daughter of the late James V. And Mary Ann (Mock) Miller and was a member of St. Peter's Methodist Church.
  Surviving are three children: Clarence H. Hartenstine, a son by a previous marriage, of Brentwood, Md.; Mary, wife of Walter A. Ringler, postmaster of Reading, and Laura T., widow of Ithamar B. Rettgers, of Reading; five grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren; one brother, Morris Miller  of St. Mary's Pa., and one sister, Mrs. Joseph Loomis, of Spring City.
  Funeral services will be conducted in the T.C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlors on Tuesday afternoon at 1 o'clock.  The Rev. Thomas R. Jeffrey will officiate.  Burial will be made in Pine Swamp Cemetery.

G. F. HARTLEY
 
(Telegraph's Georgia News Service)
  ALAMO, Nov. 3 -- Funeral services will be held for G. F. Hartley, 67, at the Baptist church here Friday afternoon at two o'clock.  Mr. Hartley developed pneumonia Saturday and he died at an early hour Thursday morning.  Mr. Hartley is a member of a very large family in which there were 12 children, only two of whom have died, the rest of the children with the exception of the girlds all reside in and near Alamo.  The family was all reared in Washington county and came here about 30 years ago.
  Funeral services will be conducted by L.D. Strickland, the regular pastor of the Baptist church, assisted by the Rev. Lum Morrison, pastor of the Methodist church, and interment will be in the Alamo Cemetery.
  Mr. Hartley is survived by his widow and six children, Lawson Hartley, Marvin Hartley, Julian Hartley and Mrs. Allene Stone, all residing at Louisville, Ga.; M. C. Hartley, Alamo, Ga. And Mrs. Alma Gillis, Lakeland, Fla.  Seven brothers and three sisters survive the deceased, W. G., B. H., T. N., R. A., J. M., E. S., and C. C. All Alamo, Ga.  Mrs. Willie Womack, Harrison, Ga. Mrs. J. A. Wilson Wadley, Ga., and Mrs. J. H. Cantrell, Atlanta, Ga.

HARTMAN -- In Ontelanunee, on the 10th inst., AMANDA R. Wife of Frederick S. Hartman, aged 70 years, 1 month, and 12 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, Ontelaunee, on Monday at 9:30 o'clock at the house.  Services and interment at Alsace Church.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Don't know who her brother John is?
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Mrs. Frederick Hartman
 
Mrs. Amanda Hartman (nee Hoch), aged 67 years, wife of Frederick Hartman, died suddenly this morning, at her home in Tuckerton.  Deceased had been seriously ailing only since Monday morning.  The immediate cause of death was due to heart trouble.
  Mrs. Hartman was a lifelong resident of Tuckerton and was a member of Alsace Lutheran Church.  Besides her husband, she is survived by four daughters: Emma and Bertha, at home; Sallie, wife of Charles Krick, Brooklyn, and Mary, of Pottsville;  two brothers, John of Tuckerton, and William, and one sister, Mary, of Reading.

Frederick S. Hartman
 
  Frederick S. Hartman, a well known retired farmer, died of influenza and grip, at 8:30 a.m., today, at his residence, in Ontelaunee, aged 85 years, 11 months and 14 days.  Deceased was ailing three weeks and was bedfast that length of time.  He was a member of Alsace Lutheran Church.  His wife, Amanda R., died eight years ago.  These children survive:  Mary A., wife of John A. Bechtel, Allentown; Sallie, wife of Charles S. Krick, Merion, Pa.; John H., Philadelphia; Bertha S., wife of Wilson K. Madeira, Ontelaunee, and Emma M., wife of Rev. William S. Dry, Stouchsburg; also 16 grandchildren.  Deceased was the last of his family.  Rev. C.E. Kistler will be in charge of the services, which will be held next Saturday, at 9:30 a.m.  Undertaker Seidel has charge.

HARTMAN -- In Ontelaunee Township, on the 21st inst., FREDERICK S. HARTMAN, aged 85 years, 11 months, and 4 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, Ontelaunee Station, Saturday morning at 9:30 o'clock at the house.  Brief services at the house.  Further services in the Alsace Lutheran Church.  Interment in Alsace cemetery.  Kindly omit flowers.

Frederick S. Hartman
 
  The funeral of Frederick S. Hartman was held from his residence at Ontelaunee Station.  Brief services were held at the house, after which the cortege proceeded to Alsace Lutheran Church, where further services were held and interment made in the adjoining cemetery.  Rev. C. E. Kistler officiated.  The remains were attired in a black suit and rested in a square-cornered quartered oak casket, with silver extension handles, silver trimmings and plate with name and age inscribed.  Undertaker Seidel had charge.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Truck Hits Upset Auto; Woman Killed
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Truck Hits Upset Auto; Woman Killed
 
  One person was killed and two escaped injury at 4 o'clock Friday morning when an overturned automobile was struck and completely demolished by a tractor-trailer on the Gettysburg-Harrisburg Pike about four miles south of Dillsburg.
  Killed instantly was Mrs. Nellie Heckard, 44, of Harrisburg, who died from a broken neck, fractured skull, crushed chest, broken right arm and two broken legs.
 
Drivers Unhurt
 
  Escaping serious injury were Mrs. Heckard's husband, William A., 36, operator of the automobile, and Charles Lau, 27 of Palmyra, driver of the tractor trailer.
  Coroner E.A. Huegele, who conducted an investigation along with State Police, reported that Heckard's car, which was traveling south, swerved to right, went over an embankment, and swerved back into the middle of the highway where it came to a stop upside down.  Heckard, who was dazed when the car rolled over, was attempting to extricate his wife, when the huge tractor-trailer came over the brow of the hill.  Lau told State Police he was unable to stop before striking the Heckard automobile.  Mrs. Heckard's body was carried 200 feet in the demolished automobile.  Coroner Huegele said.  The Heckards were en route to Dillsburg R.D. 1 to visit Mrs. Heckard's son, Curtis T. Cornell.
 
Auto Demolished
 
  The tractor-trailer was owned by Ernest R. Nelson, of Palmyra.  There was little damage to the truck buy Coroner Huegele reported the entire front of the automobile was sheared off by the impact.
  The Mechanicsburg ambulance took Heckard to the Seidle Memorial Hospital in Mechanicsburg, where he was treated for minor lacerations.  Lau escaped without a scratch.  Heckard was unable to give a reason for his car going out of control and leaving the highway.
  Pending an inquest at a later date, both Heckard and Lau were released in $1,000 bond for their appearances.

Heckard Blamed In Wife's Death
 
  William A. Heckard, 36, of Mt. Holly Springs, was held guilty of "some negligence" in the death of his wife who, a coroner's jury decided was killed when the Heckard car overturned and not when a truck crashed into the wreckage a short time later.
  The jury exonerated the truck driver, Charles E. Lau, 27, of Palmyra, of all blame in the woman's death.
  The accident occurred September 10 in the Williams Grove road near Rose Garden.  Dr. Edward A Haegele, Cumberland county coroner, directed in the inquest.  He said Heckard's car containing his 44-year-old wife, Mrs. Nellie Heckard, turned over.  Mrs. Heckard was pinned in the wreckage.  While Heckard and a passing truck driver were trying to extricate her, another truck, driven by Lau, crashed into the wrecked car.  Mrs. Heckard was dead when a physician arrived.

Sees Wife Killed By Truck While Pinned in Car
 
  Mechanicsburg, Pa., Sept. 10 -- William A Heckard, of Harrisburg today watched helplessly as a tractor-trailer plunged into the automobile wreckage where his way lay pinned.  State Police said Mrs. Nellie Heckard, 44, probably died instantly.
  Heckard told police he may have fallen asleep early today while he and his wife were driving to a son's home in nearby Dillsburg, Pa.
  Police said Heckard's car left Route 15 four miles south of Dillsburg, climbed a bank and then turned over on its side in the middle of the highway.
  Heckard dazed by the crash, fought to get his wife free of the wreckage.  He barely escaped before the truck hit the overturned automobile where his wife lay.
  The truck driver, Charles Lau, 27, Palmyra, Pa., escaped serious injury.

William A. Heckard
 
  MARYSVILLE -- William A. Heckard, 71, of 310 Cameron St. Died Sunday in Holy Spirit Hospital, Camp Hill.
  He was a retired conductor for Conrail, and an Army veteran of World War II.  He was a member of the Marysville Fire Company, Moose Lodge 821, Hunters Valley Sportsman Club, Liverpool, and a life member of VFW post 255, Duncannon and Liverpool American Legion Post.
  Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Mary E Heckard; two brothers, John P. Of Enola, and George of Liverpool, and several nieces and nephews.
  Services will be held Wednesday at 1 p.m. In the funeral home at 212 Maple Ave. with the Rev. Donald E. VanKirk, pastor of Bethany United Methodist Church, officiating.  Burial and graveside military services will be in Blue Ridge Memorial Gardens, Lower Paxton Twp.
  Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday from 7 to 9 p.m.

Verheiratet -- durch den Ehrw. Hrn. Pauli, Sonntags den 12ten intstehenden November, Hr. Peter Herbein, von Oley, mit Miss Susanna Vanreid, von Cumru.
 
Married - by the Venerable Mr. Pauli, Sunday the 12th November, Mr. Peter Herbein, from Oley, with Miss Susanna Van Reed, from Cumru.

HIGH -- In Cumru township, on the 21st inst, Esther High, widow of the late Daniel V.R. High, aged 60 years.
  The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, in Cumru twp., on Tuesday, May 28th, at 9 1/2 o'clock in the morning.  Services at the house.  Interment in Yocum's Church.

DEATH OF EZRA HIGH
 
  Ezra High, the well-known farmer of Poplar Neck, died this morning at 1:55 of diabetes and blood poisoning.  For the past month, he was confined to bed.  Mr. High was born on the High homestead, Aug 15, 1816.  He leaves a widow and the following children: Wm. P. High, of Shillington; Mrs. Wm A Schall, of Barto; Mrs. Jonas DeTurk, of Neversink, and Miss Sarah High, of Poplar Neck.  Mrs. H.E. Lewis, or Reading, another child, died 2 years ago, and Emma died 15 years ago.
  Deceased is also survived by a sister, Mrs. Rebecca Fry, of Lancaster.  He was a member of the First Reformed Church of this city, and at one time was a director of the Schuylkill Valley Bank. He was the son of Wm. And Catharine (nee Van Reed) High and was engaged in farming all his life.  Mr. High travelled extensively in the west and was a close observer.  He was well-read and his judgment was sound and reliable.  He enjoyed a large acquaintance and had the respect, esteem and the friendship of a large circle of friends, who honored him for his integrity, honesty and high Christian character.  His age was 80 years, 7 months and 23 days.  Deceased was ailing the past 10 weeks ad was bedfast the entire length of time.  During his illness he was a great sufferer, but remained conscious to the last.  He leaves a large estate.
  Funeral next Tuesday.  Services at the house.  Interment in the family burial ground on the High farm where his father and grandfather are buried.

HIGH -- At Poplar Neck on the 8th inst., EZRA HIGH, aged 80 years, 7 months and 23 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further notice, from his late residence on Wednesday morning at 10:30 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment at family burying ground.

Ezra High's Farm
  One of the largest landholders in Berks county is Ezra High, of Cumru township.  He has three farms lying right above the Poplar Neck bridge.  They are all in good order.  On the lower one is to be found a great variety of fruit trees, grapes, [â€¦].   This fruit Mr High has planted during the last ten years, as well as having build the house and barn.  Mr. High and his wife are away from home, spending some time in middle Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Ezra High
 
  Hannah (nee Gernant), widow of Ezra High, of Poplar Neck, died this morning of heart failure, aged nearly 89 yearas.  She is survived by the following children:  Kate, wife of Jonas DeTurk, of Neversink; William P. High of Shillington; Mary, wife of William A. Schall, of Oakbrook; and Miss Sarah High, at home.  Deceased was born and reared in Cumru, where she lived all her life.  She was the last of the Gernant family.  She belonged to the First Reformed Church, Reading.  She will be buried on the family plot, on the old homestead.

HIGH -- At Poplar Neck, on the 15th inst., HANNAH, widow of Ezra High, aged 88 years, 11 months, and 17 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from her late residence, Poplar Neck, on Thursday at 10:30 o'clock.  Services at house.  Interment at Family Burial Ground.

Lydia High.
 
  Lydia N., widow of William R. High aged 85, died about 6:15 a.m. Friday at her home, 439 Woodward street, as the result of infirmities.  She had been bedfast for only one day, but had been feeble for some time.
  She was born at Sinking Spring, but came to this city 23 years ago.  Her parents were the late Daniel and Susan (nee Boone) Krick.  She was a member of Yocum's Reformed church.
  Her husband, the late William R. High, who died Aug 10, 1908, had formerly been a coal dealer.  After his death the business was taken over by his son, Charles P. High.
  Those who survive her are four sons, Daniel K., 809 North 5th street; William F., Muhlenberg township; Henry K., Angelica, and Charles P., at home; 9 grandchildren and 8 great-grandchildren.

HIGH -- In this city, on the 16th inst., Lydia A., widow of the late Wm. R. High, aged 85 years, 1 month and 19 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 459 Woodward St., Monday at 2 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Yocums's Cemetery.

HIGH -- Entered into rest in this city, on the 11th inst, MARY M, daughter of the late Daniel and Esther (nee Rothermel) High, aged 74 years, 1 month and 10 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from the residence of her nephew, R. Monroe Hoffman, 37 South 3d street, on Thursday morning at 11 o'clock.  Services at the house, interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Please omit flowers.

Miss Mary M. High
 
  Miss Mary M. High, aged 74 years, died from kidney troubles this morning at the home of her niece, Mrs. R Monroe Hoffman, 37 South Third street, with whom she resided.  Deceased was ailing for a year, but was only bedfast one week.
  Deceased was a native of Cumru Township, but was practically a lifelong resident of Reading.  She was the daughter of Daniel and Esther (nee Rothermel) High, both deceased.  She was a devout member of the First Reformed Church.  Miss High is survived by one sister, Mrs. Frederick Bechtel, Brookside.

Verheiratet -- am leztern Sontag per acht Tagen, Herr Wilhelm Hoch, von Alsass, mit der liebensmurdigen Miss Catharina Vanread, von Cumru.
 
Married on the last Sunday per eight days, Mr. Wilhelm Hoch, of Alsace, with the lovely Miss Catharina Van Reed, of Cumru.

HIGH -- In this city, on the 14th inst., WILLIAM R HIGH, aged 73 years and 5 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 439 Woodward street, on Tuesday at 9:30 o'clock at the house.  Services and interment at Yocom's Church.  Please omit flowers.

DEATH OF WELL-KNOWN READING BUSINESS MAN
 
William K. High Passes Away Four Days After His 73d Birthday--Came to Reading 30 Years Ago.
 
  A well-known retired farmer and local coal, flour and feed merchant, William R High, died of a complication of diseases superinduced by liver trouble at 7:30 o'clock this morning at his home, 439 Woodward street just four days after his 73d birthday anniversary.  He had been ailing for the past few years.  About four weeks ago he recovered from a severe attack of illness and was able to be about.  On Monday he took to his bed again and sank gradually until death came.
  Mr. High was born and reared on the High homestead in Cumru township, and at the time of his death he was the owner of the place where he spent his boyhood days.  Thirty years ago he retired from the farm and moved to this city.  He engaged in the coal, flour and feed businesses at 312 Rose street.  He associated with him first his eldest son, Daniel K High, and later another son, Charles P High, who has conducted the business for the past five years, his father retiring from active pursuits in 1903.
  Mr. High was an active and life member of the Berks County Agricultural Society.  For a period of 30 years deceased was a Director in the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Berks county, and for many years was its Treasurer.  Mr. High at the time of his death, was Treasurer of Yocum's Union Church, a position he held for four decades.  He was a devoted member of the Reformed denomination of that church.
  Besides his widow, Lydia Ann (nee Krick), Mr. High is survived by five sons:  Daniel K. High, Robesonia; William R. And Charles P High, this city; Henry K. High, Ruscombmanor and Ezra K. High, Harrisburg; two sisters, Mrs. Fred Bechtel, Brookside, and Mary High, Reading, and nine grandchildren.

Entered into rest on Wednesday, February 23, 2005, Mrs. Bertha Smith  Hillman , wife of the late Mr. Ozzie Hillman .
 
She is survived by many nieces and nephews who loved her dearly.
 
Mrs. Hillman was born in Washington County, GA to the late James A. and Annie McNeely Smith. She retired from Graniteville Manufacturing Company and she was a member of Bath First Baptist Church and the Ruth's Sunday School Class.
 
Mrs. Hillman longed for everyone to have a personal relationship with Jesus Christ, so that she might meet them in Heaven one day.
 
Funeral services will be on Saturday at 1:00 p.m. in the Bath First Baptist Church with Rev. Herb Sons officiating. Mrs. Hillman will be placed in the church at noon on Saturday. Interment will follow in Hillcrest Memorial Park.
 
Pallbearers will be the Deacons of Bath First Baptist Church. Honorary pallbearers will be members of Ruth's Sunday School Class.
 
Memorials to: Bath First Baptist Church-Building Fund, P.O. Box 240, Bath, SC, 29816.
 
Friends may call at the residence of Elizabeth Smith, 130 Bryan Drive, Bath or on Friday from 6 to 8 p.m. at Hatcher Funeral Home, U.S. Hwy. No. 1, Langley, SC.

Funeral services for Mrs. Bertha Smith  Hillman , wife of the late Mr. Ozzie Hillman , will be on Saturday at 1:00 p.m. in the Bath First Baptist Church. Mrs. Hillman will be placed in the church on Saturday at noon. Interment will follow in Hillcrest Memorial Park.
 
Friends may call at the residence of Elizabeth Smith, 130 Bryan Drive, Bath or on Friday from 6 to 8 p.m. at Hatcher Funeral Home, U.S. Hwy. No. 1, Langley, SC.

Funeral services for Mrs. Bertha Smith  Hillman will be today at 1:00 p.m. in the Bath First Baptist Church. Interment will follow in Hillcrest Memorial Park.
 
Hatcher Funeral Home, U.S. Hwy. No. 1, Langley, SC.

Ozzie L. Hillman
 
  Ozzie L. Hillman of 3491 Norfolk Drive died Tuesday in an Augusta hospital.
  The funeral will be held at 3 p.m. Thursday at the Elliott Sons Funeral Home chapel, Lumpkin Road, with the Rev. James Rodgers officiating.  Burial will be in the Hillcrest Memorial Park.
  Mr. Hillman was a native of Warren County, Ga., but had lived in Augusta for 35 years.  He was a member of the [?] Gospel Church.
  Survivors include his wife, Mrs Bertha Smith Hillman; one brother, D.S. Hillman, Stapleton, Ga.; and two sisters, Mrs. Agnes Hobbs and Mrs. Jessie Phillips, Stapleton.

MRS. MARY ANN HINSON
 
  Lynchburg, Jan 12. -- Special:  Mrs. Mary Ann Hinson, eighty-two, died at her home here Wednesday night after an illness of several months.  Funeral services were held from her home Thursday afternoon at 3 o'clock by the Rev G.L. Ingram of the Methodist Church.  Interment followed in the Presbyterian cemetery.  
  Pallbearers were F.A. Cribbs, T.J. Truluck, Rufus Lane, W.S. Dukes and Marion Stuart.
  Mrs. Hinson was a lifelong resident of this place the wife of the late W.H. Hinson, and at the time of her death there were five generations in her family.  She is survived by three sons, G.N. Hinson, Delco, N.C.; G.S. Hinson, Lynchburg; W.R. Hinson, Leland, N.C.; twenty-six grandchildren, forty-four great grandchildren, and four great-great grandchildren.

W.H. HINSON DIES
Confederate Veteran Crosses River
 
Special to the State.
  Lynchburg, Feb 16 -- William H Hinson, 85, Confederate War Veteran, died at his home here Wednesday afternoon, after an illness of several months.
  He was a well known and highly esteemed citizen.  Besides his widow, Mrs. Mary Broach Hinson, he is survived by a daughter, Mrs. B.W. Thigpen of Lynchburg; three sons, Giles S. Hinson, Lynchburg; W. Robert Hinson, Wilmington, N.C.; George N Hinson, Delco, N.C.; a score of grandchildren, great grandchildren and great-great grandchildren.  
  Funeral services were held at the Presbyterian Church Thursday.

James [John] Holland
 
  At the age of 58 years, James [John] Holland died Sunday on the Thomas J. White farm, formerly the Caleb Cope property in East Bradford.  He leaves a son and two daughters living near the Eagle.

Funerals
 
  The body of John M. Holland was buried yesterday in the Lutheran Cemetery, Ardmore, services being conducted by the pastor.  Mr. Holland had died on the White farm in East Bradford.

HOLLAND, September 8 1908, MARTHA A HOLLAND, daughter of James V Miller, aged 47 years.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral on Saturday afternoon, September 12, at 1:30 o'clock from her late residence, West Point.  Services and interment at Bethel M.E. Church.  Take Norristown & Landsdale trolley to door.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: From the Florence South Carolina County Library
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
EZRA E. HUDSON CONFEDERATE VETERAN
 
Special to the State.
  Sardis, April 13.  Ezra E. Hudson, venerable Confederate veteran, and one of the most successful planters in the community, died at the home of his daughter, Mrs. W. H. McElveen, Sunday night at 11 o'clock after a lingering illness of about two years.
  He was 84 years of age.  Mr. Hudson was a consistent and devout member of Sardis Baptist church, being a senior deacon, serving for 52 years.
  He is survived by the following children:  Mrs. W. H. McElveen, Mrs. David Hill, Mrs. J. Mett Carter and J. C. Hudson, all of Sardis.  He is also survived by several grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren and two brothers, Jesse E. Hudson and E. T. Hudson of Sardis.
  Funeral services were held in Sardis church Monday afternoon at 4 o'clock by the Rev. B. K. Truluck.  The interment took place in Sardis cemetery in the presence of a large concourse of sorrowing relatives and friends.
  The floral offerings were many, varied and beautiful, which attested the esteem in which he was held.
  The pallbearers were six deacons of Sardis Baptist church as follows:  Willie J. McGee, Josh Langston, Irvin Langston, N. E. Hill, Furman Hill and James M. Benton.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: From the Florence County, South Carolina Library

Mrs. Rosana Hudson
 
Special to the State
  Timmonsville, Dec 12 -- Mrs. Rosana Hudson, the wife of Ezra E. Hudson of Sardis, died Saturday morning at 4 o'clock.  She had been in declining health for several years and for the past two or three weeks had been in bed.  She was 82 years of age.  Besides her husband, she is survived by the following children:  Mrs. W. H. McElveen, Mrs. J. M. Carter, Mrs. David R. Hill and Hampton and Jade Hudson.  She was a consistent member of the Sardis Baptist church and her remains were laid to rest in the Sardis cemetery on Saturday afternoon, the funeral services being conducted by her pastor, the Rev. B. K. Truluck.

JEFFRIES -- In this city, on the 16th inst., Catharine, wife of Edgar Jeffries, aged 75 years, 2 months and 2 days.
  Funeral from her late residence, 1023 Greenwich street, on Tuesday, at 2 p.m.  Interment private in Charles Evans cemetery.

MRS. EDGAR JEFFERIES
 
Mrs. Catharine Furlington Jefferies wife of Edgar Jefferies and daughter of the late John and Rachel Furlington of Philadelphia, died of heart failure and paralysis, at her residence, 1023 Greenwich street, Saturday morning, aged 75 years, 2 months and 2 days.  Mrs. Jefferies was a native of Philadelphia and lived in this city 48 years.  Two children remain -- Laura, of this city, and Mary, of Easton.  She was the last of her family.  Mrs. Jefferies was a member of Christ Episcopal Church.

EDGAR A. JEFFERIES
 
  Edgar A. Jefferies, 10133 Elm Street, died in bed, some time during Friday night, and the body was found by the daughter, Miss Mary Jefferies, when she went to his room to call him.  Mr. Jefferies was 84 years of age and was exceptionally active.  He had never been ill, with the exceution of slight colds.  Mr. Jefferies was both in Philadelphia.  He cam to this city 58 years ago.  He worked at the Jackson Rope Walk up to last Thanksgiving, when he retired.  His wife died seven years ago.  He leaves two daughters, Mary and Laura, both at home.  Deceased was a member of St. Paul United Evangelical Church.
  Coroner Strasser was notified and after an investigation, issued a certificate of death due to paralysis of the heart.

JEFFERIES -- on the 14th inst., Edgar A. Jefferies, aged 84 years, 4 months and 9 days.
  Funeral Wednesday at 2 p.m.

MISS LAURA JEFFRIES LAID TO REST TODAY
 
  The body of Miss Laura A. Jeffries was interred at the Steelstown cemetery this afternoon following services from the Rohland Funeral Parlor.  Rev. J. S. Harper, pastor of the Evangelical Congregational Church at Annville was in charge.
  Rohland's were in charge of the funeral arrangements.

JEFFRIES -- In Lebanon, on the 17th inst., Miss Laura A. Jeffries aged 78 years and 2 months.
Funeral on Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock from the Rohland Parlors, at Fifth and Cumberland Streets, Services at the parlors.  Interment at Steelstown Cemetery.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend without further notice, Friends may call on Monday evening, 7 to 9, at the parlors.

MISS LAURA JEFFERIES DIES HERE AT HOSPITAL
 
Miss Laura A. Jefferies, formerly of Reading, died Saturday morning at a local hospital.  She had been ill for two months.  Miss Jefferies, who was 78 years of age, was a member of St. Paul's Evangelical Congregational Church, Reading.  A number of nieces and nephews survive.

Mrs. Lizzie Mae Johnson
 
  SANDERSVILLE, Ga. -- Funeral services for Mrs. Lizzie Mae Johnson, 69, of Sandersville, who died Friday, after a short illness will be held at 3 p.m. Today from the First Church of the Nazarene, Sandersville, Ga. With the Rev. Emory Lindsey officiating.  Burial will be at Josey's Chapel Cemetery near Bartow, Ga.
  Mrs. Johnson was a member of the Ammie S. Page Baptist Church.  She was a native of Washington County.
  Survivors include four daughters, Mrs. Jeanete Davis, Augusta, Mrs. Ammie Price, Mrs. Udell Lindsey, Mrs Mary Alice Brantley, all of Sandersville; one son, James Johnson, Sandersville; two sisters, Mrs. Bertha Hillman, Mrs. Lorena Josey, both of Augusta;  four brothers, Russell Smith, Bath, S.C., Bennie Smith, Phenix City, Ala., Willie Smith, Jordan Smith, both of Augusta.  Lang's Chapel is in charge.

Mrs. Blanche Elizabeth Josey , 79, died Thursday, Jan. 11, 2001, at University Hospital, Augusta.  The funeral will be at 11 a.m. Sunday at Apostolic Church with the Revs. Vina Mae Josey and Don Proctor officiating. Burial will be in the church cemetery.  Mrs. Josey , a native of Washington County, was a homemaker and a member of Apostolic Church.   Survivors include four sons, Jerry E. Josey , Louisville, and Ronnie O. Josey , Wayne N. Josey and William E. Josey , all of Bartow; a daughter, June Elizabeth Simpson, Martinez; five brothers, Ben Smith, Jacksonville, Fla., Fred Smith and Newman Smith, both of Bartow, Herbert Smith, Grovetown, and Robert Smith, Allendale; three sisters, Lorena Ford, Tucker, Mabel Proctor, St. Simons Island, and Vina Mae Josey , Bartow; and 11 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.  Pallbearers will be her grandsons.  The family will receive friends from 7 to 9 p.m. today at Smith Funeral Home, Wadley.

Mr. Harris B. Josey , 86, died Sunday afternoon.  Funeral services will be held Wednesday afternoon at 2:00 p.m. from Freedom Fellowship Church.  The family will receive friends at Freedom Fellowship Church Tuesday evening between the hours of 6 to 8 p.m. and will be at their home in Bartow.  Arrangements are by Smith Funeral Home of Wadley.

HENRY L. JOSEY
(Telegraph's Georgia News Service)
 
WADLEY, Dec. 2 -- Funeral services for Henry Lewis Josey, 66, prominent planter of Washington County, were held at Old Bethel Baptist church, near Bartow, at 10 a.m. Saturday, the Rev. T.M. Callaway of Wadley officiating.  Burial was in the churchyard.
  Besides his widow, Mrs. Bell Smith Josey, he is survived by three sons, Zepho Josey, Ollis and Harris Josey, of Washington County; six daughters, Mrs. Stella Sineath, Mrs. Evie Lou Smith, Mrs. Ruth Smith, Mrs. Jewel Smith, Mrs O'Kellar Smith and Miss Louise Josey, all of Washington County.

Mrs. Lillie Josey
 
  Funeral services for Mrs. Lillie Belle Josey, 76, who died Friday in Clearwater, S.C. Will be conducted today at 3 p.m., at the New Bethel Baptist Church, Riddleville, Ga. By the Rev. A. W. Franklin, the Rev. Norman Farrell, and the Rev. H.G. Brantley.  Interment will be in the church cemetery.
  Pallbearers will be Windom Edgar, Paul Josey, Edwin Josey, Wilmer Josey, William Josey and Ernest Lee Josey, all grandsons of Mrs. Josey.
  She is survived by eight sons, Lewis Josey, Willis Josey and Marvin Josey, all of Riddleville;  Milo Josey, Henry Josey and Allen Josey, all of Kite, Ga., Homer Clay Josey of Savannah and Woodrow Josey of Bath, S.C.; two daughters, Mrs. R.E. Hatcher of Clearwater and Mrs. Willie Edgar of Winder, Ga.; three sisters, Mrs. Annie Hartley and Mrs. Ora Zittrauer, all of Savannah and Mrs. Nellie Pennington of Dexter, Ga.; one brother, Homer Jackson of Savannah; 40 grandchildren and 23 great grandchildren.
  Mrs. Josey was a native of Washington, Ga., and had resided at Kite, Ga.

JOSEY -- Entered into rest, May 13, 1955 at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. R. E. Hatcher of Clearwater, S. C., Mrs. Lillie Belle Josey of Kite, Ga.  Funeral services will be conducted from the New Bethel Baptist Church, Riddleville, Ga., May 15, 1955 at 3 p.m. With Rev. A.W. Franklin officiating, assisted by Rev. Norman Farrell and Rev. H. G. Brantley.  The body will remain at Posey's Funeral Home until 11 a.m., then lie in state at the Church until the hour of the service.  Interment will be in New Bethel cemetery.  Posey's Funeral Home, Langley, S.C.

Mrs. Lillie Belle Josey
 
  Mrs. Lillie Belle Josey, 76, a native of Kite, Ga., died Friday night at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. R. E. Hatcher, at Clearwater, S. C.
  Funeral services will be announced later by Posey's Funeral Home, Langley, S.C.

Louis E. Josey
 
  BARTOW, Ga. -- Louis Eugene Josey, 58, died unexpectedly at the residence near here Saturday morning.
  Funeral services will be held Sunday at 4 p.m. At New Bethel Baptist Church.  The Rev. A.W. Franklin will officiate assisted by the Rev. Milton Dwells.  Interment will follow in New Bethel Cemetery.
  Mr. Josey was a native of Washington County and had lived in Riddleville all his life.  He was a farmer.
  Survivors are his wife,  Mrs. Lorena Smith Josey; three daughters, Mrs. D.D. Hicks of Bath, S.C., Mrs. F.L. Melluried of Jersey City, N.J., and Mrs Ray Meadows of Augusta; three sons, Louis Edwin Josey of Macon, Ga., Berions Josey of Bartow, Hugh Forest Josey of Bartow; six brothers, James Mile Josey, Henry Lee Josey of Kite, Ga., Home Clay Josey of Savannah, Ga., Willis Evans Josey and Marvin Lawson Josey of Riddleville, and Woodrow W. Josey of Bath, S.C.; two sisters, Mrs. Robert Hatcher of Clearwater, S.C. And Mrs Willie Edgar of Winder, Ga.; nine grandchildren and several nieces and nephews.

Mrs. Marie Josey
Retired homemaker
 
  BARTOW, Ga. -- Mrs. Marie Beckworth Josey, 87, of 7709 Heard Bridge Road, died Saturday, Feb 24, 1996 at University Hospital, Augusta.
  The funeral will be at 3 p.m. Today at Josey Baptist Church with the Revs. Inman Gerrald and Bill Snipes officiating.  Burial will be in the church cemetery.
  Mrs. Josey, a native of Jewell, lived in Bartow about 70 years.  She was a homemaker and a member of Josey Baptist Church, where she taught Sunday School and served as church clerk.  She was former president of the Women's Missionary Union, and  a member of the Mount Vernon Association.
  Survivors include a daughter, Zulene Moats, Bartow; and five grandchildren, 16 great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren.
  Pallbearers will be Lester Moats, Brentley Moats, Eric Moats, Hollan Josey, Hank Josey, Taylor Ford, Brian Barfield and Wayne Barfield.
  Memorials may be made to Josey Baptist Church c/o Harris Josey, 8515 Heard Bridge Road, Bartow 30413.
  Friends may call at the residence.

JOSEY -- Entered into rest at a Louisville, Ga., hospital Feb 9, Mrs. Belle S. Josey, 77, of Bartow.  Funeral services will be held this (Sunday) afternoon at 3 o'clock at the New Bethel church with the Rev. L. M. Hartafield officiating.  Interment will be in the church cemetery.  Smith Funeral home, Wadley, Ga.

Mrs. Belle S. Josey
 
  BARTOW, Ga. -- Mrs. Belle S. Josey, 77, of Bartow, died yesterday morning at a Louisville, Ga. Hospital.
  Funeral services will be held today at 3 p.m. at the New Bethel church with the Rev. L.M. Hartsfield officiating.  Interment will be in the churchyard cemetery.
  Nephews will serve as pallbearers.
  Surviving are three sons, Zepho Josey, Harris Josey, Ollis Josey, all of Bartow, six daughters, Mrs. E.T. Smith of Bartow, Mrs. H.L. Smith of Harrison, Mrs. K.M. Smith of Bath, Mrs. T.S. Smith of Bartow, Mrs. B Sineath of Bartow, and Miss Louise Josey of Bartow, two brothers, H.B. Smith of Sandersville, and C.R. Smith of Bartow.

Mr. Ollis Josey
Retired Farmer
 
  BARTOW, Ga. -- Mr. Ollis E. Josey 87, of 1588 Josey Road, died Friday, Dec 5, 1997, at Memorial Hospital of Washington County, Sandersville.
  The funeral will be at 11 a.m. Sunday at Apostolic Church of the Lord Jesus with the Rev. Vina Mae Josey officiating.  Burial will be in the church cemetery.
  Mr. Josey, a native of Washington County, was a retired farmer and a member of Apostolic Church of the Lord Jesus.
  Survivors include his wife, Blanche Smith Josey; four sons, Jerry E Josey, Ronnie O. Josey, Wayne M Josey and William E Josey, all of Bartow; one daughter, June Josey Simpson, Martinez; one brother, Harris B. Josey, Bartow; two sisters, Louise Smith, Wrightsville, and O'Kella Smith, Harrison; and 13 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
  Friends may call at the residence or Smith Funeral Home, Wadley.
  The family will receive friends from 7 to 9 p.m. At the funeral home.

Windom H. Josey
 
  SANDERSVILLE, Ga.  -- Funeral services for Windom H. Josey, 74, of Davisboro, who died Saturday night at his residence after an extended illness, will be held at 4 p.m. Monday at New Bethel Baptist Church near Riddleville with the Rev. A.W. Franklin and Elder J.W. Brantley officiating.  Burial will be in New Bethel Church Cemetery.
  Mr. Josey was born in Washington County, son of the late Everett J. Josey and Lucindia Harris Josey.  He was a retired farmer, member of New Bethel  Baptist Church and a World War I veteran.
  Survivors include his widow, the former Mamie Lou Mixon; one son, Windom H. Josey, Jr., Aiken S.C.; one daughter, Mrs. John L Glover, Augusta; five grandchildren; one brother, E.T. Josey, Davisboro; several nieces and nephews.
  Honorary pallbearers will be the Men's Bible Class of New Bethel Church.
  Pallbearers will be J.E. Josey, Everett Josey, Zepho Josey, J.C. Page, Dewey Josey, and Willis Josey.

Mr. Zepho Josey Retired Tax Preparer
 
  Mr. Zepho Josey, 90, of 7709 Heard Bridge Road, died Thursday, April 6, 1995, at Jefferson Hospital, Louisville.
  The funeral will be at 11 a.m. Saturday at Josey Baptist Church, with the Revs. James Coleman and Inman Gerrald officiating. Burial will be in Josey Baptist Cemetery.
  Mr. Josey, a lifelong resident of Washington County, was a retired tax preparer and had been an agent for Modern Woodmen of America for 40 years. He was a member of Josey Baptist Church for 74 years, was a deacon for 63 years and Sunday school director and chorister for 53 years. He had taught the young adult class and was a clerk of the Mount Vernon Association for 40 years.
  Survivors include his wife, Marie Beckworth Josey; a daughter, Zulene Moats, Bartow; two brothers, Harris Josey and Ollis Josey, both of Bartow; two sisters, Okella Smith, Harrison, and Louise Josey, Wrightsville; and five grandchildren, 10 great-grandchildren and one great-great-granddaughter.
  Pallbearers will be Hollan Josey, Hank Josey, Taylor Ford, Lester Moats, Eric Moats, Brently Moats, Wayne Barfield and Brian Barfield.
  Memorials may be made to Josey Baptist Church Building Fund, c/o Harris Josey, Heard's Bridge Road, Bartow.
  Friends may call at the residence and at Smith Funeral Home, Wadley.
  The family will receive friends from 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.

KAUFFMAN -- In Laureldale, on the 17th inst., EMMA R. (nee Savage), widow of the late John Kauffman, aged 80 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the F.F. Seidel Funeral Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., on Wednesday at 10:30 a.m.  Interment, Alsace Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening.

Mrs. Emma Kauffman
 
Laureldale, April 18 -- Emma R. (Savage), widow of John Kauffman, died in the home of a daughter, Mrs. Elmer Walton, 1622 Bennett street, this borough, aged 80 years.  She was a member of Alsace Lutheran Church.  Surviving are five children:  Mrs. Harry Roberts, Reading; Mrs. Elmer Walton, with whom she resided, and Isaac, Edward and Calvin Kauffman, all of Reading; 16 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
  Funeral services Wednesday 1t 10:30 a.m. in the F.F. Seidel, Inc., Funeral Home.  Interment in Alsace Cemetery.

JOHN A. KAUFFMAN
 
  John A. Kauffman, aged 66 years, died at 2 o'clock this morning after a long illness, at his home, 560 Pike street.  Death was due to a complication of ailments.  Deceased was born and reared in Upper Bern township, a son of the late Michael and Wilhelmina (Marburger) Kauffman.  Practically all his life he was employed as a puddler at the Ninth street rolling mill of the Reading Iron Company.  He was a member of the Ninth street Beneficial Association and the Alsace Lutheran Church.  He is survived by his widow, Emma E. (Savage) Kauffman and these children: Eva, widow of Harry Roberts; Isaac, Edwin, all of this city; Clara, wife of Elmer Walton, Rossdale, and Calvin, this city.  A brother, Charles, this city, and these sisters, [], Katie, and Hettie Kauffman, all of Reading, also remain.

KAUFFMAN -- In this city, on the 10th inst., JOHN A. KAUFFMAN, aged 66 years, 8 months, and 8 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of his son, Edwin F. Kauffman, 560 Pike Street, Saturday at 1:30.  Services at the house.  Interment in Alsace cemetery.

Enoch Koller, paper maker of Alsace twp., this county, died last Thursday. He is survived by his widow and 12 innocent children.
 
Verstarb -- in lezterer Donnerstags Nacht, Enoch Koller, Papiermacher von Clsatz Taunschip, dieses County, an einem bizigen Fieber, im sten Jahre seines Alters -- er hinterliess eine Wittwe und zwolf noch unmundige Kinder.
 
Died -- in the last Thursday night, Enoch Koller, papermaker of Alsace Township, this County, on a bit of a fever, in the first year of his age, he left behind a widow and twelve children

Maria Coller, the widow of Enoch Coller of Alsace Twp., this county, died here last Sunday in her 49th year. (Wrong day)
 
Starb -- am leztern Samstag, Frau Maria Coller, hinterlatzene Wittwe des verstorbenen Enoch Coller, von Clsatz, im 49sten Jahre ihres Alters.
 
Died -- on the last Saturday, Mrs. Maria Coller, widow of Enoch Coller, from Alsace, in the 49th year of her age.

F.W. LANGSTON
 
Special to The State.
  Sardis, Jan. 13 -- Burial services for F.W. Langston were held here Monday morning at 11 o'clock and the interment took place at the Sansbury cemetery.
  Mr. Langston was 72 years old and has spent the majority of his life in the Sardis community.
  He is survived by three sons, Wheeler Langston of Sardis, Berk Langston of Florence, Fitch Langston, and three daughters, Mrs. Connell and the Misses Langston.  He is also survived by one brother, J.W. Langston of Sardis and one sister, Mrs. Sumter Welch of Olanta.

Mrs. G.S. Langston
 
  SARDIS, Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Gillespie Sansbury Langston died at her home here at noon today after an illness of several months.
  Funeral services will be held at 3:30 p.m. Monday in the Sardis Baptist Church by the pastor, the Rev. W.P. Hall, assisted by a former pastor, the Rev. Dwight McAllister, of Cheraw.  Burial will be in the church cemetery.
  Mrs. Langston was born and reared in Darlington County, a daughter of the late William Sansbury and Mary Jane Sirother Sansbury.  Her husband, Henry A. Langston, died several years ago.  She was a member of the Sardis Baptist Church.
  Surviving is one son, H. Abbott Langston; two daughters, Mrs. J. C. Vassy of Timmonsville and Mrs. G.G. Christopher of Pickens; 16 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

WHEELER LANGSTON
Special to The State.
  Florence, March 13. -- Wheeler Langston, 48, died at the McLeod infirmary Sunday afternoon as a result of injuries he received when the buggy in which he was riding Thursday was struck by a truck on a bridge on the Florence-Timmonsville highway.  Funeral services for Mr. Langston were held at the family burying ground Monday.  He is survived by his widow and six children.

Joe Sanford Langston
 
  Joe Sanford Langston, 47, roofing repairman, died Sunday at 5 p.m. At a local hospital after a day's illness.  He was a resident of 113 East Cedar St.
  Funeral services will be conducted Tuesday at 3 p.m. In Stoudenmire chapel by the Rev. D.D. Toby, pastor of Grace Baptist Church.  Burial will be in Sansbury Cemetery near Timmonsville.
  He was born in Florence County, a son of the late Fleetwood Langston and Hannah Nunnley Langston.
  Surviving are his widow, Mae Bullard Langston, Florence; two daughters, Margaret Langston and Jo Ann Langston, Florence; a son, Joseph Raymond Langston, Savannah, Ga.; two brothers, Burke Langston, Marion and Raymond Langston, Savannah, Ga.; three sisters, Mrs. [] Gaskins, Santee, and Mrs. C.H. Bowers and Mrs. G.R. Tuttle, Savannah, Ga.; also several nieces and nephews.
  Active bearers will be Leroy Hatchell, Grady Tippit, G.C. Perkins Jr., J. Waller Isgett, Ford Perkins, S.G. Cottros.
  The body will be at Stoudenmire Funeral Home until services.

DIES AT SARDIS
 
  J.W. Langston, 80, died at his home in the Sardis section yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock.  The funeral services will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock at Sardis Baptist Church and will be conducted by the Rev. B.K. Truluck.  Mr. Langston is survived by his wife and several children.

Mrs. Mozelle Langston
 
  TIMMONSVILLE, March 6 -- Mrs. Mozelle Oliver Langston, 94, of the Sardis community near here died this morning at her home after several years of declining health.
  Funeral services will be held at 3:30 p.m. Friday at Sardis Baptist Church conducted by her pastor, the Rev. William K Bagnall.  Burial will be in the church cemetery.
  Active pallbearers will be Ned Humphrey, Vernon Floyd, Ralph Carter, Dwight Yarborough, Eli Benton and Jerome McElveen.
  Mrs. Langston was the daughter of the late Miles and Sallie Sims Oliver.  She was the widow of the late Julian W. Langston.  She was the oldest member of the Sardis Baptist Church.
  Surviving are three daughters, Mrs. Gladys Jeffords, Mrs. H.W. Keels, and Miss Rosa Langston, Timmonsville;  a step-daughter, Mrs. Mattie O. Powell, Florence; a son, Wallace Langston of the home; a step-son, Josh P. Langston, Timmonsville; also a number of grandchildren and great grandchildren.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Funeral Services Mrs. Pearl Langston Are Held Yesterday
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Funeral Services
Mrs. Pearl Langston
Are Held Yesterday
 
  Funeral services for Mrs. Pearl Munn Langston were held yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock at the residence near Effingham.  The rites were conducted by Rev. W.O. Henderson, pastor of the Bethsaida Methodist church in the presence of large numbers of friends and relatives.  The interment followed in the McLaughlin cemetery.
  Active pallbearers were Herbert Collins, James Snipes, James Rogers, L.B. Rhodes, W.P. McLaughlin and Joe Touchberry.
  Those in charge of the arrangements of the flowers were Misses Catherine Munn, Virginia Oakley, Catharine Broach, Billy Collins, Irene Coward, and Luetie Broach.
  Mrs. Langston died early Sunday morning at the McLeod infirmary after a long illness.  She was the widow of Fleet Langston who died many years ago.
  Mrs. Langston was born, June 4, 1895 at Effingham, the daughter of Julius A Munn and Neomi McLaughlin Munn, also of Effingham, by whom she is survived.  She was a member of the Bethside Methodist Church.
  Besides her parents, she is survived by two daughters, Mrs. IM Thompson of Florence, Miss Evelen Munn; two sons, Woodrow Munn, Johnnie Langston, all of Effingham, three sisters, Mrs. Rufus Wilenlt, Mrs Otis Munn, Mrs. R.L. Grimmey and a brother, Sam Munn, all of Darlington.  Three grandchildren also survive.
  Water Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

William Burke Langston
 
Marion -- William Burke Langston, 59, died suddenly Sunday afternoon at 3:30 p.m. at his home.
  Funeral services are incomplete and will be announced by Bullard Funeral Home.

William B. Langston
 
  MARION -- Funeral services for William Burke Langston, 59, who died suddenly at 3:30 p.m. Sunday at his home, will be conducted at 2 p.m. Tuesday from the Marion Presbyterian Church by his pastor, the Rev. Jack Davidson.  Burial with full Masonic rites will follow in Sansbury Cemetery near Timmonsville.
  Born in Florence County May 13, 1900, he was the son of the late Fleetwood and Anna Nunnery Langston.  He was for many years a building contactor in Marion and a member of the Marion Presbyterian Church, having been active in the work of the church and for several years a teacher of the Men's Bible Class.
  Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Elizabeth Ray Langston; two daughters, Mrs Elizabeth Pittman of Conway, Miss Mary Ann Langston of Marion;  three sons, William Burke Jr., Fleetwood Augustus, Charleston, Harold Eugene of Marion; three sisters, Mrs. Lena Tuttle, Mrs Charlie Bowers, both of Savannah, Ga., Mrs. Lula Gaskins, Santee; one brother, Fitzhugh Langston of Savannah, Ga.
  The body will remain at Bullard Funeral home until one hour prior to service after which it will be at the church.

MRS. WM. F. LEBO
 
  Mrs. Bertha W. Lebo, wife of William F. Lebo, died of a complication of diseases at 9:45 a.m. today at the residence of her husband, 934 Walnut, aged 26 years.  She was ailing four days.  Deceased was born in Pottstown and resided in Reading 2 years.  She was a daughter of Joshua and Mary Yorgey, who, besides her husband, survive, together with the following brothers and sisters: Harry, David, William, Chester, Rebecca, and Ollie Yergey.  Mrs. Lebo was a member of Trinity Lutheran chruch.  The remains will be sent to Pottstown by Funeral Director Theo. C. Auman.

MRS. WM. F. LEBO.
 
Mrs. Bertha W. Lebo, wife of William F. Lebo, died of a complication of diseases at 9:45 a.m. today at the the residence of her husband, 534 Walnut, aged 26 years.  She was ailing four days.  Deceased was born in Pottstown and resided in Reading 2 years.  She was a daughter of Joshua and Mary Yorgey, who, besides her husband, survive together with the following brothers and sisters:  Harry, David, William, Chester, Rebecca and Ollie Yergey.  Mrs. Lebo was a member of Trinity Lutheran church.  The remains will be sent to Pottstown by Funeral Director Theo. C. Auman.

LEBO - At Sheridan, Pa, on the 17th inst., David Lebo. The relatives and friends of the deceased are respectfully invited, without further notice, to attend the funeral on Tuesday morning. April 23rd at 9:30 o'clock at the house. Interment at Newmanstown, Pa.

Deaths and Funerals
David Lebo died very suddenly while engaged at work in the garden of Zacharias Kauffman at Sheridan, aged 60 years. The immediate cause of death was heart disease. He was a gardener by occupation.

LEBO -- Fell asleep in this city, on the 9th inst., ELLA LEBO, wife of John Lebo, aged 65 years, 3 months, 6 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 421 1/2 Locust St., Wednesday afternoon, 3 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment, Aulenbach's Cemetery.

STRICKEN in KITCHEN
