HUSBAND FINDS WIFE LYING ON FLOOR -- DIES IN HOSPITAL
 
  Ella (Stoeber), wife of John A. Lebo, while at work in the kitchen of her home, 421 1/2 Locust street, was seized with a heart attack and died at 5:20 a.m. Today at the Homeopathic Hospital.  She was 65 years of age, Mrs. Lebo was discovered at 4:30 Friday afternoon lying on the floor, by her husband.  He summoned Dr. Glick and after prescribing treatment had her removed in the Junior ambulance to the hospital.  Her death was a shock to the family, for as late as noon Friday she had been conversing with neighbors and seemed to be in good health.  Coroner Rorke was notified.
  Deceased was a lifelong resident of this city and a member of St. Luke's Lutheran Church.  She leaves besides her husband, three sons, Warren, Raymond, both of this city; Ralph, United States Army, and a grandson, Norman Lebo, this city.  Three brothers survive.  Undertaker Cramp & Son took charge of the remains.

LEBO -- In this city, on the 1st inst., JOHN LEBO, aged 67 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of his son Warren Lebo, 21 S 23d St., Mt Penn on Saturday morning at 10 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment, Aulenbach's Cemetery.

JOHN LEBO
 
John Lebo, aged 67 years, 21 South Twenty-third street.  Mt. Penn, died at St. Joseph's Hospital after a short illness.  He was born and reared in Myerstown, but was a resident of Mt. Penn for many years, where he lived with a son.  He was a member of St. Luke's Lutheran church, and the Modern Woodmen of America.  His wife, Ellen Lebo, preceded him in death by a number of years.  He is survived by these children:  Ralph Stockton, Cal.: Raymond, Pottstown; Warren, Mt Penn.  Norma, Reading, and these brothers and sisters:  William, Detroit; Willis, Williamsport; Sallie, wife of Henry Hageman, and Kate, wife of J.W. Fett, both of Reading.  Funeral Director Miller removed the remains to his late residence in Mt. Penn.

LEBO -- In this city, on the 29th inst., LILLIAN J. (nee Spears), widow of Willis H. Lebo, aged 74 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the Miller Funeral Home, 48 N. 4th St. On Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Interment in Aulenbach's cemetery.  Friends may call at the Funeral Home Thursday evening.

MRS. LILLIAN J. LEBO
 
Lillian J. (Spears), widow of Willis H. Lebo, died at her home, 334 North Eleventh street, aged 74 years.  Surviving are three sons, Harry W., Camden, N.J.: Charles S. And F. Clayton, both of Philadelphia; two brothers, Harry Y Spears and Frank Spears, of Philadelphia, and two sisters, Katie, wife of William Collier, and Miss Lizzie Spears, both in the State of Washington.
  The body was removed to the Miller funeral home, where services will be held Friday at 2 p.m., the Rev. C.E. Roth officiating.  Interment in Aulenbach's Cemetery.

FUNERALS
The funeral of Miranda, wife of William Lebo, took place from the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Henry Winter, 534 South 14th, at 1:30 p.m. The cortege proceeded to the German Lutheran Chapel, where services were conducted by Rev. Dr. J.J. Kuendig. The remains lay in a square-cornered solid walnut casket with heavy carved corners, oxidized extension bar handles, oxidized trimmings and plate bearing name and age of deceased, and date of death and were attired in a black dress. The bearers were. Harry, Edward and Walter Winter, Charles and Clayton Lebo and Paul Hageman. The tributes included a spray of roses, from William and Bertha; cross of natural flowers, Mr. and Mrs. William Reber; family; cluster of carnations, Daughter Kathryn and family; cluster of carnations, Son John and family; wreath, H.A. Hageman and family; cluster of carnations and palms, Son Willis. Internment in Trinity Lutheran cemetery. Funeral director, F.F. Seidel.

LEBO - In this city on the 3d inst., MIRANDA, widow of William Lebo, aged 74 years and 22 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Henry Winters, 534 South 14th Street, on Monday afternoon at 1:30 at the house. Services at St. John's German Lutheran chapel. Internment in Trinity Lutheran Cemetery.

LEBO - In this city on the 3d inst., MIRANDA, widow of William Lebo, aged 74 years and 22 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Henry Winters, 534 South 14th Street, on Monday afternoon at 1:30 at the house. Services at St. John's German Lutheran chapel. Internment in Trinity Lutheran Cemetery.

Mrs. William Lebo.
  Miranda, widow of William Lebo, died Tuesday evening, aged 74 years and 22 days, at the residence of her daughter. Mrs. Henry Hagemann, 214 North 9th. These children remain: Mrs. Henry Hagemann, Mrs. Henry Winter, Mrs. John Fett, Willis, John, this city, and William of Altoona, also 16 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. The remains were removed to the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Henry Winter, 534 South 14th.

MRS. REBECCA L. LEBO
 
  At 2:55 o'clock yesterday afternoon Mrs. Rebecca L. Lebo, beloved wife of William F. Lebo, died at her home, 405 Sixteenth street, of a complication of diseases.  The maiden name of the deceased was Peifer and she was born at Sinking Spring, near Reading, November 30, 1875.  She was the daughter of Mr. And Mrs. Levi Peifer.  Her mother is dead but her father is living and is a resident of Harrisburg.  Beside her husband and one son she is survived by two brothers and one sister:  Daniel G. And Harry Peifer and Mrs. Emma Kreider, all of Reading.  The deceased was a member of the First Reformed church of Reading.  The body will be taken to that city on the 11:40 train this morning for interment.

LEBO - In Altoona, on the 6th inst., REBECCA L., wife of William F. Lebo and daughter of Levi F. and the late Lydia Peifer, aged 26 years.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from the residence of F.B. DeTurk, No. 421 North 10th St. on Tuesday morning at 8:45 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment private at Sinking Spring, Pa.

LEBO - In this city, on the 4th inst., WILLIAM LEBO, aged 65 years, 7 months and 21 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also Juniata tribe, No. 74 I.O.R.M., and St. John's Lutheran beneficial society are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, 214 North 9th St., on Tuesday afternoon, at 1:30 o'clock.  Services at St. John's Lutheran chapel.  Interment at Trinity Lutheran cemetery.

LEBO - In this city, on the 4th inst., WILLIAM LEBO, aged 65 years, 7 months and 21 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also Juniata tribe, No. 74 I.O.R.M., and St. John's Lutheran beneficial society are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, 214 North 9th St., on Tuesday afternoon, at 1:30 o'clock.  Services at St. John's Lutheran chapel.  Interment at Trinity Lutheran cemetery.

The funeral of Wm. Lebo took place from his residence, 214 North 9th.  Services were held at St. John's Lutheran chapel by Rev. Kuendic, after which interment was made in the Lutheran cemetery.  The bearers were selected from the society of St. John's Lutheran church and Juniata tribe, No 74, I.O.R.M.  There was a pillow of natural flowers from family; palm leaf and 6 roses, children; sheaf of wheat, wife, and a tomahawk from the Red Men.  Undertakers Charles Henninger & Son.

LEBO - In this city, on the 4th inst., WILLIAM LEBO, aged 65 years, 7 months and 21 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also Juniata tribe, No. 74 I.O.R.M., and St. John's Lutheran beneficial society are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence, 214 North 9th St., on Tuesday afternoon, at 1:30 o'clock.  Services at St. John's Lutheran chapel.  Interment at Trinity Lutheran cemetery.

William Lebo, aged 65 years, died of a complication of diseases, Thursday, 10 a.m. after an illness of one week, at his residence, 214 North 9th.  Deceased was born in Tulpehocken and came to Reading 24 years ago.  He was a carpenter by trade, and for a number of years worked at the Reading car shops.  For the past 4 years he and his son-in-law, Harry Hageman, conducted the cigar business.  His wife and following children survive:  Willis, of Lebanon; John, of this city, and William, of Girardville; Clara, wife of Henry Winters; Sallie, wife of Henry Hageman, and Kate, wife of John Fett, this city.   Deceased was a member of Juniata tribe, No. 74, I.O.O.R; St. John's Lutheran church and St. John's beneficial society.

LEBO -- In Williamsport, on the 28th inst., WILLIS H. LEBO, aged 69 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the parlors of Funeral Director C.I. Miller, 48 North Fourth Street, on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Remains can be viewed at the Funeral Parlors Wednesday evening.  Interment in Aulenbach's cemetery.

LEBO -- In Williamsport, on the 28th inst., WILLIS H. LEBO, aged 69 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the parlors of Funeral Director C.I. Miller, 48 North Fourth Street, on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Remains can be viewed at the Funeral Parlors Wednesday evening.  Interment in Aulenbach's cemetery.

WYLLIS H. LEBO
 
Wyllis H. Lebo, aged 69 years, a former resident of this city, died at the home of his son, Charles Lebo, at Williamsport.  He resided in Reading for many years, and went to the home of his son three years ago.  While in Reading he was employed at the Oley street mills of the Reading Iron Company.  In addition to being a member of St. Andrew's Reformed Church, of this city, he was a member of Lodge No 155, L.O.O. Moose, Reading.  There survive his widow, Lilliam (Spears) Lebo, of Philadelphia, and three sons, Harry and Clayton, both of Philadelphia, and Charles, Williamsport, at whose home he died.  The remains will be brought to this city for burial on Thursday by Funeral Director Miller.  Interment will take place in Aulenbach's Cemetery.

Verheiratet -- am 24sten, durch den Ehrw. Hrn. Pauli, Hr. Heinrich Leiss von Alsass Tauschip mit Miss Hanna Vanried, von Cumru Taunschip
 
Married - on the 24th, by the Venerable Mr. Pauli, Hr. Heinrich Leiss von Alsass Township with Miss Hanna Van Reed, by Cumru Township

LOOMIS - In Spring City, Sat. Dec. 5. FRIDOLIN LOOMIS, wife of Joseph E. Loomis, aged 81 years.
  Friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral at the Nelson Funeral Home, 331 New St., Spring City, Wednesday, Dec 9 at 2 p.m.  Interment in Brownback's Reformed Cemetery.  Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday evening, 7 to 9.

LOOMIS -- In Spring City, on Saturday, Dec. 5, 1953, Fridolin Loomis, wife of Joseph E. Loomis, aged 81 years.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral at the Nelson Funeral Home, 331 New St.  Spring City, on Wednesday at 2 p.m.  Interment  Brownback's Reformed cemetery.  Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday evening 7 to 9.

MRS. FRIDOLIN LOOMIS, 81 wife of Joseph E. Loomis, 450 ARCH STREET, SPRING CITY, formerly of East Vincent township, died Saturday night at 9:30 o'clock in her home, following an illness of nine months.
  Mrs. Loomis was born in Warwick township, daughter of the late James and Mary Miller.  She later lived many years in East Vincent township, near Hiestand's store, and live in Spring City the past six years.  She was a member of Ebeneezer Methodist church.
  Surviving besides her husband are a daughter, May, wife of Donald S. Haldeman, 318 Chestnut street, Spring City; three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
  Funeral services will be conducted Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock in the Nelson funeral home, 331 New street, Spring City.  Interment will be made in Brownback's Reformed cemetery.

LOOMIS -- In Phoenixville hospital, on Thursday, July 5, 1956, Joseph E. Loomis, aged 85 years.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral at the Nelson Funeral Home, 331 New St., Spring City, on Sunday at 2 p.m.  Interment Brownback's cemetery.  Friends may call at the funeral home Saturday evening 7 to 9.

JOSPEH E. LOOMIS, 85, of 318 CHESTNUT STREET, SPRING CITY, died at 6:05 p.m. Yesterday in Phoenixville hospital, where he was a patient eight days.  He had been ill several months.
  Son of the late William and Sarah (Whitby) Loomis, he was born in Warwick township.  For many years he lived at Hiestand's corner, Ridge road, Spring City RD 1, where he operated a truck farm.
  He lived in Spring City eight years and for the past three years lived with his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. And Mrs. Donald S. Haldeman, at the Chestnut street address.
  He is survived only by his daughter, May, wife of Donald Haldeman; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.
 Services will be conducted at the Nelson funeral home, 331 New street, Spring City, Sunday at 2 p.m.  Interment will be in Brownback's cemetery.

Berhenrathet --  vor etlichen Wochen, Hr. Johann Ludwig, von Amity Taunschip, mit Miss Sarah Bechtel von Cumru Taunschip, dieser Caunty
 
Married -- several weeks ago, Mr. Johann Ludwig, from Amity Township, with Miss Sarah Bechtel from Cumru Township, this County

HENRY L MACHEMER
 
Henry L. Machemer died Saturday at 4 p.m. At the home of his grandson, John R. Althouse, near Leinbach's Hotel, Bern township, aged 82 years.  He was a member of Epler's Church.
  There survive his widow, Mary Ellen (Savage) Machemer, and one sister, Mrs Rosa Hafer, Reading.  The Greenawalt Funeral Home is in charge.

MRS. MARY E. MACHEMER
 
Mary E. (Savage), widow of Henry Machemer, 84, died last night at the home of Mr. And Mrs. John R. Althouse, in Bern township, near Leinbach's Hotel.  Mrs. Machemer broke a leg in a fall six weeks ago and failed to recover from the injury.  Two sisters survive Mrs. Henrietta Althouse and Mrs. Emma Kauffman, both of Reading.
  She was a native and lifelong resident of Bern township and a member of Epler's Reformed Church.  Funeral services, the Rev. George W. Gerhard officiating, will take place at 2 o'clock Tuesday afternoon at the Althouse home.  Interment in Epler's Church Cemetery.  Funeral Director Greenawalt has charge.

MACHEMER -- In Bern township, on the 11th inst., MARY E., widow of Henry Machemer, aged 84 years, 8 months and 21 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of Mr. And Mrs. John R. Althouse, near Leinbach's Hotel.  Tuesday, 2 p.m. D.S.T.  All services at the house.  Interment in Epler's Church Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening.

Robert C. Martin
 
  Robert C. Martin, 59, of Dillsburg, died Friday in Holy Spirit Hospital.
  He was a truck driver, last employed at Webster's Trucking and also was a driver for C&S Grocers, Rich Food, Super Rite and Harrisburg Daries.
  He was preceded in death by his mother, Marion Martin and a son, Robert "Bobby" Martin.
  Surviving are his wife, Linda M. Martin; two daughters, Tracy Shulda of Wormleysburg and Laura Martin of New Jersey; one step son, John Carnell of Dillsburg and his fiancee, Gisela; one step-grandson, Chase Shulda and one step granddaughter, Mariah Carnell.
  Services will be at 10:30 a.m. Wednesday, at Musselman Funeral Home & Cremation Services, Lemoyne.  Entombment will be in Rolling green Memorial Park.  Viewing will be from 7-9 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home.
  Memorial contributions may be made to American Cancer Society, Capital Region Unit, 3211 N. Front Street, Suite 100, Harrisburg, PA  17110.
  Musselmanfuneral.com
  www.pennlive.com/obits

MAY - On the 14th day of March, GENE C (Fett), widow of George E MAY, of River Rd, age 82 years.
  Graveside services in Forest Hills Memorial Park.  Friday at 1:00 PM.  There will be no public viewing.  Contributions may be made to American Diabetes Foundation 2680 North Canton, OH  44720 or American Heart Assn, 25 Stevens Ave. West Lawn, PA 19609.

Gene C. May
 
  Gene G. May, 82, of River Road, Muhlenberg Township, died March 14 at 7:40 a.m. in Reading Hospital, where she had been a patient for two days.  Her husband, George E. May, died Dec 14, 1998.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late Floyd W. and Florence E. (Bechtel) Fett.
  May had been employed as a private duty licensed practical nurse in the area.
  She was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church, Reading.
  May was a 1939 graduate of Reading High School and received her nursing degree from Reading Area Community College in 1969.
  She is survived by a son, Christian A., Kimberton, Chester County; and two daughters, Carol A. (May) Angstadt, with whom she last resided, and Georgene E. (May) Lindvig, Tualatin, Ore.
  Other survivors include a sister, Marjorie (Fett) Rettgers, Dillsburg, York County.
  There are also two grandsons and four great-grandchildren.
  Graveside services will be Friday at 1 p.m. In Forest Hills Memorial Park, Reiffton.  Bean Funeral Homes Inc., Sinking Spring, is in charge of arrangements.

George E. May, 76; ex-GPU supervisor
 
  George E. May, a retired GPU Energy supervisor, died Monday at 5:50 a.m. in Mifflin Center, Cumru Township, where he had resided since last Thursday.
  May, 76, of 510 Snyder Road, Whitfield, was the husband of Gene C. (Fett) May.
  He began his career with the former Metropolitan Edison Co. In 1939 as a former Wyomissing Polytechnic Institute cooperative student.  May was name a cadet engineer in 1948.
  Early in his career, May was employed as a junior electrical engineer, electrical engineer, project engineer, system relay and meter superintendent and assistant chief electrical engineer.
  In 1969, he served as operating superintendent for the central division.  May was a consulting engineer and system planning engineer from 1969 to 1972.  Her served as senior staff engineer from 1972 to 1974 and was electrical control engineering supervisor from 1974 until his retirement in 1982.
  Born in Reading, he was a son of the late Ernest C. And Kathryn (Hunsicker) May.
   May was a 1939 graduate of Reading High school, a 1942 graduate of the former WPI, no Penn State Berks-Lehigh Valley College, Spring Township; a 1943 graduate of the Merchant Marine Academy with a bachelor's degree in marine engineering; and a 1948 graduate of Pennsylvania State University with a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering.
  He was a 1961 graduate of the University of Michigan's public utility executive program.
  May was a Navy veteran of World War II.
  He was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church, Reading.
  May was a past chairman of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, IEEE Power system Relaying Committee, the Middle Atlantic Utilities Telecommunications Association and the Pennsylvania Engineers Association's relay committee.
  He was a former committeeman and treasurer of Boy Scout Troop 429 and a former volunteer driver for the Berks County Chapter American Red Cross.
  May was a judge of the Reading-Berks County Science Fair and a former vice chairman of the Penn State Berks-Lehigh Valley College development fund drive.
  He was a past secretary of the Middle Atlantic Power Research Committee.
  Surviving are two daughters, Carol A. (May) Angstadt, Muhlenberg Township, and Georgene E. (May) Lindvig, Jackson, Wis.; and a son, Christian A., Kimberton, Chester County.
  Other survivors include a brother, Ernest C. Jr. And a sister Betty Lou (May) Miller, both of Lakeland, Fla.; and two grandsons.
  Graveside services will be Friday at 11 a.m. In Forest Hills Memorial Park, Reiffton.  The Bean Funeral Home, Sinking Spring, is in charge of arrangements.

Alex A. McNeely
 
  GIRARD, Ga. -- Alex Albert McNeely, 64, of Girard, died Tuesday.
  Funeral services will be held at 5 p.m. Thursday at Bethany Methodist Church with the Rev. H.G. McCrary and Troy Hollingsworth officiating.
  Burial will be in Burke Memorial Gardens.
  A native of Burke County, Ga., he was a member of Bethany Methodist Church and Sardis Methodist Men's Club.
  Survivors include two daughters, Mrs. Donald Self, Waynesboro, Ga., and Mrs. Larry Tyndal, Savannah; and two sisters, Mrs. Corinne Hargett, Waynesboro, and Miss Ruth McNeely, Savannah.
  Pallbearers will be A.D. Reddick, Arthur Long, Martin Skinner, Guy Zeigler, T.G. Mailard, Benny Jackson and Gillis Jenkins.
  Friends may call at DeLoach Funeral Home.

C.J. McNeely
 
  WRENS, Ga. -- Funeral services for C.J. (Jack) McNeely, 73, of Wrens, who died at 10:45 a.m. Tuesday at Waynesboro, Ga., hospital following an extended illness, will be held at 4 p.m. Wednesday at the Ebenezer A.R. Presbyterian Church, Wrens, with the Rev. L.L. Richardson officiating.  Burial will be in the churchyard cemetery.
  A native of Jefferson County, he was a son of the late Tom and Delia Garrett McNeely, was a retired farmer and a member of the Ebenezer A.R. Presbyterian Church.
  Survivors include his widow, Mrs. Louise Burke McNeely; a daughter, Mrs. Cora Lee Eaves, Wrens; a son, Ollie J McNeely, Charleston, S.C.; two sisters, Mrs. Corene Haggett, Waynesboro, and Miss Ruth McNeely, Savannah, Ga.; a brother, Alex McNeely, Girard, Ga., seven grandchildren and several nieces and nephews.
  Pallbearers will be Ross Chance, Alton Dye, Tommy Burke, Jack Hobbs, Greer Burke and Juddy Attaway.  The body will be at the residence from 10 a.m. Until the hour of the services.

Hugh McNeely to be Buried Today
Funeral will Be Held at Moxley (Ga.) Church
 
  General services for Hugh McNeely, 69, will be held at the Moxley (Ga.) Methodist Church at 3 o'clock this afternoon, Rev. J.J.M. Mize, pastor of the St. Luke Methodist church, officiating assisted by Rev. E.C. Lucas.  The funeral cortege will leave Platt's Funeral Home at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon for Moxley.
  The pallbearers will be C.L. Powell, F.H. Pope, S.L. Pardua , Byron Howard, J.B. Harroll and H Ferguson.
  Mr. McNeely died at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. W.B. Hawkins, 3065 Clark street, Wednesday night at 11:30 o'clock.   He was a native of Jefferson county, where he had been a farmer nearly all his life.  He was a member of St. Luke Methodist church here.
  Survivors are five daughters, Mrs. W.B. Hawkins, Mrs. I.T. Watkins, Mrs. Mamie Price, and Mrs. Hattie McNeely, all of Augusta and Mrs. Willis Screws, of Wadley, Ga.; one son, W.M. McNeely of Augusta; one brother, Joe McNeely, of Summit, Ga.; 23 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

RUSSELL M'NEELY DIES AT MIDVILLE
 
  Midville, Ga., Nov. 20 -- Russell McNeely died Sunday night at his country home in Burke county near Midville, following an illness of one week.  He was 52 years old.  He had engaged in farming in Burke county for many years.
  He maintained an interest in politics and in the civic affairs of his community.  He served for several years as a steward in the Midville Methodist church.  His wife preceeded him to the grave just three months ago.
  He is survived by one son, Paul McNeely of Jacksonville, Fla., a stepson, Milton Coleman of Midville, and three brothers, Gus McNeely of Davisboro, and Clyde and Roger McNeely of Wrens.
  The funeral was conducted Monday afternoon from the Midville Methodist church by the pastor, the Rev. A.C. Prickett.  Burial was in the Midville cemetery.
   The pallbearers were:  Joe B. Jones, J.E. Cross, Joel Davis, W.C. Mulling, Seab. A Johns and J Lewis Slade.

JOSEPH P. MCNEELY
 
  SWAINSBORO, Ga., Aug. 14. -- Joseph P. McNeely, 70, Emanuel county farmer, died at his home near Graymont early yesterday morning.  Funeral services were held at 2:30 this afternoon at Coleman Chapel church near Wadley.  Interment was in the church cemetery.  Rev. L.B. McMichael of Summit and Rev. J.M. Foster of Swainsboro officiated.
  He was a son of Hugh and Sallie Roberts McNeely of Jefferson County.  He moved to Emanuel county 32 years ago.  The deceased was married four times as follows:  Anna Murphy, Sallie Watkins, Mamie Raines and Mollie Anderson, all deceased except the last named.
  Besides his widow and a large family connection in Jefferson and Emanuel counties, he is survived by seven children, Willie McNeely and Mrs. Cora Lee Lamb of Augusta; Freddie McNeely of Summit and Joseph McNeely of Metter, all children by his first wife; Silas McNeely of Micanopy, Fla., a son by his second wife, and Jordan McNeely of Summit and Mrs. Mary Beasley of Graymont, children by his fourth wife.

J.P. M'NEELY, 72, CLAIMED BY DEATH
 
  Graymont Summitt, Ga., Aug. 13 -- J.P. McNeely, 72, died at his home near here at 4 o'clock today.  Funeral services will be held at Coleman's chapel near Wadley at two o'clock Tuesday.  Rev. L.B. McMichael will conduct the services assisted by Rev. J.M. Foster of Swainsboro.  He is survived by his wife and five sones.  Willie McNeely of Augusta; Freddy McNeely and Jordan McNeely, Jr., of Summit, Joe McNeely,  of Metter, Silas McNeely of Micanopy, Fla., two daughters, Mrs. Cora Lee Lamb of Augusta, Mrs. Mary Beasley of Graymont.

MCNEELY FUNERAL IS SET FOR TODAY
 
  Midville, Ga., Aug 16 -- Mrs. Russell McNeely died early Thursday morning at her country home one mile from Midville.  Her death was not unexpected as she had been seriously ill with cancer for a long time.  She was 56 years of age.
  She was twice married.  By her first husband, Daniel Coleman, she leaves one son, Milton Coleman of Midville.  Following Mr Coleman's death, she married Russell McNeely, who survives her, as does their son, Paul McNeely, of Jacksonville, Fla.  Surviving her also are five brothers, Douglas, Joseph D., Paul D., William B., and Wilson D. Drew, all of Midville, and a number of nephews and nieces.
  The funeral will be conducted Friday morning at the Midville Methodist church of which she was a devoted member.  The service will be conducted by her pastor, Rev. A.C. Prickett.  Burial will follow in the Midville city cemetery.

Mrs. Louise B. McNeely
 
  WRENS, Ga. -- Mrs. Louise B. McNeely, 78, died Saturday in a Louisville, Ga., hospital.
  The funeral will be held at 3 p.m. Monday at Ebeneezer A.R.P. Church with the Rev. Arthur Allen officiating, assisted by the Rev. Michael Garvey.  Burial will be in the church cemetery.
  Mrs. McNeely was a native of Jefferson County.  She was a member of Ebeneezer A.R.P. Church and the W.M.S. And secretary of the Sunday school class.
  Survivors include one daughter, Mrs. C.F. Eaves, Wrens; one son, Ollie J. McNeely, Goose Creek, S.C.; and one brother, Paul Burke, Wrens.
  Friends may call at the home of her daughter or at the Oaklawn Chapel until 1:30 p.m. And then at the church.

Mrs. Mollie McNeely
 
  TWIN CITY, Ga. -- Mrs. Mollie A. McNeely, 81, died Tuesday.
  Funeral services will be at 3 p.m. Today at twin City Methodist Church with the Rev. Loy Scott and the Rev. C.E. Seago officiating.  Burial will be in Coleman's Chapel Cemetery.
  She was a native of Jefferson County and a member of Twin City First United Methodist Church.
  Survivors include two daughters, Mrs. Lee Ely of Soperton, Ga., and Mrs. Cora Lamb of Madison, Ala.; two sons, Jordan McNeely of Twin City and Silas McNeely of Ormand Beach, Fla.; and two brothers, Miles Anderson of Twin City and Lee Anderson of Wadley, Ga.
  Pallbearers will be B.W. West, Buster Jones, Robert Roland, Luther Watson, George Clifton and Darly Lane.
  Friends may call at Peebles-Curry Mortuary in Swainsboro, Ga.

Roger Gamble McNeely Passes at Wrens Home
 
  WRENS, Ga., Sept 21. -- Funeral services for Roger Gamble McNeely, 59, will be held at the Ebeneezer Presbyterian church Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock with the Rev. James H Snell officiating and the Rev. Dr. M.R. Plaxten assisting.
  Mr McNeely died at his home in Wrens early Tuesday morning following an extended illness.
  He is survived by his wife Mrs. Sara Lou Dukes McNeely, one daughter, Mrs. Sara Alive Yonkey of Pacific Grove, Calif., one grandson, Jerry Ray Yonkey of Pacific Grove, Calif., two brothers, C.J. McNeely of Wrens and Alex McNeely of Girard, two sisters, Mrs. Corine Hargett of Waynesboro and Miss Ruth McNeely of Virginia.
  Pallbearers will be Walter Wren, Walter Bell, D.C. Kirkland, Will Jordon, Moody Allen, Robert Hobbs, Ralph Harris, and Lynn Farmer.

Mrs. Catharine Miller died at her home near Warwick, Chester county, aged 78 years.  Deceased was a very estimable lady.  Her maiden name was Stoneback.  A husband and 6 children, 4 sons and 2 daughters, survive.  Mrs. Miller was a sister-in-law of Mrs. Adeline B Fry and John E. Miller, this city.

MILLER -- In Chester County, on the 25th inst., JAMES B. MILLER, in his 89th year.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend from the residence of his grand-daughter, Mrs Mary Hofheinz, near St. Peters, Monday, March 1, at 12:30.  Services at the house.  Further services at Pine Swamp Church.  Interment in adjoining cemetery.  Autos will meet the trains at St. Peters.

JAMES V MILLER
 
  Relatives in this city were informed of the death of James V. Miller, which occurred at his home, St. Peters, Chester county, on Thursday at 5 p.m.  Deceased was in his 89th year and a frequent visitor to this city.  Joseph Miller, train dispatcher at the local station of the Pennsylvania Railroad, is a nephew.  Deceased was a brother of the late Mrs. Adeline Fry, mother of Dr. John M. Bertolet.  She died last spring at the age of 94.  He was the last of his immediate family.  Deceased's wife, Mary Ann, died in 1913.
  Mr. Miller for many years was an engineman at the Brooke plant, Birdsboro.  There survive four children, as follows:  Mrs. Ida Torpey, 1017 Oley street; Mrs. Fridola Loomis, living near Spring City; Theodore, McKees Rocks, and Morris, Coatesville.

DEATH OF JOHN MILLER
 
Parkesburg Man Succumbs as Result of Being Struck by Steam Hammer
 
  John Miller, Sr., was seriously injured by being stuck by a steam hammer in the Parkesburg Iron Works on Thursday last, died in the Coatesville hospital last evening at six o'clock.  Death was the result of some internal injuries that he received at the time of the accident.
  Until noon yesterday the condition of Mr. Miller was reported to be favorable and it was thought that he was getting along nicely and he had good chances of recovering.  During the afternoon however his condition grew worse rapidly and by four o'clock his condition was very grave.
  Mr. Miller was forty nine years old and has been living in Parkesburg for the last twenty years during which time he has been employed in the iron works as a shingler, and he was considered one of the best in the business.  About seven years ago his wife died and since then he has been boarding in town.
  He is survived by his father and mother who are living at St. Peters, Chester county and by a son and a daughter.  The daughter, Miss Flossie Miller is a student at Pierce school in Philadelphia while his son John Miller, Jr. Is a foreman on the Pennsylvania railroad.  He also has a bother Morris Miller, who lives in Coatesville.
  The funeral will take place from 412 Main street, Parkesburg on Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Internment will be made at Upper Octorara cemetery.

Mrs. Martha Miller, nee Thomas, widow of John H Miller, died at her home, in Warwick township, Chester county, this a.m.  Had she lived until February 7th, 1893, she would have been 95 years of age.  She was taken ill on Sunday night with heart trouble.  Dr. Christman, of Warwick attended.  Mrs. Miller's husband died in 1876.  Deceased was the mother of 10 children, 4 sons and 6 daughters, 5 of whom survive:  Philip, Wm. And James, of Warwick; Mrs. Adeline B. Fry, of Reading, and Mrs. Sarah Taggard, of Phila., besides a great number of grand and great grand children.  Funeral on Saturday morning, Sept 17.  Mrs. Miller was remarkably active for one of her age and up to her last illness was able to be about, and take short walks.  It was her annual custom to visit her children in Reading and Phila., and she usually make the these trips alone.  Her eyesight was good, her memory was excellent and she loved to relate reminiscences of her youthful days.  She was a devoted mother, took a great interest in her numerous descendants and was beloved by a large circle of friends and neighbors.

Death of Mrs. James Miller
 
From infirmities incident to old age, Mary (nee Mock), wife of James Miller, died Tuesday evening in her home near St. Peters.  Deceased had been ailing for some time, but was confined to her bed for only about three weeks.  She was in her 82d year.  Besides her husband, she is survived by several children, among them being Maurice, of Coatesville; Theodore, residing in Western Pennsylvania, and Mrs. Joseph Loomis of Seven Stars.  She was a member of Pine Swamp Evangelical Church.

Morris T. Miller
 
  Morris T. Miller, 77, of Elverson R.D. 1, a retired Reading Company locomotive hostler, died in Pottstown Hospital after an illness of one week.  He was employed by the railroad for 30 years before retiring 14 years ago.  Born in Warwick Township, he was a son of the late James and Mary (Mock) Miller.  He was a member of Mt. Carmel Methodist Church, Warwick Township.
  Surviving are a daughter, Viola, wife of Roy Klinger, Elverson R. D. 1; two grandchildren; five great-grandchildren; and a sister, Fridolan, wife of Joseph Loomis, Spring City.
  Services will be conducted Thursday at 2 p.m. In the home of his son-in-law and daughter.  Burial will take place in Mt. Carmel Cemetery, in charge of the White Memorial Home, Parkerford.

Weddings.
 
  Peter P. Miller, barber, 339 North 9th, and Miss Sallie I. Savage, daughter of Enoch Savage, 1554 North 9th, were married at 7:30 p.m., Thursday, by Rev. Father Bornemann, at the parsonage of St. Paul's Catholic church.  Miss Annie Miller, sister of the groom, was the bridesmaid, and Benj. J. Becker was the groomsman.  The bride and bridesmaids were attired in crÃ¨me cashmere.  After the ceremony, the wedding party was driven to 903 North 11th, where the happy couple commenced housekeeping, the groom having furnished the dwelling in a handsome manner.  Numerous wedding gifts were received, among which was  a bed-room suit and other costly presents.

Peter P. Miller
 
  Peter P. Miller died at his home 915 Buttonwood street, aged 70 years.  He was born in Pottsville, the son of Phillip and Catherine Miller.  He conducted a barber shop for many years.  He was a member of St. Paul's Catholic Church, F.O.E. And the Ivy Leaf Association.
  Surviving are his widow, Sallie I. (Savage) , and a sister, Mrs. Rose Schlick, of Philadelphia.  Funeral Friday at 8:30 a.m. In the Kern Funeral Home.  High Requiem Mass will be celebrated at 9 a.m. In St. Paul's Church.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Reading Doctor's Uncle Dies at Age of 92 years
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
READING DOCTOR's UNCLE DIES AT AGE OF 92 YEARS
 
  Philip Miller, the oldest resident of Warwick township, Chester county, and one of the most highly respected citizens, died at his home at Pine Swamp after an illness of six months with asthma.  The was 83 years old and a native of Warwick.  He died on the old homestead premises, although not in the original house, where his father, John Miller, lived.
  He was a farmer by occupation.  His son John farmed the old place for years.  Mr Miller's wife (nee Stoneback) preceded him in death by 20 years.  He leaves the following children:  Philip Jr., of Atlantic City; Theodore, of Parkeford; Clara, wife of James Evans, of Elverson; John, of Pine Swamp, and Martha, at home.  Deceased resided with his unmarried daughter for some years.  He was a brother to James Miller, of St. Peter's and Mrs. Adeline Frey, of Shillington.  Dr. John M Bertolet, 1333 Perkiomen Avenue, this city, is a nephew of deceased, who frequently visited Reading.
  Mr Miller was a Republican, but never sought or held office, although taking an intelligent interest in public affairs.  He was a keen angler and loved to whip the trout stream.  He was a member of Stichter Lodge, F. And A. M.

MILLER -- On the 18th inst., SALLIE I. (nee Savage) MILLER, aged 85 years.
  Services from the Theo. C. Auman, Inc. Funeral Parlors, 247 Penn St., Tuesday at 11 a.m.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

Mrs. Sallie I. Miller
 
  Mrs. Sallie I. (Savage) Miller 85, widow of Peter Miller, of the Caum Memorial Home, 1701 Hampden Blvd., died yesterday in the Reading Hospital.
  A daughter of the late Enoch and Helen (Ritz) Savage, Mrs. Miller was a member of St. Luke's Lutheran Church.
  Funeral services will be held in the T.C. Auman, Inc., Funeral Parlors on Tuesday at 11 a.m.  The Rev. Samuel C. Jaxheimer will officiate.  Burial will be made in Charles Evans Cemetery.

MRS. SARAH MILLER
 
  Birdsboro, Sept. 21 -- Mrs. Sarah Miller (nee Slipp) died suddenly at the home of her son-in-law, Charles Care, in Union township, near the eastern boundary of the borough from a hear attack.  Although nearly 89 years of age, she was a comparatively active and had been about the house as usual.  She complained of pain about her heart and went to her room to lie down and she died shortly after.
  Mrs Miller came to live with her daughter from Pine Swamp near Warwick, Chester County, several years ago, and became quite well acquainted with people of the neighborhood.  The following children survive:  Mrs. Charles Care, Union township; Mrs Sallie Hughes, this borough; Mrs Mahlon Jeffries, Pottstown; Godfrey, of town, and William, Ohio.  Funeral from the residence of Charles Care, Union township.  Saturday, Sept. 23 at 12 o'clock (standard time), with further services in Pine Swamp Church at 1:30 p.m. (standard time) and interment in the Pine Swamp Church cemetery.  Funeral directors A.E. Mauger & Son, of town, have charge.

MILLER -- Near Birdsboro, on the 19th inst., SARAH (nee Slipp) MILLER aged 88 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of Charles Care, near Birdsboro, on Saturday, Sept 23.  Meet at the house at 12 o'clock noon (standard time).  Further services in Pine Swamp Church at 1:20 o'clock p.m. (standard time).  Interment in Pine Swamp Church Cemetery.

THEODORE MILLER
 
  Relatives here were informed of the death of Theodore Miller, 70, in Woodvale, Allegheny county.  Surviving are two sisters and one brother:  Mrs. Thomas Tarpey, this city; Mrs. Joseph Loomis, Spring City, and Morris Miller, St. Peter's Chester County.
  Funeral Friday at 1:30 p.m.  Services at the F.F. Seidel, Inc., funeral parlors, the Rev. Frank W. Scott officiating.  Interment in Pine Swamp cemetery.

Death of William T Miller
  William T Miller died at the residence of his son-in-law, Charles Care, on the river road, near Birdsboro, aged 77 years, after having been ill for 10 days.  During the past three years he had his home with Mr. Care, doing light work about the place.  Though not in the best of health, it was not expected that his death was so near at hand.  His widow survives and these children:  Mrs. Charles Care, Union; Godfrey, Hopewell; Mr. Horace Hughes, Pine Swamp, and William, Illinois.  The funeral will be held from Charles Care's residence on Monday morning, Sept 26, at 9 o'clock.  Services at Pine Swamp United Evangelical church, of which he was a member, by Rev. William Scheiffley, of Shenandoah.  A. E. Mauger & Son, undertakers.

Funeral of William T Miller
  The funeral of William T. Miller was held from the residence of his son-in-law, Charles Care, this morning, and was attended by a large number of his relatives.  The remains were dressed in a black suit and lay in a handsome black broadcloth-covered silver-mounted casket, having silver extension bar handles, and upon the lid a heavy silver plate bearing the word "Father."  The body was taken to Pine Swamp United Evangelical church where a large number of acquaintances and former neighbors of the deceased were assembled, and regular services were held and a sermon was preached by Rev. William Scheiffley, of Shenandoah, a former pastor.  The interment was made in the adjoining graveyard.  The bearers were the following grandsons:  Warren Hughes, Charles Miller, Ralph Amole, Atwood Lacey, Vernon Sheeler and Hunter Matthews.  The arrangements were in charge of Funeral Directors A.E. Mauger & Son.

ALLISON -- On the 27th inst., M. EFFIE (nee Wamsher), widow of Robert J Allison, aged 83 years.
  Services from Shalkop Funeral Home, 433 E. First St. Birdsboro, Saturday at 10:15 a.m.  Further services in Pine Swamp E.C. Church at 11.  Interment in adjoining cemetery.  Friends may call at the Funeral Home Friday evening.

Mrs. M. Effie Allison
 
Birdsboro, June 28 -- Mrs. M. Effie Allison, 83, formerly of Moncacy, died yesterday in her home at 1150 S. Wilton St., Philadelphia.
  A daughter of the late Henry and Hannah M. (Kelly) Wamsher, Mrs. Allison was a member of First Presbyterian Church, Philadelphia.
  Her first husband, Joseph S. Miller, died in 1900, and her second husband, Robert J Allison, died in 1930.
  Mrs. Allison is survived by two sons, Paschel J. Miller, at home and Robert J Allison, South Gate, Calif.
  Also, two daughters: Mabel B. And Elsie J Miller, both at home, and one grandson.
  Services will be held Saturday at 10:45 a.m. In the Shalkop Funeral Home here with further services scheduled at 11 a.m. In Pine Swamp Evangelical Congregational Church.
  The Rev. John H Bixler will officiate at the rites, to be followed by burial in the adjoining cemetery.

MRS. MARY EMMA DAMPMAN, 69, wife of Albert Dampman lifelong resident of Warwick township;  was found dead in bed at her home at FALLS OF FRENCH CHURCH yesterday morning.  Mrs. Dampman had been in failing health the last four years.
  She was born in Warwick township, daughter of the late Cyrus and Hannah (Houck) Murray, and was a member of Mr. Carmel Methodist Church.
  Surviving besides her husband are two children, Viola, widow of Clyde W. Swinehart, Warwick; and Elmer Dampman, St. Peters;  a sister, Kathryn, wife of Christ Orrs, and a brother, Lewis Murray, Star Route, Pottstown.
  The funeral service will be held Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock in Mt Carmel Methodist church, with burial in Knauertown Reformed Cemetery.

Mrs. Milligan Dies in City
 
  Mrs. Hattie Milligan, 59, died at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Mary Seymour, 558 Arch street, at noon Wednesday after an illness of a month.
  Mrs. Milligan, widow of T.M. Milligan, was born in Washington county, Ga., the daughter of William J. Smith and Mrs. Eliza Allen Smith and had made her home with her daughter in Macon for six years.  She was a member of the Baptist Church.
  Surviving are seven daughters, Mrs. Seymour and Mrs. D.G. Pritchett of Macon; Mrs. Mabel Robinson, Davisboro; Mrs. Sara Loubach, Waycross; Mrs. Bessie Sharp, Fitzgerald; Mrs. Maggie Markell, Atlanta; Mrs. Daisy Butts, Milledgeville; two sons, F.L. Sheppard, Davisboro, and W.Y. Milligan, Sparta.
  The body will be taken to the home of her daughter, Mrs. Robinson at Davisboro, this morning and from there to the Baptist church at Riddleville for funeral services at 3 p.m. Friday.  The Rev. Joe Branch will officiate and burial will be in the Riddleville Cemetery.

MILMORE -- In Schenectady, N.Y., on the 6th inst., EDITH FLORENCE (nee Savage), widow of Thomas G. Milmore.
  Services from the Henninger Funeral Home, 239 North Fifth St., Saturday at 2:30 p.m.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Friends may call Friday evening.

MRS. EDITH MILMORE
 
  Mrs. Edith Florence Milmore, wife of the late Thomas F. Milmore, of 51 Saratoga road, died Monday in Parkwood Convalescent home after a long illness.  Rev. Anthony Van Westenburg, pastor of the First Reformed church, Scotia, will conduct the funeral service at Baxter's Funeral home tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.  Interment will be in Reading, Pa.
  Mrs. Milmore was born in Reading, Pa.  And came to this city about 40 years ago.  The survivors are two sons, Merritt A. and Harold F. Of Schenectady; one nephew, Leo L Frees of Schenectady and two sisters, Mrs. Clara Bechtel and Mrs. Sally Miller of Reading, Pa.

MILMORE-SAVAGE
 
  Thomas G., son of Daniel Millmore, [] North 11th, and E. Florence, daughter of Enoch E. Savage, 1017 Douglass Avenue, married Tuesday evening by Rev. Dr. Horn at his parsonage.  The bride was [] in a white Persian lawn, trimmed with lace and satin ribbons and carried a bouquet of bridal roses.  Immediately after the ceremony a reception was held at the home of the bride to the immediate families and dear relatives.  Many gifts were received.  The couple will reside with the parents of the bride for the present.  The groom is employed at Nolde & Horsts's stocking factory.

MILMORE -- In this city, on the 9th inst., THOMAS G. MILLMORE, aged 24 years.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also Reading Tent, No 426, Knights of Macabees, and employees of Nolde & Horst Company's hosery factory, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 836 Mulberry st., this city, on Wednesday afternoon.  Feb 14, at 2 o'clock.  Services in the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

THOMAS G. MILLMORE.
 
  The funeral of Thomas G. Millmore, aged 24 years, took place from his residence, 836 Mulberry, at 2 p.m. today.  Rev. Dr. E.T. Horn conducted services.  The remains lay in a cedar casket with oxidized extension bar handles, oxidized trimmings and plate bearing name and age of deceased and date of death.  They were attired in a black suit with patent leather slippers.  The bearers were fellow employees from the plant of Nolde & Horst where Mr. Millmore was employed.  The tributes included the following; Pillow on pedestal, brother Harry; wreath, parents; spray of carnations, brother; George: spray of pink hyacinths, Aunt Kate and Cousin Katie, spray of lilies, Katie Shank; spray of white carnations, sister Ida and husband; broken hear, surmounted by dove, sister Bertha and Gertrude, spray of lilies of the valley and tulips, sister Clara and husband; spray of hyacinths, Mr. And Mrs. Cunningham; spray of carnations, Mayme Leiking; spray of pink carnations, Mr. And Mrs. R. Staab; Spray of carnations, Mr. And Mrs. W.A. Romberger and family; spray of roses, Mr. and Mrs. Moyer; star on pedestal, Mr. And Mrs. Bechtel and family; wreath, Mr. And Mrs. Savage; wreath of violets, Mr. And Mrs. Joseph Wilson; clock shop hand, Nolde & Horst hosiery mill; pillow, widow spray of violets, children circle K.O.T.M. Wheel.  Camp Somoskos; spray of carnations, Mr. And Mrs. Kissinger; spray of carnations.  Mr. And Mrs. Leeds, spray of lilies, Miss Mengel.
  A delegation of the members of Reading Tent, Knights of Maccabees attended.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Funeral director, F.F. Seidel.

Thomas G. Milmore
 
died of typhoid fever aged 24 years, at 11:30 p.m. Friday, at his residence, 836 Mulberry after an illness of four weeks.  He was a presser at the plant of Nolde & Horst before his illness.  Besides his widow, E. Florence (nee Savage), three children remain.  Merritt, Harold, and Paul and these brothers and sisters: George, Harry, Gertrude, Ida, wife of Harry Haines, Bertha, wife of Wm. Eddinger, this city, and Clara, wife of Herbert Baker, Allentown.  Deceased was a member of Trinity Lutheran Church and Reading Tent No 426 Knights of the Maccabees.  Mr Millmore was a well-known local baseball player and for a time was on the P. & R. Team of the City League.  He caught for several years for the Robeson and Windsor clubs.  He was popular among a wide circle of friends.

MOCK -- At Kline's Corner, between Topton and Maxatawny, on the 13th inst., DAVID MOCK, aged 83 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from his late residence, Schweyer's Hotel.  On Wednesday at 10 a.m.  All services at the house.  Interment at Zion's Church Maxatawny.

DAVID MOCK
 
  Topton, June 14 (Special). -- David Mock, aged 83 years, a veteran of the Civil War, died of infirmities at Schwoyer's Hotel.  A.H. Schwoyer, proprietor, at Klines Corner.  Deceased was a native of Birdsboro and resided with Mr. Schwoyer for about 60 years.  Funeral on Wednesday, June 18, at 10.  All services at the house.  Rev. George B. Smith will officiate.  Interment at Zion's Church, Maxatawny.  Undertaker Schofer has charge.

John Mock, an old and well known resident of Birdsboro, died yesterday morning, after a short illness.  Deceased had been an efficient employee of the E & G Brooke iron company for over thirty years in the blast furnace department and at the time of his death was chief engineer of machinery at No. 2 furnace.  He leaves a widow and six children.

MOCK -- In Birdsboro, on the 26th inst., John Mock, aged 57 years, 4 months and 7 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also members of the I.O.O.F and masonic lodges, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from his late residence in Birdsboro on Saturday morning at 10:30 o'clock.  Services at M. E. Church.  Interment at Michael's cemetery.

MOCK -- On August 14, at Birdsboro, MRS. MARY A. MOCK, widow of the late John Mock.
  The relatives and friends are respectively invited to attend her funeral, without further notice, from her late residence at Birdsboro, Pa., on Wednesday, August 18, 1897.  Services at the house only, at 11 a.m.  Interment at St. Michael's cemetery.

The funeral of Mrs. Mary Mock took place from her late residence on Main st. and largely attended.  Services were held at the house by Rev. William Powick, of Manayunk, assisted by Rev. J.B. Gracy, of Spring City.  The remains were attired in a black dress and lay in a black covered, silver mounted casket.  It had silver extension handles, was trimmed with rope moulding and a silver place inscribed "Mother," was on the lid.  The pall-bearer were:  John I. Reeser, John Deeds, J. M. Prutzman, John Boyer, Henry Meyers and Jacob Cramp.  Interment was made at St. Michael's cemetery and the arrangements were in charge of Fuenral Directors Raymond Mohr & Son.

The funeral of Mrs. John Mock, who died suddenly on Saturday afternoon, will take place from her late residence on Main street on Wednesday morning at 11 o'clock.  Services will be held at the house only and the interment will take place at St. Michael's cemetery.  Funeral Directors Raymond Mohr & Son will have the arrangements in charge.

Birdsboro:  Mrs. John Mock fell dead at her residence on Main street, Saturday afternoon, the result of heart disease.  She was 65 years old.  Her husband died 12 years ago.  She was a sister of Mrs. Clement Squibb, of Birdsboro, and William Huston, contractor, Phila.  Howard and William, of Brooklyn, N.Y.; George, John, and Mrs. Elmer Shaneman, of Birdsboro, are children.

MORRISON, -- In this city, on the 14th inst., Clara Morrison, born Jefferies, wife of Ithamar S. Morrison, aged 36 years, 3 months, and 4 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Saturday, at 1 o'clock sharp, from the residence of her husband, 934 Greenwich St.  Services at the Otterbein U.B. church.  Interment at Charles Evans cemetery.

Clara, wife of Ithamar S. Morrison, 934 Greenwich St., died of a lung affection at 11:10, Tuesday evening after an illness of over a year.  She grew rapidly worse since last December, but was confined to her room only a week.  She was in her 26th year and resided in Reading all her life.  Deceased was well known and highly respected throughout the neighborhood.  Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Jefferies survive together with her husband and 5 children: Edgar S, Charles H., Sallie E., Margaret D., Ithamar.  Laura H. and Mary E. Jefferies are sisters.  Mrs. Morrison was a leading member of the Otterbein U.B. church.

Rev. C. E. Morrison
 
  The Rev. C. E. Morrison, retired pastor of Evangelical Congregational Churches in the Lebanon County area for a number of years, died Saturday morning en route to the Harrisburg Hospital.  The Rev. Mr. Morrison was being transported by ambulance following a heart attack at his Gratz, Pa., residence.
  He was a member of the Evangelical Congregational Church in Gratz.
  His wife, the former Mary Wagenbach Troup, preceded him in death seven months ago.
  He is survived by one son, the Rev. Early Troup of Mt. Joy; five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, and a number of nieces and nephews.

EDGAR S. MORRISON.
 
Edgar S. Morrison, Reading Railway conductor, died of a complication at 1:50 a.m. today at his home, 305 West Douglass street, after observing his 46th birthday anniversary on Thursday, Jan 12.  He had been ill 14 weeks.
  Mr. Morrison was born in this city, where he had lived the greater part of his life.  He was a son of Ithamar and the late Clara (nee Jeffries) Morrison.  He was employed by the Reading Railway Co. for years as a conductor on a local freight running between Reading and Wilmington.  He was well known in railroad circles, having been treasurer of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen and a member of the P.&R. Relief Association.  He was a member of St. Paul's United Evangelical Church, the Knights of Malta, Knights of the Golden Eagle, Odd Fellows and local lodge of Mechanics.
  In addition to his father, he leaves his widow, Minnie T. (nee Werner) Morrison; a daughter, Viola I., wife of Norman R Lachman; a grandson, Norman Jr; two brothers, Charles and Clyde, and two sisters, Sallie wife of Fred Rettgers, and Margaret, wife of Carl Stanley, all of this city.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 23d inst., EDGAR S. MORRISON, aged 40 years, 2 months and 11 days.
  Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 305 West Douglass St., Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment private in Charles Evans cemetery.

Mrs. Elizabeth Morrison
widow of John Morrison, died at the home of her daughter, Miss Mary C. Morrison, 421 Buttonwood, on Friday, of a complication of diseases, aged 84 years.  She was a member of the Memorial United Brethren in Christ Church.  She is survived by a brother, George J Smith, of Sweet Springs, Missouri, and these children;  Samuel E. Morrison, Columbia, Pa; Ithamer S., George J., Mary C, and Mrs A Stephan, all of Reading.

MORRISON - In this city, on the 27th inst., ELIZABETH, widow of John Morrison, aged 84 years, 9 months and 7 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 421 Buttonwood St., on Tuesday afternoon at 1:30.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

Mrs. Clyde E. Morrison
 
  Cleona, Sept. 23 -- Florence V. (Nonamaker), wife of Rev. Clyde E. Morrison, died of complications after an illness of 10 months, at her home, 111 North Center avenue, this place.  She was 48 years of age.
  An active church worker, she was a member of the Steelstown Evangelical Congregational Church and Sunday school, the Women's Missionary Society of the congregation, the W.C.T.U., and was also active in the Bunker Hill and Union Salem Church.
   Surviving, besides her husband, are two brothers, Frank Nonamaker, Pottstown, and Ralph, Reading; and one sister, Mrs. Laura Lord, Reading.
  Funeral on Saturday at 1 p.m., from the Rohland Funeral Parlor, Lebanon.  Services in the Steelstown Evangelical Congregational Church at 2 p.m.  Interment in the adjoining cemetery.

George J Morrison
 
Shillington, Dec 2 -- George J. Morrison, 76, 30 Chestnut street, this borough, died in the Homeopathic Hospital, Reading.  Morrison was employed by the Reading Company since 1935 and previous to that was a letter carrier in Reading.  He was a member of the Orioles' Lodge and of the Knights of Golden Eagle.
  Surviving are his widow, Henrietta (Naugle), one son, George F., one daughter, Helen E., and one granddaughter.
  Funeral services will be held in the Miller Funeral Home on Monday at 2 p.m.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 1st inst., GEORGE J. MORRISON, aged 76 years, 10 months, and 3 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, from the Miller Funeral Home, 48 N. 4th St., Monday afternoon, 2 o'clock.  Interment in Womelsdorf cemetery.  Friends may call at the Funeral Home Sunday evening.

Mrs. Henrietta Morrison
 
  Mrs. Henrietta (Nagle) Morrison, 78, widow of George J. Morrison, [] Chestnut St., Shillington, died this morning in Community General Hospital.  She was a daughter of the late Benjamin F. and Sarah A. (Stahl) Nagle, and was a member of Grace Lutheran Church, Shillington.
  Her husband died nine years ago.  Surviving are two children, Helen E. and George F. Morrison, at home; one grandchild, Henrietta E. Morrison; one brother, George W. Nagle, Shillington.
  Funeral Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock from the Kindt Memorial Home in Shillington.  The Rev. Victor A Kroninger will officiate.  Interment in Fairview Cemetery, Shillington.

MORRISON -- On the 24 inst., HENRIETTA MORRISON, 30 Chestnut St., Shillington, aged 78 years.
  Services from the Kindt Memorial Home, Friday, 2 p.m.  Interment in Shillington Cemetery.  Friends may call at the Memorial Home, Thursday evening, 7 to 9.

ON RAILWAY 51 YEARS
 
I.S. MORRISON, READING LINE VETERAN, DIES IN HOSPITAL
 
Ithamar Sylvester Morrison, who for many years was employed in various capacities on the Reading Railway, died of a complication of diseases at 6:30 Saturday evening at the Homeopathic Hospital. Deceased was 67 years old and resided at 541 Rose Street. He had been in ill health a year, but was confined to the hospital only a short period. Deceased was a native of Springvale, Lancaster County. He spent the greater part of his life in this locality and worked 51 years for the railway company. He was last employed as a brakeman on the main division. Mr. Morrison was a member of the Evangelical church. he was a member of Mystic Star Commandery, No 47, Knights of Malta; Mt Penn Castle, Knights of Golden Eagle, and the P. & R. Veterans' Association. Deceased leaves his widow Chrissie M. (Young), at home; eight children, and one brother and one sister, all of Reading. Undertaker Seidel too charge of the remains.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 5th inst., ITHAMAR S MORRISON, aged 67 years, 3 months and 22 days.
  Relatives and friends and all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 841 Rowe Street.  Wednesday at 11 a.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

John Morrison
 
died unexpectedly at 1:30 a.m., at his home, 421 Buttonwood, aged 79 years, 8 months, and 22 days.  On Thursday Mr. Morrison seemed to be in his usual health, although he complained for some time with pains in the region of the heart.  Deceased was born in Georgetown, Lancaster county, and when young learned the cabinet-making trade.  Sever years later he removed to Lancaster where he engaged in the undertaking business, which he conducted for a long time.  Some 16 ago he removed to Reading, and since that time has been a collector for the German-American Ins. Co, of New York.  Mr Morrison was a member of the Evangelical church, and for several years visited a number of towns in Lancaster, having received a license to preach.  He leaves a widow Elizabeth, and these children:  William M., Samuel M., John F., and Mary C. Morrison, Ithamar S. Morrison, Rachel wife of Aug. Stephan, and George J. Morrison, the latter a letter-carrier of this city.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 28th inst., JOHN MORRISON, aged 79 years, 8 months and 6 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from his late residence, 421 Buttonwood street, on Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 22d inst., John F. Morrison, aged 52 years, 11 months, and 13 days.
  Funeral from the residence of his father-in-law, Albert Leinbach, 415 North Fifth street, on Satuday morning at 10 o'clock.  Interment private in Charles Evans Cemetery.

JOHN F. MORRISON
 
  John F. Morrison died Wednesday at the Homeopathic Hospital of an abcess, aged 52 years, 11 months, 13 days.  He resided at 419 Buttonwood street.  Deceased was ill since March and was bedfast two weeks.  He was born in Lancaster county and came to Reading many years ago.  He was a painter at the P.&R. shops 30 years.  His wife Sallie (nee Leinbach) and these children survive:  Elizabeth, William, Wrightsville; Samuel, Columbia; Ithama, Mrs. Augustus Steven, Mary and George J., of Reading.  The remains were removed to the home of his father-in-law, Albert Leinbach, 415 North 5th street.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 27th inst., MARY C MORRISON, aged 53 years, 7 months and 15 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 421 Buttonwood St., on Friday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment at Charles Evans Cemetery.

MARY C. MORRISON
 
  Mary C. Morrison died shortly after 6 o'clock Monday evening of a complication of diseases at her home.  421 Buttonwood street, aged 52 years, 7 months and 15 days.  She was a member of the Evangelical church and is survived by the following sister and brothers;  Mrs. Rebecca Stephen, Ithamon S. and George J., of this city, and Samuel Morrison, of Columbia.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Mrs. C.E. Morrison, 77, Dies in Gratz Residence
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Mrs. C.E. Morrison, 77, Dies in Gratz Residence
 
  Mrs. Mary E. Morrison, 77, Gratz, wife of the Rev. C.E. Morrison, died at her home early Wednesday morning.
  She was a member of the Simeon Evangelical Congregational Church of Gratz.
  In addition to her husband, she is survived by one son, the Rev. Earl A Troops, Mount Joy; five grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

MORRISON -- In Gratz, on Feb. 26, 1969, Mrs. Mary E Wagenbach Morrison, wife of Rev. C.E. Morrison, aged 77 years.
Funeral on Tuesday morning at 10 A.M. From Simeon Evangenlical Congregational Church, Gratz with Rev. C.M. Bean and Rev. H. D. Wittmaier officiating.  Interment at East Harrisburg Cemetery.  Relatives and friends are invited to attend without further notice.  Friends may call Monday evening 7 to 9 at the church.

MRS. MINNIE T. MORRISON
 
  Minnie T. (Werner), widow of Edgar S. Morrison, died at 4:10 a.m. Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital following an operation.  She was admitted from her home, 305 West Douglass street.  She was 58 years of age and a member of St. Mark's Lutheran Church, Birdsboro.  There remain one daughter, Viola, wife of Norman R. Lachman, this city; her mother, Mrs Henrietta Werner, of Birdsboro; three sisters, Edna and Lilian, Birdsboro; Elsie, wife of George Miller, Reading; two brothers, Thomas and Werten Werner, Birdsboro, and one grandson.  Norman R. Lachamn, jr.  Funeral Director, Henninger.

MORRISON -- In this city, on the 4th inst., MINNIE T., widow of Edgar S. Morrison, aged 52 years, 2 months, and 22 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice from her late residence, 305 West Douglass street.  Tuesday, at 1:30 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment, private.  Friends may call Monday evening.

MORRISON -- In Wyomissing, on the 17th inst., Sallie E. (nee Leinbach), widow of John S. Morrison, aged 59 years, 1 month, 28 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from F.F. Seidel's Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., Thursday at 3:30.  Interment Charles Evans Cemetery.
MRS. SALLIE E. MORRISON, 60, died at her home, 120 Park road, Wyomissing.

Morrisson
 
  Cecelia N. Morrisson, 82, of 105 W. Oley St., died Thursday morning in the Arlington (Va.) Hospital, where she had been a patient since May 21.
  She was the widow of Francis B. Morrisson, who died Jan. 24.
  Born in Mellonsville, Luzerne County, she was a daughter of the late Stephen and Mary (Baranko) Natafalusy.
  She had been employed for 25 years as a registered nurse in Community General Hospital, retiring in 1969.
  A member of Calvary United Church of Christ, she was a 1928 graduate of the former Homeopathic Hospital School of Nursing, now Community General Hospital.
  Surviving are a son, Frank D., Gainesville, Va., and two grand-children and a sister, Carolyn, widow of William Skuba, Hazleton.
  The Bean Funeral Home Inc., Reading, is in charge of arrangements.

MORRISSON -- On the 4th inst., CECELIA N. (nee Natafalusy) widow of, Francis B. Morrisson, of 105 W. Oley St., age 82 years.
  Services from Bean Funeral Home, N. 16th & Rockland Sts., Hampden Heights, Saturday 2 p.m.  Interment in, Pleasant View Cemetery.

MORRISON - In this city, on the 7th inst., CHARLES MORRISON, residence P. & R. Y. M. C. A., aged 57 years, 6 months and 10 days. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from F.F. Seidel's Funeral Chapel, 117 N. 5th St. Monday at 11 a.m. Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery. Friends may call at the Funeral Home Sunday evening.

CHARLES MORRISON
 
Charles Morrison, a resident of the Reading Company Y.M.C.A., died this morning in the Homeopathic Hospital, aged 58 years. His mother, in Philadelphia, is the only survivor. The body was removed to the F.F. Seidel, Inc. funeral chapel.

Clarence, a one-year-old son of J.S. Morrison, 623 Moss Street, was interred at Charles Evans Cemetery today.  Rev. F. K. Huntzinger conducted the funeral services at the house.  Henninger & Son, undertakers, had charge.

MORRISSON -- In this city, Sept. 5th, of scarlet fever, Clarence Wilfert, infant son of I.S. and Clara Morrisson, aged 1 year and 4 months.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Monday afternoon at 2 o'clock from the parents' residence, 623 Moss Street.  Services at the house.  Interment at Charles Evans Cemetery.

Former Area Pastor Dies in Dauphin
 
  The Rev. C. E. Morrison, 81, of Gratz, Dauphin County, a former Evangelical Congregational pastor at Oley and Temple, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack en route to the Harrisburg Hospital.
  Born in Reading, the Rev. Mr. Morrison was preceded in death by his wife, the former Mary Wagenback Troup, seven months ago.
  Retiring eight years ago, he was a member of Simeons Evangelical Congregational Church, Gratz.
  Surviving are a son, the Rev. Earl Troup, pastor of the Evangelical Congregational Church in Mount Joy; five grandchildren; two great-grandchildren and several nieces and nephews.
  Services will be held Friday at 10 a.m. from Simeons E.C. Church, Gratz, the Rev. Charles M. Bean and the Rev. H. D. Wittmaier officiating.  Burial will be made in Steelstown Cemetery, Steelstown, Lebanon County.

Elizabeth M. Morrison
 
  Services for Elizabeth M. Morrison, 81, Eisenhower Apartments 835 Franklin st. Will be private at the convenience of the family.
  The Rev. John Croneberger will officiate in the Francis F Seidel, Inc., Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in Charles Evans Cemetery.
  She died Monday afternoon in the community General Hospital, where she had been a patient since Oct. 23.
  Born in Reading, a daughter of Ithamar and Chrissie M. (Young) Morrison, she had been employed as a saleslady by Strawbridge and Clothier, Philadelphia, before retiring in 1960.
  She was a member of St. Mary's Episcopal Church.
  She is survived by a sister, Madeline M., widow of Frank Saurman, Vero Beach, Fla.
  Two brothers: Sylvester W. Morrison and Francis B. Morrison, both of Reading.

MORRISSON -- On the 22nd inst., ELIZABETH M. MORRISSON, age 81 yrs.
  Services & interment strictly private at the convenience of the family.  No viewing.

MORRISSON -- On the 19th inst., EMMA K. (nee Immendorf) wife of Sylvester W. Morrisson of 825 Church Street, age 78 years.
  Services from Theo. C. Auman Inc., 247 Penn Street, Wednesday at 1 p.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening 7 to 9 p.m. O.E.S. Chapter #390 will conduct services Tuesday 7:30 p.m.

Former official of club dies
 
  A former official of the Order of the Eastern Star, Emma Katherine Morrisson, died Monday morning at 4:14 in Reading Hospital, where she had been a patient since Nov. 23.
  Mrs. Morrisson, 78, of 825 Church St., was a past matron of Golden Rule Chapter 390, Order of the Eastern Star, and a past president of the Matron's Club of District 15B of the Order of Eastern Star.
  The wife of Sylvester W. Morrisson, she was a past president of Auxiliary 32, Tall Cedars of Lebanon, and past mother advisor of the Reading Order of Rainbow.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late John C. And Elsie (Kuhlman) Immendorf.
  She had been employed as a travel consultant by the Reading-Berks Automobile Club, Wyomissing, retiring in 1970.
  In addition to her husband, she is survived by two daughters: Elaine M., widow of Elbert Bethel, Ashland, Mass., and Joan E., wife of Raymond J. Shugar, Laureldale.
  Also a son, John C. Of Chatham, N.J., and six grandchildren.
  Theo. C. Auman Inc. Is in charge of arrangements.

MORRISSON -- On the 24th inst. FRANCIS B. "Frank" husband of Cecelia (nee Natafalusy) Morrisson of 105 W. Oley St., age 79 years.
  Services from Bean Funeral Home, N. 16th & Rockland Sts., Hampden Heights, Tuesday at 1 p.m.  Interment in Pleasant View Cemetery.  No viewing.

Morrisson
 
  Francis B. Morrisson, 79, of 105 W. Oley St. Died Saturday at 6:$5 a.m. In St. Joseph Hospital, where he had been a patient since Jan. 3.
  Born in Reading, he was a son of the late Ithamar and Chrissy Mae (Young) Morrisson.
  He was the husband of Cecelia (Natafalusy) Morrisson.
  He was employed as a salesman by Wetherhold & Metzger Shoes for 50 years until his retirement in 1970.
  He was a member of Calvary United Church of Christ.
  In addition to his wife, he is survived by one son, Frank D. Morrisson, of Gainesville, Va., and two grandchildren.
  Also a brother, Sylvester Morrisson, Reading.
  Bean Funeral Home Inc., Reading, is in charge of arrangements.

Samuel M. Morrison, aged 67 years, died at his home, on Walnut street, on Friday morning last.  He is survived by his wife and two daughters.  The deceased served in the 195th P.V. During the Civil War.  At the time of his death he was a member of the "Artisans" and the Trinity Reformed Church.  The funeral took place on Monday, with interment in Mt. Bethel.

Sylvester W. Morrisson
 
  Sylvester W. Morrisson, 85, formerly of 825 Church St., died Monday at 3:55 a.m. In the Leader Nursing & Rehabilitation Center, West Reading, where he had resided since May 25.
  His wife, Emma K. (Immendorf) Morrisson, died December 19, 1983.
  Born in Reading, he was a son of the late Ithamer S. And Chrissie Mae (Young) Morrisson.
  Morrisson had been employed by the Reading Company as a machinist for 43 years, retiring in January 1964.
  He was a member of Holy Spirit Lutheran Church.
  A past steward of St. John's Lodge 435, F&AM, and the Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite, Valley of Reading, he was also a past Grand Tall Cedar of Neversink Forest 32, Tall Cedars of Lebanon.
  He is survived by a son, John C., Herndon, Va.; and two daughters, Elaine M., widow of Elbert Bethel, Ashland, Mass., and Joan E., wife of Raymond J. Shugar, Laureldale.
  There are also six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.
  Theo C. Auman Inc. Is in charge of arrangements.

MORRISSON -- On the 30th inst., SYLVESTER W., widower of Emma K. (nee Immendorf) Morrisson, of 825 Church St., age 85 years.
  Services from Theo. C. Auman Inc, Funeral Directors, 24 Penn St.  Thursday 1 p.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Wednesday 7 to 9 p.m. St. John's Lodge #435 F&AM will conduct services Wednesday 8 p.m.
MORRISON -- On Oct. 6, 1904 at Philadelphia, William Matthew Morrison, aged 58 years.

Jacob Nichols, who died at Phoenixville, in his 86th year, had 8 children, all of whom and his aged wife survive, as follows:  Elias C. Nichols, Mrs. Eliza, wife of Jacob B Hartenstine, both of Pottstown; Lewis Nichols, of Phoenixville; Samuel Nichols, of the far west; Isaac Nichols, of Port Kennedy; J. Dinggie Nichols, Moris Nichols, and Mrs Mary, wife of David M. Cloud, Phila.  There are 13 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.  Three of the grandchildren reside in Pottstown, the wife of John Willauer, police office; Horace Hartenstine, and Miss Bertha Hartenstine.  During the war, 3 of his sons were soldiers, Elias C., Isaac, and Samuel.

Richard M. Nunnery, died suddenly last Thursday night of paralysis.  He was on the streets Thursday morning conversing with his friends.  That evening he was stricken and died in a few minutes.  He was an old confederate soldier who is well known here in this city and country.  He had been in failing health for some time, but his friends did not think that death was so near.  The burial took place at Providence Saturday morning.

OLINGER -- In this city, on the 11th inst., MARY N. (nee Ritz), widow of William Olinger, aged 68 years, 11 months and 23 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family and members of St. Bernhard Lodge No. 16, L. Of G.E., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of her son-in-law, L. Althouse, 136 Bern Street, on Wednesday morning at 9 o'clock at the house.  Services in Faith Lutheran Church, Centre avenue and Bern street.  Interment in Hinnershitz Church cemetery.

Mrs. Mary N. Olinger,
  nee Ritz), widow of William Olinger, aged 68 years, 11 months and 23 days, died of pleuro-pneumonia, Friday, at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. George Wanner, 1744 Madison Avenue, after an illness of five days.  Deceased was a daughter of the late William and Sarah Ritz and was born at Muhlenberg.  She resided in that township until the death of her husband three years ago, when she moved to Reading to take up her residence with her daughter.  These children survive:  Emma, wife of George Wanner; Mary, wife of L. Althouse; grand children, Margarette, wife of Andrew Kramer, Katie, wife of Ervin Seyler, Florence, wife of Calvin Stoudt; William and Maberry Wanner; great-grandchildren.  Emma and Themlio Stoudt; Ervin and Margarette Seyler.  She is also survived by one sister, Helen, wife of E. Savage, New York; and these brothers, Obadiah, George, John and William Ritz.  Mrs. Olinger was a member of the Hinnershitz Lutheran Church, and a charter member of the St. Bernhard Lodge No. 16, L. Of G. E.

William Ohlinger,
 
aged 66 years, who died of a complication of diseases at his home, in Muhlenberg township, on Friday, conducted a fruit and truck farm, supplied a large milk route in Reading and was well-known here.  He was a member of the Hinnershitz Lutheran church.  Besides his widow, Mary Ann, deceased is survived by two daughters, Mrs. George H Wanner, Reading, and Mrs Llewellyn Althouse, at home; five grandchildren, two great-grandchildren; one brother, John; and one sister, Mrs. John Gross.  He belonged to the Knights of Friendship Lodge, No. 23, and P.O.S. Of A. Camp No. 68.

OHLINGER -- In Muhlenberg township, on the 15th inst., WILLIAM OHLINGER, aged 68 years and 2 months.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also members of Knights of Friendship, No. 23, of Reading, and P.O.S. Of A., No 68, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence in Muhlenberg township, on Thursday morning at 9:30 at the house.  Services and interment at Hinnershitz Church.  [?] will meet friends at Bodey's store, N Reading, between 8 and 9 a.m.

REV. J. G. PAGE
 
  RIDDLEVILLE, Oct. 16 -- The Rev. James Gaynor Page, 66, of Riddleville, died Sunday night, Oct. 15, of a sudden heart attack at Wesley, Ga., where he was teaching school.  Funeral services will be held Tuesday at 4 p.m. EWT from the Middleville Baptist church.  The Rev. Joseph W Branch and Rev. A. W. Franklin together with Henry Sammons will officiate.  Interment will follow in Riddleville Cemetery.
  Surviving besides the wife, Mrs. Leah Josey Page of Riddleville, is a daughter, Merrill Page Rapley of Oconee; two sons, J.C. Page Rapley of Oconee, and W. M. Page of Macon.  In addition, one brother and one sister, T.L. Page and Mrs. T. J. Brett, both of Riddleville, survive.  Rev. Page served as a Baptist minister in this part of the state for 30 years, and was also engaged as a teacher in the public schools during that time.

Final Rites Held for Wesley Pastor
 
  DAVISBORO, Ga., Oct 18. -- Funeral services for the Rev. James G. Page, 66, who died after a heart attack at Wesley, Ga., Sunday night, were held at the Riddleville Baptist church, near Davisboro, at 4 o'clock, Tuesday afternoon, with the Rev. Joseph M. Branch, assisted by the Rev. A. W. Franklin and Layman Henry G. Sammons, officiating.
  Burial was in Riddleville cemetery with the Woodmen Lodge members conducting services at the graveside.
  The Rev. Page had been a Baptist minister for 35 years and he had been a teacher in the public schools for 30 years.  At the time of his death, he was pastor of the Baptist church in Wesley and superintendent of the Wesley public school.
  He was born and reared in Washington County.
  Survivors are his widow, Mrs. Leah Josey Page, Riddleville; a daughter, Mrs. Meryll Rapley, Oconee; two sons, J. C. Page, Oconee; and W. M. Page, Macon; a brother, T.L. Page and a sister, Mrs. T. J. Brett, both of Riddleville; two grandchildren and a number of nephews and nieces.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Add to Laura E Yohn Hartenstine Peplau
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
John W. Peplau
 
  Services for John W. Peplau, 78, of 1246 Church St., who died Thursday morning in the Reading Hospital and Medical Center, where he was a patient since Monday, will be held Monday at 1 p.m.
   The Rev. Paul J Hoh will officiate in the John P. Feeney Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in the Charles Evans Cemetery.
  Born in Reading, a son of the late Mr. And Mrs. Adolph Peplau, he was an Army veteran of World War I.
  His wife, Laura E. (Hartenstine) Peplau, died Feb. 2.
  He was a member of St. John's Lutheran Church, Nest No. 2, Fraternal Order of Orioles, Reading; Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, Local 652, and the Brotherhood of Railway and Trainmen Assn.
  Mr. Peplau had been employed as a shop foreman by the Reading Co. Before retiring in 1962.
  Surviving are a stepson, Clarence L. Hartenstine, Reading; five stepgrandchildren and six stepgreat-grandchildren.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Add to Laura E Yohn Hartenstine Peplau
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
John W. Peplau
 
  John W. Peplau, 78, of 1246 Church St., died this morning at 5:10 o'clock in the Reading Hospital and Medical Center, where he had been a patient since Sept. 29.
  The John P. Feeney Funeral Home has charge.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Add to Laura E Yohn Hartenstine Peplau
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
PEPLAU -- On the 2nd inst., JOHN W. PEPLAU, aged 78 years.
  Services from the John P. Feeney Funeral Home, 625 N. 4th St., on Monday at  1 p.m.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Friends may call Sunday eve 7 to 9 p.m.

WILLIE H. PERKINS DIES AT RESIDENCE; RITES TO BE TODAY
