  Willie Houston Perkins, 76-year old retired farmer and filling station operator who lived at 1954 Boulevard avenue, died yesterday morning at 11:30 o'clock at his home after an illness of three weeks.
  Funeral services will be conducted this afternoon at 4 o'clock at Elliott's Funeral Home.  The Rev. E.C. Sheridan will officiate and interment will follow in this Westover Memorial Park.
  Pallbearers will be Dan Bridwell, Police Sgt. James Bishop, B.B. Lite, Bill Boyd, W.M. Turner, and Rena Sawyer.
  Mr. Perkins was born in Jefferson County and had been a resident of Augusta for the past 20 years.
  He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Lizzie Hudson Perkins; three sons, Riley R. Perkins, Harmon P. Perkins, and Philip Perkins, all of Augusta; one daughter, Mrs. Corinne Price, Augusta; eight grand-children; two great-grandchildren; and several nieces and nephews.

Debra Jean Mays Quackenbush
 
WARRENVILLE, SC - Mrs. Debra Jean Mays Quackenbush, 61, wife of fifty-four years to Mr. Bo Quackenbush, entered into rest on Friday, July 15th, 2016.
Born in and a lifelong resident of Aiken County, SC, she was a daughter of the late Robert Eugene "Buck" and Vancie Lavon "Bunny" Moody Mays. She was a homemaker.
Miss Debra was a diehard Gamecock fan and enjoyed making jewelry. More than anything however, she enjoyed watching her granddaughters play softball.
In addition to her husband and parents, family members include her daughters, Wendy Smith and her husband, Jimmy, Warrenville, SC and Stacie Cobb and her husband, James, Graniteville, SC; siblings, Patsy Napier and her husband, Joe, Warrenville, SC and Nancy Storey and her husband, Wilbur Lee, Monetta, SC, grandchildren, Tyler Langley, Taylor Smith, Brandon Cobb, Ashlee Cobb and Maghen Cobb and a great-grandchild, Brayden Peacon.
Friends are welcome to call at the home of Wendy and Jimmy Smith.
In accordance with her wishes, Debra was cremated and a graveside service will be held on Wednesday, July 20th, 2016, at noon in Langley Cemetery, Langley, SC, with Pastor Herb Sons officiating.
Should you desire to do so, memorials may be made to the Susan G. Komen Foundation . (ww5.komen.org) . Please visit HatcherFuneralHome.com to share memories and leave message of condolence for the family.

QUACKBUSH -- Entered into rest Dec 15, 1986, Mr. Stanley S. Quackenbush Sr., husband of Mrs. Eunice Smith Quackenbush of Key Plantation Road, Route 1, Warrenville, S.C.  Funeral services will be held Wednesday, Dec 17, 1986, at 1 p.m. From Posey's Funeral Home Chapel with the Rev. James Rowland Smith officiating.  Burial will be in the Langley Cemetery.  Additional survivors include 10 grandchildren.  The family will receive friends Tuesday evening from 7 to 9 p.m. At the funeral home.  Friends may call at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Shirley Frye. Key Plantation Road, Route 1, Warrenville, or POSEY'S FUNERAL HOME, LANGLEY, S.C.

S. S. Quackenbush Sr.
 
  WARRENVILLE, S.C. -- Stanley S. Quackenbush Sr., 72, of Route 1, Pine Log Road, died Monday at his Residence.
  The funeral will be at 1 p.m. Wednesday at Posey's Funeral Home, Langley, with the Rev. James Rowland Smith officiating.  Burial will be in Langley Cemetery.
  Mr. Quackenbush was a native of Bennington, Vt.   He was a U.S. Army veteran of World War II and a former employee of Bath Mill, a division of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc.
  Survivors include his wife, Eunice Smith Quackenbush; four sons, Adelbert M. Quackenbush, Randy M. Quackenbush, Mark A. Quackenbush  and Stanley S. Quackenbush Jr., all of Warrenville; and three daughters, Mrs. Douglas (Shirley) Frye, Mrs. Larry (Janet) Gregory and Mrs. Gene (Rhetta) Garland, all of Warrenville.
  Pallbearers will be Willis Herndon Jr., Howard Seigler, Jimmy Smith, Barry Smith, Ollie Eubanks and Parks Farrell.
  The family will receive friends at the funeral home from 7 to 9 p.m. Today.
  Friends may call at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Shirley Frye, Key Plantation Road, Route 1, Warrenville, or the funeral home.

Berhenrathet -- am Sonntag Abend, Herr Valentin Reber, von Bern Taunschip, mit der liebensmurdigen Miss Magdalena Vanread, von Cumru.
 
Married - on Sunday evening, Mr. Valentin Reber, of Bern Township, with the lovable Miss Magdalena Van Reed, of Cumru.

Reddick Rites Be Held Today
 
  Funeral services for Ben Reddick will be held Friday morning at 11 o'clock at the grave side in the Willow Creek Baptist church cemetery near Evergreen.  The body will remain at the Waters Funeral home until 10 o'clock this morning.
  Mr. Reddick was known to hundreds of Florentines as "sharpen-em-now Reddick" and for years he was a familiar figure on the streets of Florence pushing a cart decorated with various items of cutlery and sharpening stone.
  Mr. Reddick died Wednesday morning after a long illness.  He was born in Darlington county, November 14, 1870, the son of the late B.M. Reddick and Ida Jeffords Reddick, both also of Darlington county.  For the past 21 years he had been a resident of this city.
  He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Laney Cornell Reddick of Charleston; three daughters; Mrs. Marie Ricks of Scranton, Mrs. Laney Mae Long of Charleston, Mrs Lela Mae Wilson of Jacksonville Fla.; four sons, Manton Reddick of Effingham, Lee Reddick, Willie Reddick, Robert Reddick, all of Charleston; two step-sons; J.B. Frier of Florence county and Joe Frier of Effingham.

Familiar Florence Character Passes
 
  Ben Reddick is dead.  Known to hundreds of Florentines as Sharpen-em-now, Reddick was for years a familiar figure on the streets of Florence pushing a cart decorated with various items of cutlery and sharpening stones.  In recent months his usual rounds have been interrupted by long periods of sickness in the hospital due to the infirmities of his more than eighty years and to a very bad heart.  He has been a patient at the McLeod Infirmary since last May and in that institution this morning, he expired.  Various welfare agencies in the city are arranging for his burial.

Mrs. Carnell Redick
 
  Mrs. Carnell Redick, 77, died at Bruce Hospital at 5:30 p.m. Yesterday, after an illness of three weeks.
  She had lived near Florence all of her life and was a member of the Pentecostal Holiness Church.  She was the widow of the late Ben Redick, and a daughter of the late Willie and Ida Carnell.
  Surviving are three daughters: Mrs. Lella Simpson of Las Vegas, Nev.; Mrs R.M. Hillseman of Charleston; and Mrs. Thad Hicks of Scranton; six sons, J.L., Joe, Friar, Manton, Lee, Robert E., and W.L. Redick; one sister, Mrs. Leatha Dees; two half-brothers, Melvin and Franklin Carnell; and several grandchildren.
  Funeral arrangements will be announced by Walers Funeral Home.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Deaths and Funerals in the Pee Dee
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Mrs. Laney C. Reddick
 
  Funeral services for Mrs. Laney Carnell Reddick, 70, widow of the late Ben T. Reddick, will be conducted at 3 p.m. Wednesday in Willow Creek Pentecostal Holiness Church by the Rev. U.T. Baldwin, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Dallas Hatchell, pastor of St. Paul Pentecostal Holiness Church of Swansea, S.C.
  Burial will follow in the Garden of Memories, formerly the Old Willow Creek Methodist Church Cemetery.
  Serving as active bearers will be J.B. Lamb, C.C. Hatcher, J.C. Morris, Chalmers Hutchinson, Benion Collins, and Theodore Avant.
  Mrs. Reddick died at 5:30 p.m. Sunday in a local hospital after an extended illness.
  She was a life-long citizen of Florence County.  Born June 27, 1884, a daughter of the late Willie and Ida Mae Barnes Carnell, both of Florence County.  She was a member of Willow Creek Pentecostal Holiness Church and Ladies Auxiliary of the church.
  Mrs. Reddick was twice married.  Her first husband was the late Joe Friar.  From this marriage survive two sons, Joe Friar of Effingham and J.L. Friar of Florence County.
  Surviving by her second marriage are three daughters, Mrs. Jack Simpson of Las Vegas, Nev., Mrs. R.M. Hillsman of Charleston and Mrs. Thad Hooks of Scranton:  four sons, Manton Reddick of Effingham, Lee Reddick of Charleston, Robert E. Reddick of Georgetown, and W.L. Reddick of Charleston: one sister, Mrs. Leathea Deas of Charleston and two half brothers, Melvin Carnell of Baltimore, Md. And Franklin Carnell of Greenville; 41 grandchildren and four great grandchildren.
  The body of Mrs. Reddick will remain at the Walters Funeral Home until 11 a.m. Wednesday at which time it will be taken to the church to remain there for the services.

Ethel M. Rettgers
 
  Ethel M. Rettgers, 64, of Fleetwood R.D. 3, died today at 7 a.m. In the Reading Hospital where she was a patient since June 29.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late Frederick H. and Sallie E. (Morrison) Rettgers.  She was a member of Zion's United Church of Christ, this city.
  Surviving are two brothers: Frederick E., Reading; Charles W., Philadelphia; a sister, Mazie H., with whom she resided; two nephews and two nieces.
  Services will be held in the Henninger Funeral Home on Tuesday at 1 p.m., the Rev. Richard G Ott officiating.  Burial will be made in Laureldale Cemetery.

RETTGERS -- On the 19th inst., ETHEL M RETTGERS of Fleetwood R.D. 3, Pa. age 64 years.
  The Rev. Richard G Ott will officiate at services in the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St. Tuesday at 1 p.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening.  7 to 9.

Forrest Rettgers, former national business official
 
Forrest I. Rettgers, a retired Army colonel and former national business official, died Tuesday at 8:10 a.m. In his residence at 1801 Cambridge Ave., Wyomissing.
  Rettgers, 73, was the husband of Virginia M. (Felix) Rettgers.
  He entered the Army as a private in the Pennsylvania National Guard's 213 Coast Artillery when it was federalized in 1940.  Rettgers was commissioned a second lieutenant in December 1941; a first lieutenant in October 1942 and promoted to captain in 1943.
  Rettgers was promoted to lieutenant colonel in March 1953 and retired from the Army as a colonel in 1966 after serving in the office of the Secretary of Defense, in the Army War College and as Senate liaison officer.
  From 1966 to 1972, he was chief of staff for U.S. Sen. Harry F. Byrd Jr. Of Virginia.
  Moving to private industry in 1972, Rettgers became president of Midwestern Industries Inc., Washington.
  He was name executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers from 1975 until 1983.
  Born in Reading, he was a son of the late Ithamar Benedict and Laura Tyson (Hartenstine) Rettgers.
  Rettgers was a former employee in the Reading Times composing room.
  A 1939 graduate of Reading High School, he received his bachelor's degree from the University of Maryland in 1953 and his master's degree in international relations from George Washington University, Washington, D.C.
  Rettgers was a graduate of the West Point Preparatory School, a June 1955 graduate of the Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., and a June 1964 graduate of the Army War College, Carlisle.
  He was a member of the Lincoln Park United Methodist Church.
  Rettgers was an Army veteran of World War II and the Korean War.
  In addition to his wife, he is survived by three daughters:  Bonnie J. Rettgers, Long Beach, Calif.; Robin E., wife of Harry W. Stone III, El Paso, Texas; and Pamela Ann Jones, Fairfax, Va.
  Other survivors include a brother, Robert E., Dillsburg, York County; and two sisters, Miriam, wife of Wilbur Nagle, York, and Joyce, wife of Burtram Bassham, Abingdon, Va.
  There are also three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.
  Memorial services will be Friday at 7:30 p.m. In the Bean Funeral Home, Sinking Spring.  Inurnment will be in the Arlington (Va.) National Cemetery Columbarium.

RETTGERS -- In Florida on the 12th inst., FREDERICK E. Husband of Pearl (nee Leiby) Rettgers of Port St. Lucie, Florida, aged 80 years.
  Service from Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St at the convenience of the family.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  No viewing.

Frederick E. Rettgers
 
  Services for Frederick E. Rettgers, 80, of 11 El Camino Road, Port St. Lucie, Fla., who was dead on arrival Wednesday morning in Fort Pierce Memorial Hospital, Port St. Lucie, will be private.
  The Rev. Charles E. Fair will officiate in the Henninger Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in Laureldale Cemetery.
  Born in Reading, a son of the late Frederick H. and Sallie E. (Morrison) Rettgers, he had been employed by the former Reading Co. as an engineer.
  An Army veteran of World War I, Mr. Rettgers is survived by his wife, Pearl (Leiby) Rettgers, and a daughter, Virginia M., wife of the Rev. David P Heil, Allentown.
  Also two stepsons, Irvin L. Fisher, Muhlenberg Park, and Wilmer Fisher, Cleveland, Ohio, and two grandsons.

RETTGERS -- On the 25th inst., FREDERICK H RETTGERS, aged 71 years.
  Services from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St. On Wednesday at 2 p.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening.

Frederick H. Rettgers
 
  Frederick H. Rettgers, 71, died yesterday in his home, 249 North 11th St.  He was a son of the late John and Henrietta (Jansen) Rettgers.  His wife, Sallie E. (Morrison) preceded him in death.
  He was a member of the Loyal Order of Moose, Spanish War Veterans, Veterans of Foreign Wars, P. And R. Relief Association, Metacomet Home Association, and Company A Fourth Pennsylvania Regiment, Spanish-American War Volunteers.
  Surviving are two sons, Frederick E., of Reading, and Charles W., of Philadelphia; two daughters, Ethel M. and Mazie H., both at home; four grandchildren, one great-grandchild and a sister, Mrs. Mary Schultz, of Reading.  Funeral services will be held Wednesday at 2 p.m. In the Henninger Funeral Home, the Rev. Harry S. Kehm officiating.  Interment will be make in Laureldale Cemetery.

HONEYMOON IN NEW ENGLAND
 
WEDDINGS DURING SEPTEMBER'S CLOSING DAYS
 
  A pretty church wedding was that which took place at 3 o'clock this afternoon in St. Peter's Methodist Church when Rev M. Shelley joined in wedlock Laura F. Hartenstine, a nurse.  17 Oley street, and Ithamar B Rettgers, 24 North Eleventh street.  A number of friends and relatives of the couple witnessed the ceremony which was followed to a reception at the bridegroom's home on North Eleventh street.
  Miss Rhea E Drexel was at the organ.  Prior to the ceremony Miss Florence R Miller, soprano, sang O Promise Me.  During the ceremony Miss Drexel played At Dawning by Cadman.
  Miss Ethel Goldman was the bridesmaid.  The best man was Earl Kraemer.  The bride was charmingly gowned in white georgette and carried a bouquet of white roses.
   The bride is a graduate of the Reading Evening High School also the Reading Hospital Training School class 1920.  The groom is a locomotive fireman for the Reading Railway Co.  The newlyweds will spend their honeymoon visiting points of interest in the New England states.
  Mr. Rettgers holds quite a record as an overseas veteran.  He was sergeant first class of Co. D. 150th Machine Gun Battalion, and saw considerable action in all the major offensives on the French front.  He enlisted in Co. D two weeks after its return from the Mexican border and at which time it was then known as Co. I Fourth Regiment, N.G.P.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Sarah (Marion) Rettgers ins tead of Morrison? Mazie (instead of maisie) Frederick F instead of Frederick H
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Rettgers' Death Attributed to War
 
National Guard Captain Gassed in France
 
  Illness due to World War injuries resulted in the death of Captain Ithamar B. Rettgers, of Battery G, 213th Coast Artillery, of the Pennsylvania National Guard.
  The 39-year-old commander of the local battery died early today in the Reading Hospital from a stomach ailment which physicians traced to a gas attack of which Captain Rettgers was victim during the war.  He had undergone an operation last Thursday.
  Enlisting in the National Guard on the day war was declared, Captain Rettgers carved out a notable army career.  Inducted into the federal service on August 25, 1917, he was assigned to Company A, 149th Machine Gun Battalion of the 42d, or Rainbow Division.  He was made a corporal three months later, and on May 4, 1918, was promoted to sergeant.
 
In Eight Major Battles
 
  As a sergeant, Captain Rettgers took part in eight major battles, becoming the victim of a gas attack in the Meuse-Argonne offensive.  He also served in the battles of Luneville, Baccarat, Esparence, Champagne-Marne, Aisne-Marne and St. Mihiel.
  Captain Rettgers served with the army of occupation in Germany after the armistice.
  Continuing his military activities after his return to this country, Captain Rettgers was commissioned a second lieutenant in the National Guard on February 12, 1920.  He was promoted to the first lieutenant under Captain William J Smith on December 22, 1929, and on January 22, 1931, was commissioned a captain.
  Captain Rettgers was foreman of the stereotype department of the Reading Times.  He was a member of the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
  He was a member of the Windsor Street M.E. Church and a son of the late Frederick F and Sarah (Marion) Rettgers.  Surviving are his widow, Laura T. (Hartenstine), two sons, Forrest and Robert, and two daughters Miriam and Joyce; two brothers, Frederick, this city; Charles, Philadelphia, and two sisters, Ethel and Mazie, this city.
  Funeral Saturday at 2 p.m., from the Henninger Funeral home.  The Rev. Leighton S Palmer officiating.

Rettgers' Death Attributed to War
 
National Guard Captain Gassed in France
 
  Illness due to World War injuries resulted in the death of Captain Ithamar B. Rettgers, of Battery G, 213th Coast Artillery, of the Pennsylvania National Guard.
  The 39-year-old commander of the local battery died early today in the Reading Hospital from a stomach ailment which physicians traced to a gas attack of which Captain Rettgers was victim during the war.  He had undergone an operation last Thursday.
  Enlisting in the National Guard on the day war was declared, Captain Rettgers carved out a notable army career.  Inducted into the federal service on August 25, 1917, he was assigned to Company A, 149th Machine Gun Battalion of the 42d, or Rainbow Division.  He was made a corporal three months later, and on May 4, 1918, was promoted to sergeant.
