  As a sergeant, Captain Rettgers took part in eight major battles, becoming the victim of a gas attack in the Meuse-Argonne offensive.  He also served in the battles of Luneville, Baccarat, Esparence, Champagne-Marne, Aisne-Marne and St. Mihiel.
  Captain Rettgers served with the army of occupation in Germany after the armistice.
  Continuing his military activities after his return to this country, Captain Rettgers was commissioned a second lieutenant in the National Guard on February 12, 1920.  He was promoted to the first lieutenant under Captain William J Smith on December 22, 1929, and on January 22, 1931, was commissioned a captain.
  Captain Rettgers was foreman of the stereotype department of the Reading Times.  He was a member of the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
  He was a member of the Windsor Street M.E. Church and a son of the late Frederick F and Sarah (Marion) Rettgers.  Surviving are his widow, Laura T. (Hartenstine), two sons, Forrest and Robert, and two daughters Miriam and Joyce; two brothers, Frederick, this city; Charles, Philadelphia, and two sisters, Ethel and Mazie, this city.
  Funeral Saturday at 2 p.m., from the Henninger Funeral home.  The Rev. Leighton S Palmer officiating.

RETTGERS -- In this city, on the 24th inst., CAPTAIN ITHAMAR B. RETTGERS, husband of Laura T. (nee Hartenstine) Rettgers, aged 39 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 North Fifth Street, Saturday at 2 p.m.  Friends may call Friday evening at the Funeral Home, 7 to 9.

Military Funeral Held for Rettgers
 
Veteran Groups Attend Service in Body
 
  A military funeral, attended by hundreds of representatives of veteran organizations, relatives and friends, was held this afternoon for Captain Thamar B. Rettgers at the Henninger Funeral home.
  The Rev. Leighten S. Palmer, pastor of Windsor Street M.E. Church of which the late world-war veteran was a member, conducted the rites.
  At the grave in Charles Evans Cemetery, Major Henry W. Prentiss, of Bethlehem, an officer at the Valley Forge Military College, conducted the committal service.
  Officers of the 213th anti-Aircraft Coast Artillery Regiments, headed by Colonel C.J. Smith, Allentown, attended in a body.  The military and veteran organizations met at their respective headquarters and marched to the funeral home.
 
March to Cemetery
 
  First Lieutenant Albert H. Early , of Captain Rettgers' Battery G, and Captain John E Hickman, commander of Battery A, had their entire companies in a uniform and marched to the cemetery as an escort of honor.
  At the grave a squad of Captain Rettgers' men fired a salute.  The squad consisted of Second Lieutenant Kenneth Tarves, in charge; First Sergeant Harry Leinbach, Sergeants Jesse R. Conner, Harry Roland, Harry Feather, Emerson Hoover, Stanley Witzel, Anthony Remba and Earl Wheeler.
  Members of Old Company I, in which Captain Rettgers served in France as a private, corporal, and sergeant through some of the heaviest fighting of the World War, served as active bearers.
  Among the organizations represented were Gregg Post, American Legion; Greater Reading Post, Veterans of Foreign Wars, and the Reading Artillerists.
 
Honorary Bearers
 
The honorary bearers, officers of the Second Battalion were:  Major William J. Smith, First Lieutenant Ralph O. Bowman, Captain David J. Evans, First Lieutenant John r Oatman, Second Lieutenant Carroll E. Stauffer, Captain George T. Tucker, First Lieutenant Phillip H Melching, and Second Lieutenant John W. Feather.
  A guard was placed at the bier from 1 o'clock this afternoon until the funeral, at 2 o'clock.
  Last evening more than 800 persons viewed the body.  During the morning hours, several hundred more pass the bier.
  Captain Rettgers died early Wednesday in the Reading Hospital.

John Rettgers.
 
Rev. F.K. Huntzinger conducted services over the remains of John Rettgers, whose funeral was held from the residence of his brother, Fred E. Rettgers, 1041 Elm Street.  The body was attired in a dark gray suit and rested in a square-cornered solid oak casket, with silver handles, silver trimmings and plate bearing the name and age of deceased.  Interment was made at Charles Evans cemetery.  Undertaker Kern had charge.

John Rettgers
 
  John Rettgers, aged 56, was found dead in the hay loft of the stable of Jacob Reubenstein.  Coroner Norton issued a certificate of death due to natural causes.  Deceased is survived by one brother and one sister.  He was last seen alive at 7 o'clock Wednesday night.

Mrs. Laura T. Rettgers
 
  Services for Mrs. Laura T. Rettgers, 80, formerly of Wyomissing, will be held Wednesday at 11 a.m.
  The Rev. Harold E. Bashore and the Rev. Reeves C. Havens Jr. Will officiate in the Levi Zerr Chapel at the Cornwall Manor, Cornwall.  Burial will be made in the Charles Evans Cemetery.  The Rohland Funeral Home, Lebanon, has charge.
  Mrs Rettgers died Sunday night in her home at Cornwall Manor.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late Jacob and Ida (Miller) Hartenstine.  She was preceded in death by her husband, Ithamar Rettgers.
  Mrs. Rettgers had been employed as a nurse by the Wilson School District for 25 years, before retiring in 1964.
  She was a member of Cornwall United Methodist Church.
  Surviving are two sons, Forest I. Alexandria, Va., and Robert E., Dillsburg; two daughters: Miriam J. Nagle, York and Joyce A. Bassham, Abingdon, Va.
  Thirteen grandchildren, six great-grandchildren; and a sister, Mary Ringler, in Wyomissing Lodge.

RETTGERS -- In Cornwall, on the 18th inst., LAURA T. (nee Hartenstine) widow of Ithamar Rettgers.  Cornwall Manor, formerly of Wyomissing, age 80 yrs.
  Funeral on Wednesday at 11 a.m. from the Levi Zerr Chapel, Cornwall Manor, Cornwall, Pa.  Interment Charles Evans Cemetery, Reading.  Services at 12:30.  Friends may call Wednesday from 10:40 until time of services at the Chapel.  Contributions may be sent to Parkinson Disease Fund, the Heart Assoc., or the Cancer Society.

RETTGERS -- On the 11th inst., MAZIE H RETTGERS, R.D. 3, Fleetwood, age 65 years.
  The Rev. Harvey S. Kehm will officiate at services in the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St., Wednesday, 11 A.M.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening, 7 to 9.

Mazie H. Rettgers
 
  Mazie H. Rettgers, 65 of Fleetwood R.D. 3, died yesterday in the Reading Hospital, where she had been a patient for the past six days.
  She was born in Reading, a daughter of the late Frederick H. and Sallie E. (Morrison) Rettgers.
  She is survived by two brothers, Frederick E., Reading, and Charles W., Philadelphia, and a number of nieces and nephews.
  Arrangements are in charge of the Henninger Funeral Home.

Robert E. Rettgers
 
  Robert E. Rettgers, 90, of Bethany Village, Mechanicsburg, and formerly of Reading, York, and most recently of Dillsburg, passed away Wednesday in the Holy Spirit Hospital, Camp Hill.
  He was born July 28, 1923, in Reading, the son of the late Ithamar B. and Laura T. (Hartenstine) Rettgers.
  Robert is survived by his wife, Marjorie E. (Fett) Rettgers: three daughters, Sharon A. Idema of Williamsburg, BA; Jane A. Carnell of Harrisburg, PA; Barbara K. McFarland of Sandy, UT; on sister, Miriam J Nagle of York.  He also leaves behind seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren.  Robert was preceded in death by one brother, Forrest I Rettgers and one sister, Joyce A. Bassham.
  Robert retired in 1985 from Metropolitan Edison Co. (GPU) after 38 years.  His last position was as a District Manager in Dillsburg.  He graduated in 1941 from Reading High School and from Penn State Extension School in 1954, where he studied Industrial Electricity.  Robert was a member of Masonic Lodge #549 in Reading; Harrisburg Consistory; Dillsburg Lions Club, where he served as past President and Secretary;  Navy League; past Chairman of the Dillsburg Sewer and Water Authority; Monaghan Presbyterian Church, where he served as an Elder; Life Member of the South Mountain V.F.W. Post #6771, Dillsburg; and past President of Metropolitan Edison Employees Assoc.  Robert served his country in the U.S. Navy during W.W. II and served on board the USS Helena, USS Saufley, and the USS Boston.
  Memorial services will be held Tuesday, July 15, 2014, at 1:00 pm in the Monaghan Presbyterian Church, 1185 Gettysburg Pike, Dillsburg, PA.
  Memorial contributions may be made to his church, Monaghan Presbyterian Church, 1185 Gettysburg Pike, Dillsburg, PA 17019 or the Dillsburg Lions Club, P.O. Box 264, Dillsburg, PA 17019.
  An online guestbook can be signed at www.cocklinfuneralhome.com

RETTGERS -- On the 2d inst., SALLIE E. (Morrison), wife of Frederick F. Rettgers aged 63 years.
  Services from the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th St., Tuesday at 1:30 p.m.  Friends may call Monday evening.

RETTGERS - On the 22nd inst., SALLIE E (nee Steffe), wife of Frederick E. Rettgers of 354 Spring St., age 77 years.
  The Rev. David P. Heil will officiate at services in the Henninger Funeral Home, 229 N. 5th Wednesday, 11 a.m.  Interment in Laureldale Cemetery.  Friends may call Tuesday evening, 7 to 9.

Mrs. F. E. Rettgers
 
  Services for Mrs. Sallie E. Rettgers, 77, wife of Frederick E. Rettgers, who died Sunday morning in her residence at 354 Spring St., will be held on Wednesday at 11 a.m.
  The Rev. David P. Heil will officiate in the Henninger Funeral Home.  Burial will be made in Laureldale Cemetery.
  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late James and Sallie E. (Good) Steffe.
  In addition to her husband, she is survived by a daughter, Virginia M., wife of the Rev. David P Heil, Lancaster; two grandsons and a brother, Raymond Steffe, Clear Brook, Va.

Mrs. Frederick F. Rettgers
 
Sallie E. (Morrison), wife of Frederick F. Rettgers of 249 North 11 St., died yesterday in the Reading Hospital, aged 63 years.  Born in Reading, she was a daughter of the late Ithamar and Clara (Jefferies) Morrison, and was a member of the Reformed denomination.
  Surviving besides her husband are two sons, Frederick E., of Reading; and Charles W., of Philadelphia; two daughters, Ethel M. and Mazie H., both at home; four grandchildren, one sister, Margaret, wife of Carrol Stanley, Reading; one brother, the Rev. C.E. Morrison, of Cleona; two step-brothers, Sylvester and Francis, both of Reading; and two step-sisters, Elizabeth and Madeline, both of Jenkintown, near Philadelphia.
  Funeral services will be held Tuesday at 1:30 o'clock from the Henninger Funeral Home with the Rev. R.M. Campbell officiating.

RICHARDS -- On the 29th inst., of dropsy, Elizabeth Richards, wife of Martin Richards, in the 73rd year of her age.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Monday afternoon at 1 o'clock, from the residence of her husband, No. 335 Franklin street, to proceed to the Baptist Church, from thence to Chas. Evans Cemetery.

Martin Richards died yesterday morning at the residence of his son, H. J. Richards, 439 South Sixth street, in the 81st year of his age.  His death was caused by apoplexy.  Deceased was a member of the First Baptist church, and had been janitor of the High School for nearly 25 years.  One son survives.

SAMUEL RICHARDS
 
  Mr. Samuel Richards, who has been a resident of this city for a number of years past, died on Saturday last.  In early life, he was an ore contractor and farmer.  All his life, he enjoyed the best of health and his death was the result of old age.  He was the father of Levi Richards, the Select Councilman, from the second Ward.

RINGLER - On the 15th inst., MARY (nee Hartenstine) widow of Walter Ringler, formerly of 47 South 8th Street, age 94 years.
  Graveside services at Aulenbach's Cemetery on Tuesday at 11 a.m.  No visitation.

Mary Ringler, 94, formerly of 47 S. Eighth St., died Sunday morning at 7:10 of natural causes in Wyomissing Lodge, where she had resided since 1972.
  She was the widow of Walter Ringler, who died in 1951.
  Born in Chester County, she was a daughter of the late Jacob S. And Ida (Miller) Hartenstine.
  She was a member of Park United Methodist Church.
  Surviving are two nieces and two nephews.
  Theo. C. Auman Inc. Is in charge of arrangements.

Rites Set For Ringler
 
Six Local Post Office Workers to Serve As Bearers at Funeral
 
  Funeral services for Walter A. Ringler, Reading postmaster, who died Thursday evening, will be held Tuesday at 11 a.m. in the T.C. Auman, Inc., parlors with the Rev. Dr. Charles E. Roth, pastor of St. Andrew's Reformed Church, officiating.  Burial will be made in Aulenbach's Cemetery.
  Moses S. Herbein, acting postmaster, today announced the names of six postal employees who will serve as bearers.  They are: George W. Emerich, of the supervisory staff; Luther Finerfrock, representing the clerks; Russell Herbein, carriers; Charles H. Hiester, mailhandlers;  Norman E. VonNeida motor operators, and Raymond Neidig, custodial services.
 
Office to Close
 
  Herbein announced that executive offices of the post office will be closed from 10:30 a.m. To 12:30 p.m. On Tuesday in respect to Ringler, who was postmaster for nearly 15 years.
  The entire post office staff will visit the funeral home Monday evening at 7 o'clock to pay their last respects to Ringler.  The public viewing will be held between 7 and 9 o'clock.
  The flag in front of the post office has been placed at half mast in tribute to the late postmaster.  Ringler took ill several weeks ago and early this week was injured in a fall, which apparently resulted from a stroke.  He died in St. Joseph's Hospital.  His wife is the only survivor.  They had no children.

Death of Ringler
Closes Long Career
 
Love of Work is Blamed for His Last Illness
 
  Unfailing devotion to duty and stubborn refusal to heed ailments of advancing years led to the death of Postmaster Walter A. Ringler, his widow said today.
  The 71-year-old former assemblyman, county commissioner and city assessor, who would have rounded out 15 years as head of the Reading Post Office on June 28 succumbed in St. Joseph's Hospital at 9:45 o'clock last night.  He would have been 72 on March 7.  Funeral arrangements had not been completed this morning.
  Although death was attributed directly to a brain injury caused either by a paralytic stroke or a fall against a radiator at his home, 47 South Eight St., Ringler suffered from exhaustion and heart trouble, Mrs. Ringler disclosed.
  The postmaster caught a cold attending the funeral of County Commissioner John G. Keller, Ringer's personal friend and Democratic colleague of many years, who died 21 days ago.  Mrs. Ringler said that her husband refused to call a doctor until the cold developed into a touch of pneumonia and his temperature was 104 degrees.
  It was while recuperating that he suffered the fall, but he was not taken to the hospital until about a week later.  He was semi-conscious after his admittance to the hospital last Monday.  He failed to rally to treatment after numerous tests and X-rays.
  Mrs. Ringler said that working was her husband's pleasure and for this reason he rarely took a vacation.  She said he preferred to stay in harness despite his advancing years.
 
Leave Days Accumulated
 
  His refusal to take a vacation from his post office duties piled up for him a total of approximately 183 days owed him by the department.  This was reduced to about 80 at the time of his death because his superiors in Washington ordered him take off one or two days a week during the last year or so.
  Ringler always said he would take a long vacation when he retired.
  The 19-story court house, the county tuberculosis hospital and prison in Bern Township and the Buttonwood Street Bridge today stand as monuments to Ringler's career.
  It was during the 12 years that he was chairman of the county board of commissioners that these projects were constructed.  He directed the inauguration and supervision of a county program of public improvements the like of which never before and probably never again will be accomplished in a similar period of time.
  It was also under Ringler's chairmanship that the county launched a road-building program that gave Berks its first hard-surfaced rural highways.  Millions of dollars were expended for these various improvements and new buildings.
 
Had Simple Life
 
  Although he ran the post office with the efficiency of a big business executive, his private life was simple.  Virtually his only pastime, except for an occasional motion picture, was a late afternoon pinochle game with a few cronies at the Americus Club.  Otherwise he enjoyed quiet evenings at home with his wife, the former Mary S. Hartenstine.  They had no children.
  During his postmastership, postal receipts here increased from $660,000 to more than $1,500,000 annually.
  While in office Ringler won the esteem of his employees when his name was placed on the honor roll of the National Federation of Post Office Clerks.  This honor is accorded to post office officials who ignore politics and personal favoritism and adhere rigidly to seniority rules in making appointment.  Ringler's name was placed on the honor roll upon nomination of the Reading members of the federation.
  Although running the post office was his immediate concern, Ringler enjoyed talking of the days when he was a county commissioner and directed many fights to give Berks County modern institutions and services.  He prided himself that he accomplished all these things as a self-made and self-educated man without much formal schooling.
  He was born on a farm in Exeter Township on March 7, 1879, the son of William Ringler, a farmer, and Louisa Morgandale Ringler.  His father died when he was in sixth grade.  His mother then moved to Reading, where Ringler worked at odd jobs to support the family.
 
Worked at Shops
 
  Later he landed a job at the Reading Company shops.  That was in 1898.  He worked at the shops for 20 years, first as an apprentice, then as a journeyman, and finally as a foreman in the railroad machine shops.
  It was while working at the shops that he became interested in politics and in 1915 he decided to run for one of the two city seats in the General Assembly.  He was successful in his bid along with the late James H Maurer, Socialist leader, who won the other seat.  He was reelected for another two-year term.
  For a time, Ringler had to stay out of politics because the government had taken over operation of the railroads during World War I and ruled that railroad employees must quit their rail jobs or get our of politics.
 
Won County Berth in 1919
 
  This didn't hold Ringler back long.  He aimed his sights for the county commissionership and was elected in the fall of 1919 without much trouble.  He took office the following January, was reelected twice and ended his tenure after the first major political defeat of his career in January 1932.
  That same year he was an unsuccessful candidate for state senator from Berks.  Some months later he was appointed city assessor of Reading.  Fro a short time previously, he had been assistant assessor.  However, the assessorship lasted only until 1936 because a new Socialist administration was swept into city hall.
  The postmastership became vacant that same year upon the retirement of the late Horace H Hammer.
 
Won Guffey's Support
 
 More than a dozen applicants sought the post, but the old guard of the Democratic Party was solidly behind his candidacy and his appointment because assured when the then U.S. Sen. Joseph F Guffey threw the weight of his influence in favor of Ringler.
  During the past 15 years Ringler's appointment came up for renewal several times.  Although new opposition developed, Ringler always won reappointment.
  Besides the Americus Club, Ringler was a member of the Postmaster's Association, the Fraternal Order of Eagles, the Union Fire Company, the Veteran Fireman's Association, the Odd Fellows and the Bavarian Association.
   The widow is the only survivor.  Funeral arrangements are in charge of T.C. Auman, Inc., Funeral directors.  Burial will probably take place in a plot at Aulenbach's Cemetery where his parents and two brothers are buried.

RINGLER -- On the 8th inst., WALTER A. RINGLER, aged 71 years.
  Services from the Theo C. Auman, Inc.  Funeral Parlors, 247 Penn St., on Tuesday at 11 a.m.  Interment in Aulenbach's Cemetery.  Friends may call Monday evening, 7 to 9.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 1st inst., AMELIA (nee Phillips), wife of William J. Ritz, aged 72 years, 1 month and 16 days.
  Relatives and friends, also Ladies of the Golden Eagle, are invited to attend the funeral services, without further notice, at F.F. Seidel's Funeral Parlor, 117 North Fifth Street, Saturday at 2 p.m.  Interment in Hinnershitz Cemetery.  Remains can be viewed at the parlor Friday evening.

MRS. WILLIAM J. RITZ
 
  Amelia (Phillips), wife of William J. Ritz, late of 310 Franklin street, West Reading, died Tuesday night of complications, after an illness of 18 months.  She was 72 years of age.  She was a member of St. James Reformed Church, West Reading.  She is survived by her husband, two sons, Edwin W. and Howard C. Ritz, West Reading; two sisters, Henrietta, wife of Henry Yocum; Malinda Phillips, Reading; 13 grandchildren and two great-grand-children.  The body was removed to the retaining rooms of Funeral Director Seidel.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 7th inst., ELIZABETH W., wife of Obediah B. Ritz, aged 31 years, 4 months and 21 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also St. Bernard Temple, No 16, L.G.E. Are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, 1729 Thorn St., on Thursday at 1:30 p.m. at the house, Services and Interment at Alsace Church.

Mrs. Obadiah Ritz
 
  Mrs Elizabeth W. Ritz, wife of Obadiah Ritz, died of catarrh of the stomach late Saturday night at her residence, 1729 Thorn.  Aged 51 years, 4 months and 21 days.  She was ailing several weeks.  Deceased was born in Reading and lived here all her life.  She was a member of Alsace Church.  Besides her husband, she leaves several children.

RITZ -- In Muhlenberg township, on the 20th inst., GEORGE P. RITZ, aged 68 years, 9 months and 9 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from F.F. Seidel's Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., Wenesday at 1:20 p.m.  Serivces in Epler's Church.  Interment in cemetery adjoining.

OLD LOCK TENDER DIES
 
  George P. Ritz, lock tender to scores of canoeists and other followers of river sports in this community, died of pneumonia at his home at Felix's Locks, Muhlenberg township, aged 68 years and 9 months.  He was bedfast four weeks.  For 36 years deceased was a lock tender and during that period had many thrilling experiences along the river in the way of floods and in assisting saving people from drowning and recovering bodies.
  Deceased was a son of the late William and Sarah (Bridegam) Ritz.  He is survived by his widow, Mary (Steely) and the following children:  Harvey, Hamburg; Walter and Floyd, Reading; Sallie, wife of Ernest Kelchner, Muhlenberg township, and Mamie, wife of Walter Frank, Bern township.  Two brothers, John and William, this city, and a sister Helen, wife of Enoch Savage, New York, survive, as well as 24 grand children and two great grandchildren.  Deceased was a member of the P. & R. Relief Association and Epler's Reformed Church.  Rev. G.W. Gerhard will officiate at the funeral which will be held Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. From Undertaker Seidel's chapel, 117 North Fifth Street.

John Ritz
 
  John Ritz died yesterday at his home, 1748 Madison avenue, aged 78 years.  He was a member of Hinnershitz Lutheran Church, Tuckerton.  Funeral Directors F.F. Seidel, Inc, have charge.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 23d inst., JOHN RITZ, 1748 Madison Ave., aged 78 years, 2 months and 3 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services, without further notice, at F.F. Seidel's Funeral Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., Saturday at 3 p.m.  Interment in Hinnershitz Church cemetery.  Friends may call at the Funeral Home Friday evening.

RITZ -- In Muhlenberg Township, on the 12th inst., MARY M. (nee Stiely), widow of George P. Ritz, aged 71 years, 4 months, 3 days.
  Relatives and friends also all organizations of which she was a member, are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, at F.F. Seidel's Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., on Friday, at 1:30 p.m.  Services at Epler's Church. Interment in cemetery adjoining.  Remains can be viewed at the Chapel Thursday evening.

MRS. MARY M. RITZ
 
  Mary M. (Stiely), widow of George P. Ritz, died of complications Sunday at her home, Kelly's Locks, in Muhlenberg township, aged 71 years, 4 months, and 3 days.  She was the last of her immediate family and a member of the Reformed congregation of Epler's Church.  She leaves three sons, Harvey, of Hamburg; Walter, Reading, and Floyd Ritz, Leisz's Bridge;  two daughters, Mamie, wife of Walter Franks, and Sallie, wife of Vernie Kelichner, both of Leisz's Bridge; 28 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.  Funeral director, Seidel.

OBADIAH B. RITZ
 
  Obadiah B. Ritz, aged 74 years, 6 months and 20 days, died as the result of paralysis at 6:30 a.m. Today, at his residence, 828 Nicolls street.  Deceased had been in ill health for a long time.  He suffered two strokes in quick succession.  The first was sustained Sunday night.  Early this morning he was stricken again.
  Deceased was a native of Muhlenberg township and live in this city the greater part of his life.  He was a laborer and was last employed at the Ninth street mill of the Reading Iron Co  He was a member of Alsace Lutheran Church, Sirius Castle, No 63, Knights of the Golden Eagle, and the Riverside fire Co.  There survive, besides his widow, Rebecca (nee Yiengst), at home; three children, Sallie, wife of William King; Mary, wife of James A. Phillips, and William C., this city;  also three brothers, George Felixs Locks; William, West Reading; John, Riverside, and one sister, Hellen, wife of Enoch Savage, New York; five grandchildren and one great-granddaughter.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 25 inst., OBADIAH R. RITZ, aged 74 years, 6 months and 20 days.
  Relatives and friends, also Lodge No. 63, Knights of the Golden Eagle, are invited to attend the funeral services, without further notice, from F.F. Seidel's Chapel, 117 N. 5th St. On Friday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock.  Interment in Alsace Cemetery.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 6th inst., REBECCA, widow of Obadiah Ritz, aged 64 years, 10 months, 1 day.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services, without further notice, at F.F. Seidel's Chapel, 117 North Fifth Street.  Thursday at 3 p.m.  Interment in Alsace cemetery.  Remains can be viewed at the chapel Wednesday evening.

Rebecca Ritz
 
Rebecca Ritz died of complications Friday at her home in Shillington, aged 64 years.  She has no known relatives.  The body was removed to the retaining rooms of Funeral Director Seidel.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 24th inst., SARAH widow of the late William Ritz, aged 82 years and 28 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of their son-in-law, William Olinger, 520 Robeson St., on Saturday afternoon at 1:30 at the house.  Services and interment at Alsace Church.

MRS. WILLIAM RITZ
 
  Sarah, widow of the late William Ritz, died from the effects of a stroke of apoplexy, which she received Monday evening at the residence of her daughter, Mrs. William Olinger, 520 Robeson.  Deceased was 82 years old, was born in Alsace and came to this city with her husband about 22 years ago.  She was a member of the Alsace Second Reformed church.  Her husband, William, died 19 years ago.  The following children remain:  Mrs. William Olinger, Mrs. Daniel Speicker, Mrs. H. Savage, Obediah, William, and John Ritz, of this city, and Geo. Ritz of Muhlenberg, and one brother, Edgar Bridegam, of this city.

RITZ -- In this city, on the 2d inst., WILLIAM J. RITZ.  1215 N 9th St., aged 81 years, 8 months and 21 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services, without further notice, at F.F. Seidel's Funeral Chapel, 117 N. 5th St., on Wednesday at 2:30.  Interment in Hinnershitz Church cemetery.  Friends may call at the Seidel Funeral Home Tuesday evening.

INJURIES FATAL TO AGED AUTO VICTIM
 
  A fractured skull, suffered Wednesday afternoon when struck by an automobile, caused the death early this morning of William J. Ritz, 81, of 1215 North Ninth street.
  Death ensured at 1 o'clock this morning in the Homeopathic Hospital.  Dr. S. B. Glick, Berks coroner, issued a certificate of accidental death.
  Edgar Moll, of Bernhart's P.O. Hyde Park, was driving the automobile which struck Ritz, according to city police reports.  The accident happened near the Ritz home.
  Ritz was employed by the Reading Iron Company a period of 37 years.  HE was a member of the Lutheran congregation of Hinnershitz Church, Tuckerton; the West Reading Fire Company, and Camp 68, P.O.S. Of A. Hyde Park.
  His wife, Amelia Ritz, died three years ago.  Surviving are two sons: Edwin W., with whom he resided, and Harvey C. Ritz, West Reading; 12 grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, and one brother, John Ritz, Shillington.
  The body was removed to the F.F. Seidel, Inc. Funeral home.  Services Wednesday at 2:30 p.m. In the Seidel chapel, the Rev. Karl L Reisner officiating.  Interment in Hinnershitz Church Cemetery.

Verstarb, in der leztern Dienstags Nacht, Peter Rothermel, ein alter und fehr geschazter Burger von Elsass Taunschip, im 63ften Jahre sienes alters.
 
Died, on last Tuesday night, Peter Rothermel, an old and honored citizen of Alsace Township, in the 63rd year of his age.

SAVAGE - In Bern township, on the 10th inst., ELLEN, widow of the late John Savage, age 82 years, 5 months, and 29 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence in Bern township, on Wednesday morning at 9:30 at the house.  Services and interment at Epler's church.  Carriages will be awaiting at Leesport to meet the 7 o'clock train.

Mrs. John Savage.
 
Leinbach's Ellen N., widow of John Savage, deceased, died Saturday at 11 a.m.  She was the daughter of Enoch and Maria Koller, of Alsace, who lived near Olinger's Dam, where her father operated a paper mill.  She was born May 16, 1818.  Her father died when she was 6 years, and her mother when she was 3 years old.  She was the youngest of 12 children and the only one surviving.  She was married to John Savage in 1842.  Seven children survive: Four sons, Sam'l, Isaac, and Enoch, all of this city; John of West Leesport, and three daughters, Mary, wife of Henry Machemer, Leinbachs; Henrietta, wife of Howard Althouse, deceased, at home, and Emma, wife of John Kauffman, of Reading.  Deceased and her husband lived at what was known as Savages' Store since they began housekeeping.  they were engaged in the hotel business at their home up to 23 years ago.  Since then, they conducted a dry goods store.  Mrs. Savage had been ailing the past six years with rheumatism.  She was unable to walk for two years and was helpless the past year.  She leaves 22 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.  Deceased was a member of Epler's Reformed congregation.  Deceased requested that Rev. R.S. Apple of Hamburg, should preach at her funeral.  Her husband preceded her in death July 25, 1899.  She was 82 years, [unreadable] months and 29 days old.  Mrs. Savage was the oldest woman for miles around and was well known.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Found Dead on the Floor of her Residence
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Found Dead on the Floor of Her Residence
 
LEESPORT:  Mrs. Ellen, wife of John Savage, died of heart disease, aged 43 years.  Deceased ate a hearty supper after which she and the domestic went out in the field to drive the horses and cows into the barn-yard.  Soon after Mrs. Savage sent the girl out to see if the gate was closed, and when she returned she found Mrs. Savage on the floor dead, she having probably expired of heart disease.  Deceased's husband, 2 brothers -- Daniel Tobias, Hyde Park, and James Tobias, and 2 sisters, Mrs. Sarah Moser, Reading and Mrs. Albert Aulenbach, Tuckerton, survive.  She was a member of Epler's Reformed Church.

Funeral of Mrs. John Savage.
 
LEESPORT: the funeral of Ellen, wife of John Savage, of Bern township, was largely attended.  Services were conducted at Epler's church by Rev. Samuel A. Leinback, of this city.  The pall-bearers were:  Obediah Eblin, Samuel H. Moser, Jacob Tobias and Joseph Bellman.  Interment in the cemetery adjoining the church.  Undertaker Francis F Seidel had charge.

SAVAGE - In Bern township, on the 14th inst., Ellen, wife of John Savage, in the 44th year of her age.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice from the residence of her husband, near Epler's church, on Saturday morning, at 9 o'clock.  Services and interment at Epler's church.

ENOCH E. SAVAGE
 
  Enoch E. Savage, a native of Bern township, who for many years had been making his home at Schenectady, N.Y., died of pneumonia at 7:20 p.m. Sunday at the residence of his daughter Sallie, wife of Peter Miller, 915 Buttonwood street, aged 79 years.  He was bedfast three months, but had been ailing for several years.  He and Mrs. Savage came to make their home with Mrs. Miller, their daughter, two years ago.  His death followed that of his brother, Samuel Savage, for years a well-known tailor of this city.  He died last September.
  Deceased had been making his home at Schenectady for 20 years where he was a stage overseer at the Proctor Theatre.  Years ago he was employed as a car inspector for the Reading Company in this city.  He was a member of Sirius Castle, Knights of the Golden Eagle; P. & R. Relief Association.  Surviving are this widow, Helen (Ritz) Savage, and three daughters, Mrs. Miller, at whose home deceased passed away; Clara, wife of John H. Bechtel, this city; and Mrs. Florence Milmore, of Schenectady; five grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, two brothers, John Savage, Leesport; Isaac Savage, Reading; and three sisters, Mrs. Mary Machemer, Bern township; Mrs. Henrietta Althouse and Mrs. Emma Kauffman, both of Reading.  Undertaker Seidel removed the remains to the residence of deceased's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. And Mrs. John H Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich street, from which place the funeral will be held.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 23d inst., ENOCH E. SAVAGE, aged 78 years, 3 months and 12 days.
  Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from the residence of his son-in-law, John H. Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich Street, on Thursday at 1:30 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 23d inst., ENOCH E. SAVAGE, aged 78 years, 3 months and 12 days.
  Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from the residence of his son-in-law, John H. Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich Street, on Thursday at 1:30 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

Enoch E. Savage.
 
The funeral of Enoch E. Savage was held from the residence of his son-in-law.  John H. Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich street.  Services were conducted at the house by Rev. Gustav R Poetter, interment following in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Undertaker Seidel had charge.

Mrs. Samuel Savage
 
  The funeral of Hattie, wife of Samuel Savage, took place from her residence, 105 North Tenth, at 2 p.m. today.  Rev. Dr. L.K. Derr officiated.  The bearers were her three sons and son-in-law, Thomas Jefferson, Ulysses, Samuel and Charles K. Savage and James Reifsnyder.  The remains were attired in a black dress and rested in a square walnut casket with silver handles and trimmings and plate with name and age.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Undertaker Henninger.

SAVAGE -- In this city on the 13th inst., HATTIE, wife of Samuel Savage, aged 63 years, 8 months and 21 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, 105 N. 10th St. , on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment private in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Please omit flowers.

Mrs. Samuel Savage
 
  Hattie (nee DeLong), wife of Samuel Savage, died of a complication of diseases at 6:45 p.m. Monday, at her residence, 105 North Tenth, aged 63 years, 8 months and 21 days.  She was ailing 18 months and was bedfast about the half of this time.  Deceased was born in Maxatawny.  She came to this city with her husband about 40 years ago.  She was a member of Zion's Reformed Church.  Besides her husband, she is survived by three sons:  Thomas Jefferson, City Ticket Agent for the P & R Railway; Charles F., of this city, and Ulysses Samuel, of Wernersville;  three daughters: Ella, wife of Joseph R. Hoover; Agnes, wife of James M. Reifsnyder, of Harrisburg, and Katie, at Egg Harbor; one brother, Joel; four sisters: Mary, wife of Daniel Moser; Lydia, wife of Franklin Snyder; Mrs. Kate Reinhardt; Sarah, wife of Levi Wagner, all of Center township, and nine grandchildren.

MRS. HELEN SAVAGE
 
  Word was received in this city of the death in Schenectady, N.Y. of Helen (Ritz), widow of Enoch Savage, aged 79 years, a native of Reading.  Mrs. Savage, who had been ailing for some time with complications, died at the home of her daughter, Florence, widow of Thomas Milmore, in that city.  She was a member of St. Mark's Reformed Church, this city.  There survive three daughters, Mrs. Milmore, Sallie, wife of Peter Miller, and Clara, wife of John Bechtel, both of Reading; two brothers, William and John Ritz, Reading; four grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren.  Funeral Director Seidel is making arrangements to bring the remains to the home of the daughter, Mrs. John Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich street.

SAVAGE -- In Schenectady, N.Y. on the 5th inst., ELLEN E., widow of Enoch Savage, aged 78 years and 1 month.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of her son-in-law, John Bechtel, 229 West Greenwich Street, Reading, Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock, Daylight Saving Time.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Remains may be viewed at the residence Tuesday evening.

MRS. HELEN A. SAVAGE
 
  Mrs. Helen A. Savage, mother of Mrs. E.F. Millmore of [] Saratoga road, died Saturday night at the home of her daughter after an illness of three months.  The house will be open tonight from 7 to 9 o'clock.  The funeral will be conducted Wednesday afternoon at the home of her daughter, Mrs. J. H. Bechtel at Reading, Pa, by Rev. Gustave Poetter of St. Mark's Reformed Church.  Burial will be in the Charles Evans Cemetery.
  Mrs. Savage was born in Reading, Pa., and had lived in this section about 20 years.
  Her husband, Enoch E Savage, died four years ago.  She is survived by three daughters, Mrs E.F. Milmore of this city, Mrs. J.H. Bechtel and Mrs. Peter Miller of Reading, two brothers, William and John Ritz of Reading, several grand children, eight great grand children, and two great great grandchildren.

ISAAC H. SAVAGE
 
Isaac H. Savage, retired employe of the Reading Company, died Sunday at his Summer home at Mechanicsville, near Leinbach's Hotel, Bern township.  The cause of death was a severe heart attack.  Mr. Savage was born Sept. 27, 1856, and his wife, Katie (Fromm), preceded him in death three years.  He was the son of the late John and Eleanora (Koller) Savage and was born in the same house in which he passed away.  He was a member of Zion's Reformed Church, Juniata Tribe, 74, I.O.R.M.; Sirius Castle, Knights of the Golden Eagle, and the P. & R. Relief Association.  He was employed by the Reading Company as a painter for over 45 years and was retired five years ago.  There survive two children, Mrs. Lena Reifsnyder ad Alvin G. Savage, both of 1627 Perkiomen avenue, where he made his home, and two grandsons, A. Warren East, Richmond, Ind., and Benjamin F. Deeter, Mt. Penn.  Funeral Director Seidel has charge.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 10th inst., ISAAC H. SAVAGE, aged 75 years, 9 months, and 13 days.
  Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 1627 Perkiomen Ave., on Thursday at 2:30 p.m.  Daylight Savings Time.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Remains can be viewed at the residence Wednesday evening.

JOHN SAVAGE
 
died this morning at his residence in Mechanicsville, Bern township, of catarrh of the stomach and old age, aged 84 years, 8 months and 11 days.  Deceased was ailing about three weeks.  He was for several terms assessor of Bern.  He entered a tailor establishment as an apprentice at Mechanicsville, 65 years ago, and after finishing his trade he purchased the shop from his employer and conducted it successfully up to the time of his death.  He was a member of Epler's Reformed church and had many friends.  His wife died some time ago.  Following children remain:  Samuel, Enoch, and Isaac Savage, of Reading; John Savage, of Bern; Mrs. Henry Machemer of Bern; Mrs. Howard Althouse and Mrs. John Kauffman, of Reading, and these sisters, Mrs. Catharine Gehret, or Reading, and Mrs. Jacob Kramer, of Brooklyn, N.Y.

SAVAGE - In Bern township, on the 25th inst., JOHN SAVAGE, aged 84 years, 8 months, and 11 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, in Bern township, on Friday morning at 10 o'clock at the house.  Services and interment at Epler's Church.

The funeral of John Savage, aged 84 years, took place from his residence in Bern township at 10 a.m., and after a short prayer and the singing of several hymns at the house proceeded to Epler's Church, where services were conducted by Rev. R.S. Appel.  The remains were attired in a black silk robe and reposed in a solid walnut casket with silver trimmings, extension bar handles and plate bearing the deceased's name and age.  Interment at Epler's Church.  The report that deceased's wife had died is incorrect, but she was too sick to attend the funeral.  Her condition is quite critical.  Funeral Director Francis F Seidel had charge.

MRS. ISAAC H. SAVAGE
 
  After suffering a heart attack two weeks ago, Kathryn (Fromm), wife of Isaac H. Savage, aged 69 years, died this morning at 5 o'clock at her home, 1627 Perkiomen avenue.  Deceased was bedfast after being stricken, but was ailing the last two years.
  Mrs. Savage was a native of Leinbachs Bern township, Berks county, and a daughter of the late William and Rebecca (Harbach) Fromm.  She was born on March 15, 1860, and was an active member of Zion's Reformed Church.  For the last 47 years, Mrs. Savage made her home here after moving from Bern township.
  Besides the husband, there survive the following children:  Mrs. Emma R. East; Lena, wife of James Reifsnyder, and Alvin Savage, all of this city; on sister, Mrs. Helen Kauffman, Reading; a brother, George Fromm, of Ridgewood, and two grandchildren, Benjamin F. Deeter, Mt Penn. And A Warren East, Richmond, Ind.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 17th inst., KATIE M (Fromm), wife of Isaac H. Savage, aged 69 years, 1 month 2 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her residence, 1627 Perkiomen avenue, Saturday at 2:30.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans cemetery.

SAMUEL SAVAGE
 
  Samuel Savage, well-known tailor, following a two months illness died of complications at 2 o'clock this morning.  He lived for many years at 105 North Tenth street, but his death occurred at the residence of his son, Thomas J. Savage, 335 North Third street, where he made his home during most of his illness.  He was bedfast seven weeks and the first of seven children of his family to pass away.
  Mr. Savage was in his 83d year and was born near Leinbach's Hotel.  For more than 50 years he was in the employ of the old Leinbach & Bro. Clothing firm, Eight and Penn streets.  He was one of the first tailors in their employ.  When the firm went out of existence some time ago he continued following his trade.  Deceased attended Zion's Reformed Church at the time when Rev. Dr. L. K. Derr was pastor.
  Deceased's wife, Hettie (DeLong) Savage, preceded him in death 19 years.  Three sons and two daughters survive, Thomas J., at whose home deceased passed away; Ulysses S., Wernersville; Charles F. Savage, Reading; Mrs. Katie Carter, Egg Harbor City, N.J., and Mrs Ella Hoover, Reading.  Eight grandchildren, 12 great-grandchildren, three brothers and three sisters survive, as follows:  Enoch and Isaac Savage, Reading;  John Savage, West Leesport; Mrs. Mary Machemer, Leinbachs P.O.; Mrs Henrietta Althouse and Mrs. Emma Kauffman, Reading.

Samuel Savage
 
  The funeral of Samuel Savage took place from the residence of his son, Thomas Savage, 335 North Second street.  Rev. Dr. Carl H. Gramm was in charge of the services at the house.  Interment was made in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Undertaker Seidel had charge.
  The following were the bearers: Thomas Savage, W. Samuel Savage, Charles F Savage, Jacob Savage, Joseph S Hoover, and Alvin Savage.  The tributes:
  Bouquet, Helen Rouse, Eleanor Hurley, Sara Gottball, Marjorie Britton, Avis Crowley and Mrs. Oberst; basket of gladiolus, Mrs. Henrietta Savage and family; asters and gladiolus, James Reifsnyder; asters, Mr. and Mrs Paulies; asters sister, Mary Machemer; asters, Enoch Savage and family; asters and gladiolus, Mr and Mrs. Harry Miller; wreath of gladiolus, Isaac Savage and family; asters, Sewing Circle Girls from Egg Harbor, N.J.; asters John Miller and Ethel.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 2d inst., SAMUEL SAVAGE, aged 82 years, 10 months and 12 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from the residence of his son, Thomas Savage, 333 N. 2d St., on Saturday at 3 p.m.  Services at the house.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

MRS. JOHN SAVAGE
 
  West Leesport, Aug. 29 (Special).  -- Susan (Meyer), wife of John Savage, died from heart failure, after an illness of but a few days, at her home here, aged 76 years, 9 months and 20 days.  She was reared in Wayne township, Schuylkill county, was a daughter of the late Christian and Catharine (Feick) Meyer, and a member of the Lutheran denomination of Epler's Church.  There survive her husband and one sister, Ellen, wife of Samuel Bittle, Schuylkill Haven.
  Funeral Thursday, Sep 1, at 9:30 a.m. from the home.  Further services in Epler's Church.  Rev. Karl L. Reisner officiating.  Interment in the adjoining cemetery, in charge of Funeral Director J.D. Naftzinger, of Centerport.

SAVAGE-- In West Leesport, on the 27th inst., SUSAN, wife of John Savage, aged 76 years, 9 months and 20 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, in West Leesport, on Thursday, Sep 1, at 9:30 a.m. at the house.  Services and interment at Epler's Church.

SAVAGE -- In this city, on the 28th inst., JOHN SAVAGE, aged 84 years, 5 months and 14 days.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral without further notice from the residence of his brother, Isaac H. Savage, 1627 Perkiomen Avenue, Saturday at 2:30, daylight saving time, at the house.  Services in Epler's Church.  Interment in cemetery adjoining.  Remains can be viewed at the residence Friday evening.

CIVIL WAR VETERAN ANSWERS LAST CALL
 
  John Savage, formerly of West Leesport, died at the home of his brother, Isaac H. Savage, 1627 Perkiomen avenue, at 3 o'clock this morning, aged 84 years, 5 months and 14 days.  His wife, Susan (Moyer), preceded him in death almost three years.  There survive three sisters, Mary, wife of Henry Machemer, Leinbach's; Mrs. Henrietta Althouse, and Mrs. Emma Kauffman, and one brother, Isaac, all of this city.
  Mr. Savage was but 18 years of age when he enlisted, Sept 2, 1864, and was mustered in the U.S. Service at Harrisburg to serve for the duration of the war in Co. H, 205 regiment, Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry, under Capt. Franklin Schmehl, and Col. J.A. Mathews.  The regiment proceeded to Washington, D.C., encamped at Ft. Corcoran, Va., thence to Camp Distribution, escorted 1,300 recruits to City Point and constructed earthworks and forts assigned to the 2d brigade, 3d division, 9th corps, Army of the Potomac under Gen. Hartranft.  He participated in the battles of Fort Steadman, March 25, 1865; Fall of Petersburg, April 2, 1865; pursuit of Lee along the South Side Railroad to Burkesville, until Lee surrendered  On one occasion he saw Abraham Lincoln on the firing line, witnessing the progress of the Union forces, much to the anxiety of the officers in command.  Comrade Savage shared in all its movements and engagements and narrowly escaped a trap set for a cavalry officer and himself by guerillas.  He was honorably discharged June 2, 1865 at Harrisburg, Pa., on account of the close of war.

BENEDICT SCHULTZ
 
Benedict Schultz, aged 67 years, died suddenly of heart disease at 4:30 p.m. Friday at his home, 330 North Eleventh street.  Until his seizure, he was apparently in good health.  He was employed by the Penn Hardware Company and was a member of St. Paul's Catholic Church.  Holy Name Society, St Bonifacius' Beneficial Brotherhood.  Holy Cross Society, Hampden Fire Company, Firemen's Relief Association, and the Veteran Volunteer Firemen's Association.  He was born in this city  Besides his widow, Mary (Rettgers), he is survived by two daughters, Gertrude and Anna, at home, and a sister, Mrs. John Impink of Reading.

Mrs. Mary Schultz
 
Mary (Rettgers), 82, widow of Benedict Schultz, died yesterday in her home, 350 North 11th St.  She was a member of St. Paul's Catholic Church and Holy Family Society.
  Surviving are two daughters, Gertrude and Emma, at home.  Funeral Thursday at 8:30 a.m. at the house.  High Requiem Mass in St. Paul's Catholic Church at 9 a.m.  Interment in Gethsemane Cemetery.  The Dougherty Funeral Service in charge.

SCHULTZ -- On the 13th inst., MARY (Rettgers), widow of Benedict Schultz, aged 82 years.
  Funeral from the residence, 330 N. 11th St., Thursday 8:30 a.m. Solemn High Requiem Mass in St. Paul's R.C. Church, 9 a.m.  Interment in Gethsemane Cemetery.  Friends may call at the residence Wednesday evening.

SCHULTZ -- In this city, on the 1st inst., BENEDICT S. SCHULTZ, aged 67 years.
  Relatives and friends, also members of the Holy Name Society of St. Paul's parish, Bonifacious Brotherhood, Holy Cross Brotherhood of St. Paul's, Veteran Firemen's Association, also members of Hampden Fire Company, are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 330 North Eleventh street on Wednesday at 8:30 a.m.  High mass of requiem in St. Paul's Catholic Church at 9 o'clock.  Interment, Gethsemane Cemetery.

ABRAHAM SEIVARD
 
  Abraham Seivard, aged 60 years, a well-known patternmaker for the Mt. Penn Stove Works, died at his home, 209 Oley street.  Deceased leaves besides his widow, four children and several brothers and sisters.  Mr. Seivard was city building inspector during the administration of Mayor Shanaman from 1893 to 1896.

Abraham Seivard
 
  Services were held over the remains of Abraham Seivard at his home, 209 Oley street, at 2 p.m. today by Rev. Charles T Isenberger, pastor of the Windsor Street M. E. Church.  The remains were attired in a black suit and lay in a black cloth-covered casket, with silver trimmings and plate inscribed with name and age.  Interment was made in Charles Evans Cemetery.  Undertaker Henninger had charge.

SEIVARD -- In this city, on the 12th inst., ABRAHAM SEIVARD, aged 59 years, 11 months and 6 days.
  The relatives and friends of the family, also members of Chandler Lodge, No 227, F. And A. M., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, 209 Oley street, on Saturday afternoon at 1 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment private in Charles Evans cemetery.  Please omit flowers.

Mrs. Annie M. Seivard
 
  Mrs. Annie M. Seivard, widow of Jacob Seivard, one time well known citizen of Pottstown, died Saturday morning at 2.45 o'clock at the residence of her son-in-law, Frazier Keene, 467 North Evans street.  Deceased was aged 81 years, 7 months and 19 days.  She was the daughter of the late Jacob and Annie Hartenstine, of Pine Swamp, Chester County.
  She is survived by a son and a daughter, Charles B. Seivard, of Pottstown, and Laura L., wife of Frazer E. Keene.  It is a coincident that the mother and father-in-law of Charles B. Seivard died within the past several days.  Mrs. Seivard was for many years a faithful member of the First M.E. Church.  The funeral will be held on Tuesday at 2 p.m.  Services and interment private.

MRS. ANNIE M. SEIVARD
 
Pottstown, Sept 2. -- Mrs. Annie M. Seivard died at the residence of her son-in-law, Frazer Keene, 467 North Evans street, this borough, aged 81 years, 7 months and 19 days.  She was the widow of Jacob Seivard of town, and a daughter of the late Jacob and Annie Hartenstine, of Pine Swamp, Chester County.
  She is survived by a son and a daughter, Charles B. Seivard, of town, and Laura L., wife of Frazer E Keene.  Charles B. Seivard also lost by death, his father-in-law, Benton Rutter, within two days after his mother's demise.  Mrs. Seivard was for many years a faithful member of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, this borough.  Funeral Tuesday, Sept 5 at 2 p.m.  Services and interment private.  Friends may view the remains Monday evening, Sept 4, at the Keene residence.

MRS. CLARA A. SEIVARD
 
  Clara A., widow of Abraham Seivard, died from the results of a cerebral hemorrhage at 3 o'clock Thursday afternoon at her residence, 209 Oley street, aged 71 years.  Deceased had been ill for a few weeks.  Her husband preceded her in death 17 years.  Deceased leaves three children as follow:  Arthur M., Reading; Harry G. Seivard, Cleveland, O., and Mrs. Stanley F Bingaman, this city.  Surviving also are two grandchildren, a brother, Charles F. Fry, this city; and a sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Wolfinger, Trenton, N.J.

SEIVARD -- In this city, on the 18th inst., CLARA A., widow of Abraham Seivard, aged 71 years and 11 months.
  Funeral strictly private from her residence, 209 Oley street.  Please omit flowers.  Interment in Charles Evans Cemetery.

MRS. ELIZABETH M. SEIVARD
 
  Mrs. Elizabeth M. (Shick) Seivard, long a member of Grace United Evangelical Church, died of infirmities at 12:10 p.m. Today at her residence, 742 North Third street, aged 84 years.  Mrs. Seivard had been failing gradually for two months.  She was the widow of Henry Seivard, who died Feb 4, 1925, and who was the last of the original firm of the Mt. Penn Stove Works.
  Deceased was a native of Chester county and had been making her home in this city for the last 55 years.  A brother, A.W. Shick, Brooklyn, N.Y. And a number of neices and nephews survive.

SEIVARD -- In this city, on the 8th inst., Elizabeth M., widow of Henry Seivard, aged 84 years.
  Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her residence, No 742 North Third street, on Friday afternoon at 2 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment Charles Evans cemetery.

SEIVARD -- In this city, on the 4th inst., HENRY SEIVARD, aged 85 years, 2 months, 23 days.
  Relatives and friends, also employees Mt Penn Stove Works, are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from his residence, No 742 North Third street, on Saturday afternoon, at 1 o'clock.  Services at the house.  Interment, Charles Evans cemetery.

HENRY SEIVARD
 
  Henry Seivard, aged 85 years, last of the original firm of the Mt. Penn Stove Works, died of infirmities and general debility at 9:45 a.m. Today at his home, 742 North Third street, after an illness of several years.  He was confined to bed since last Thursday.
  Mr. Seivard was born in Birdsboro and came to Reading more than 50 years ago.  His parents were the late Abraham and Catharine (Keimerd) Seivard.  He was a devout member of Grace United Evangelical Church.
  Deceased, who was a pattern-maker, learned his trade at the Orr, Paiter & Sembower Stove Works.  In 1881 he assisted in the organization of the Mt. Penn Stove Works and since then had been a director.   He retired 14 years ago.
  Surviving, besides his widow, Elizabeth M. (Shick) Seivard, is an only sisten, Mary A., widow of Heber Hartenstine, of Wilmington, Del.

Jacob Seivard
 
  Impressive funeral services in memory of Jacob Seivard were held yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock from his residence, 467 North Evans street.  The services were in charge of Rev. Everett D. Decker, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church and were attended by a large number of friends and relatives of the deceased.  A mixed quartette from the First Methodist Church sang, "I Would Not Live Always" and "My Jesus As Thy Will."  Interment was held privately in the Pottstown Cemetery.
  The bearers were Frazer E. Keen, William Rotz, Horace Keen, Howard W. Hartenstine, David Hughes and Charles B. Seivard.  The tributes included:  Blanket, from wife:  hand bouquet, fro great-grandson Hedges; spray of asters, Daughter Laura and family; spray of asters, Son Charles and family; spray of roses, Grand-daughter Flora and family; was weath, Grandson Horace and wife and spray of asters, Mrs. Charles Snyder and family.  Funeral Director J. S. Gabel had charge.

SortedNewspaperLinks.Notes: Obtained from the Pottstown Cemetery by Richard Carnell
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
DEATH SUMMONS JACOB SEIVARD
 
Retired Iron Worker Passes Away Following Two Weeks' Illness.
 
  After an illness of two weeks from general debility, Jacob Seivard, a well known retired iron worker died yesterday morning at 11.20 o'clock at his late residence, 467 North Evans street, at the age of 81 years, seven months, and nine days.  Although he had been in failing health for several years his condition was not serious and he was able to be about until two week ago.
  Deceased came to Pottstown 47 years ago from St. Mary's Chester county.  He was a son of the late Abraham and Catharine Seivard.  For many years he worked as a puddler in the plant of the Pottstown Iron Company, but for the past five years he has lived retired.
  He is survived by his widow, Ann, nee Hartenstine.  Had Mr. Seivard lived until Sept 11 the couple would have celebrated their 57th wedding anniversary.  Two children survive.  They are:  Laura, wife of Frazer Keen, and Charles B. Seivard, both of this borough.  The following brothers and sisters also remain:  Harry Seivard, of Reading; Kate, widow of William Williams' of St. Mary's; Mary, widow of Heber Hartenstine, of Glen Moore, and Elizabeth, widow of Cyrus Hartenstine, of Maryland.
  He also leaves four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.
  Mr. Seivard was a member of the First Methodist Church.  He was well known and enjoyed a host of friends in this borough as well as in the vicinity of his native home in St. Mary's.
  The funeral will be held on Monday afternoon, Aug 26.  Services will be held from his late residence at three o'clock.  Interment will be made privately in Pottstown Cemetery.

Miss Mary Seivard died on Tuesday at her home in Robeson, near Plow church, of apoplexy.  Deceased was 80 years of age, and a daughter of the late Jacob and Catharine Seivard, both of whom died many years ago.  She is survived by an only sister, Mrs. Hannah Fry, of Birdsboro, who is now 91 years of age.  Building inspector Seivard and brother, Henry, both of this city are nephews.  Funeral, Saturday morning, Aug 3.  Services in Plow church at 10 o'clock by Rev. Z.H. Gable, and interment in the cemetery adjoining.

Elwood Sellers Dies; Retired Railroader
 
  Elwood Sellers Sr., retired Reading Company railroader died at 7 o'clock last evening in the Reading Hospital after an illness of four days.  His home was at 1230 Chestnut St.  He was aged 88 years.
  A native of Chester County, he was a son of the late Mr. And Mrs. Frederick Sellers was a member of the P. & R. Relief Association and the Foresters of America in Pottstown.
  His wife, Elizabeth K. (Miller) Sellers, preceded him in death.  Surviving are a son, Henry Clay Sellers, with whom he resided; a daughter, Mary, wife of Robert Hofneinz, Pottstown; seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
  Arrangements for the funeral are in charge of Irvin J. Cramp, local funeral director.  Burial will be made in Pine Swamp Cemetery near Hopewell in Chester County.

Samuel Shepp, a retired farmer, died from the effects of an apoplectic stroke at his residence in Cumru, aged 69 years.  Deceased was stricken nearly a week before his death.  Two daughters, Mrs. Evans, of Iowa, and the other residing at home, and 2 brothers, John Shepp, of Reading, and Jacob Shepp, of West Reading survive.  Deceased was a member of the Alsace Reformed Church.

SHEPP -- In Cumru township, on the 30th ult., SAMUEL SHEPP, in his 70th year.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from his late residence, in Cumru township, near Centre hotel, on Tuesday morning at 9:30 o'clock at the house.  Services and interment at Alsace church.

SHEPP -- In Cumru township, on the 11th inst., SARAH E., widow of Samuel Shepp, aged 73 years.
  The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, in Cumru township, near the Centre House, on Thursday morning at 9 o'clock at the house.  Services and interment in Alsace Church.

Mrs. Samuel Shepp.
 
  Sarah, widow of Samuel Shepp, died of a heart failure, aged 73 years, at her residence, near the Centre House.  She was only ill a few hours and passed away at 5 a.m. today.  Mrs. Shepp is survived by two daughters, Mrs. Thomas Evans, of Iowa and Mary, at home, a brother, William R. High, of Reading, and two sisters, Mrs. Frederick Bechtel, Brookside, and Mary, of this city.  Mrs Shepp was a member of Yocum's Reformed Church, and had many friends.

SAVANNAH - Beverly Nell White Shoemaker , 55, died November 8, 2007.  She was born in Savannah, daughter of the late, Raymond Howard White, Sr. and Miriam Cornell White.  She was a member of Montgomery Presbyterian Church.  Mrs. Shoemaker was a loving homemaker who opened her doors to anyone in need in her community.  She was preceded in death by her daughter, Rebecca Shoemaker and sister, Brenda White.  Surviving are her husband, Michael J. Shoemaker ; son, Joseph M. Shoemaker ; sister, Barbara J. Hickey, sister in love, Debbie Rice-Reagan; brothers, Raymond White, Jr.; Ronald White; Roland T. White and many nieces and nephews.  Visitation: 3:00-5:00 p.m. Sunday, November 11, 2007 at Fox & Weeks.  Funeral: 11:00 a.m. Monday, November 12, 2007 at Montgomery Presbyterian Church with Rev. Dr. Mark Giuliano, officiating.  Burial: Forest Lawn Cemetery.  Remembrances: Montgomery Church or Hospice Savannah.  Fox & Weeks Funeral Directors Hodgson Chapel

SAVANNAH - Michael Joseph Shoemaker , 58, died February 29, 2008.  Born in Savannah, he is the son of Stella Cronk Shoemaker and the late Louis Charles Shoemaker .  He was a member of the Montgomery Presbyterian Church.  Michael was preceded in death by his loving wife, Beverly Nell White Shoemaker , a daughter, Rebecca Shoemaker , and a younger brother, Robert L. Shoemaker .  Michael and Beverly were well known for opening their doors to anyone in need in their community.  Surviving are his son, Joseph M. Shoemaker ; mother, Stella Cronk Shoemaker ; brothers, Richard C. Shoemaker , Carl F. Shoemaker , and Gary L. Shoemaker ; sisters, Joan S. Aliffi and Ann S. Boxxe; sister-in-love, Debbie Rice-Reagan; brothers-in-law, Raymond White, Jr., Ronald White, and Roland T. White; sister-in-law, Barbara J. Hickey, and many nieces and nephews.  Michael was a graduate of Jenkins High School and served in the U.S. Army in Germany.  He worked until his retirement as a mail handler for the U.S. Post Office.  Visitation: 3:00 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. Sunday, March 2, 2008 at Fox & Weeks Funeral Directors Hodgson Chapel followed by a Christian Wake Service at 4:30 p.m.  Funeral: 11:00 a.m. Monday, March 3, 2008 at Montgomery Presbyterian Church with Rev. Dr. Mark Giuliano, officiating.  Burial: Forest Lawn Memory Gardens  Remembrances: Muscular Dystrophy Association or Montgomery Presbyterian Church.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Hair Turns White When Girl Drowns Near Milledgeville
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Hair Turns White When Girl Drowns Near Milledgeville
 
  MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Aug 15.  The body of Miss Eunice Smith, 18, nurse at the Georgia State Sanitarium, was recovered from the Oconee River at 5:30 o'clock this morning, thirty-six hours after she lost her life while wading in the stream.
  Arthur Layfield, to whom Miss Smith was engaged to wed, recovered the body while diving in the stream a half mile below the point where she was drowned.
  Layfield is a brother of William Layfield, 14, who rescued Miss Mary Youngblood, another nurse of the State Sanitarium, who was wading in the stream with Miss Smith Friday evening, when both sand from sight.
  The younger Layfield, after rescuing Miss Youngblood, returned for Miss Smith, but she had disappeared and the body did not rise to the surface again until it was recovered this morning.
  Miss Smith was a brunette, but when the body was found, her hair had turned white.
   The body was taken to the J.A. Moore undertaking parlors here and later was taken to Sunny Hill Cemetery, near Sandersville in Washington County, where the funeral service took place this afternoon.
  The Oconee River where the nurses and William Layfield went walking Friday evening is normally shallow, but there had been a sudden rise, due to rains up stream, and they got into water over their heads.  Neither of the nurses could swim.
  Miss Smith was from Bartow, Ga.  Her father can here at once as soon as news of the drowning reached him and he kept a constant vigil along the river, with scores of other persons, during Friday night, Saturday, and Saturday night.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Dives Into River and Brings up Body of Fiancee
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
DIVES INTO RIVER AND BRINGS UP BODY OF FIANCEE
 
Arthur Layfield finds Body of Miss Eunice Smith, Nurse at Georgia State Sanitarium.
 
DROWNED WADING BEYOND HER DEPTH
 
14 Year-Old Brother of Layfield Rescues Companion.  Victim's Hair Turns White in Water.
 
  MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Aug 15 - (AP) - Arthur Layfield today dived into the Oconee river near here and brought up the body of his fiancee, Miss Eunice Smith, graduate nurse at the Georgia State Sanitarium, who drowned yesterday when she waded in the stream beyond her depth.  Layfield was a member of a searching party seeking the young woman's body.  She was found half a mile from the point where she was last seen in the river.
  Layfield is a brother of William Layfield, 14, who rescued Miss Mary Youngblood, another nurse of the State Sanitarium, who was wading in the stream with Miss Smith Friday evening, when both sand from sight.
  The younger Layfield, after rescuing Miss Youngblood, returned for Miss Smith, but she had disappeared and the body did not rise to the surface again until it was recovered this morning.
  Miss Smith was a brunette, but when the body was found, her hair had turned white.
   The body was taken to the J.A. Moore undertaking parlors here and later was taken to Sunny Hill Cemetery, near Sandersville in Washington County, where the funeral service took place this afternoon.
  The Oconee River where the nurses and William Layfield went walking Friday evening is normally shallow, but there had been a sudden rise, due to rains up stream, and they got into water over their heads.  Neither of the nurses could swim.
  Miss Smith was from Bartow, Ga.  Her father can here at once as soon as news of the drowning reached him and he kept a constant vigil along the river, with scores of other persons, during Friday night, Saturday, and Saturday night.

Recovers Sweetheart's Body
 
Hair Turned White in a Day
 
  MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Aug 15 - (AP) - Arthur Layfield today dived into the Oconee river near here and brought up the body of his fiancee, Miss Eunice Smith, graduate nurse at the Georgia State Sanitarium, who drowned yesterday when she waded in the stream beyond her depth.  Layfield was a member of a searching party seeking the young woman's body.  She was found half a mile from the point where she was last seen in the river.
  Layfield is a brother of William Layfield, 14, who rescued Miss Mary Youngblood, another nurse of the State Sanitarium, who was wading in the stream with Miss Smith Friday evening, when both sand from sight.
  The younger Layfield, after rescuing Miss Youngblood, returned for Miss Smith, but she had disappeared and the body did not rise to the surface again until it was recovered this morning.
  Miss Smith was a brunette, but when the body was found, her hair had turned white.
   The body was taken to the J.A. Moore undertaking parlors here and later was taken to Sunny Hill Cemetery, near Sandersville in Washington County, where the funeral service took place this afternoon.
  The Oconee River where the nurses and William Layfield went walking Friday evening is normally shallow, but there had been a sudden rise, due to rains up stream, and they got into water over their heads.  Neither of the nurses could swim.
  Miss Smith was from Bartow, Ga.  Her father can here at once as soon as news of the drowning reached him and he kept a constant vigil along the river, with scores of other persons, during Friday night, Saturday, and Saturday night.

GIRL DROWNS: FRIEND SAVED BY SMALL BOY
 
Miss Eunice Smith, Nurse at State Sanitarium, Lost in Oconee
 
HER BODY NOT YET FOUND
 
William Layfield, 14, Proves Himself a Hero During Emergency
 
MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga.  Aug 14.  A 14-year-old boy late yesterday saved the life of Miss Mary Youndblood, 18, a nurse at the Georgia State Sanitarium, when the treacherous waters of the Oconee River below Fort Wilkinson closed over her head.  But he was unable to save Miss Eunice Smith, 18, of Bartow, Ga., whose body was sucked under by the current and has not yet been found by searching parties.
  Misses Youngblood and Smith were wading in the middle of the river, which previously had been shallow, but which recent rains upstream had treacherously swollen.  Suddenly both girls went under.  William Layfiled, 14, was with them, but wading near the shore.  He hastened to the rescue, and pulled Miss Youngblood safely to shore.  Then he returned to save Miss Smith, but it was too late.  Her body had disappeared for the last time.
  Parties of searchers have been dragging the river all last night and throughout today, but without success.  The search is continuing tonight.
  The condition of the Oconee was not anticipated by the girls, as they had visited the stream frequently of recent days, and found no deep water.  Parents living in that section have been taking their children there to wade.  A near freshet, however, was precipitated by the upstream rains, and the water at the point now is about six feet deep.
  Miss Smith's father, who lives at Bartow, Ga., hurried here when he was advised of her death.  He is assisting in the search for her body.
  Miss Youngblood did not suffer seriously from her experiences.

SortedNewspaperLinks.NewspaperHeading: Bath Child is Killed in Road Accident
SortedNewspaperLinks.Transcription:
Bath Child is Killed in Road Accident
 
Gerald Smith, 6, Ran in Front of Automobile
 
  Gerald Smith, six-year-old son of Mr. And Mrs. Kendrick Smith, of Bath, was crushed to death about 5:00 o'clock Tuesday afternoon when he was struck by an automobile driven by Mrs. Dan Miller of Leesville, S.C. According to Sheriff Price Fallaw.
  The accident happened on the highway in front of a tourist camp between Bath and Langley.  The child was playing with other children and ran out on the highway in front of the approaching car, the sheriff said.
  Mrs. Miller was returning to her home in Leesville at the time of the accident.  The sheriff said he did not learn the identity of her woman companion.
  Coroner Tom Tarver investigated the accident along with Deputy Sheriff C.L. Hartley and County Patrolman C.M. Courtney.  He said a coroner's inquest will be held at a date to be selected later.
  Funeral services were conducted Thursday afternoon at 3:30 at Bath Baptist Church.  Rev J.E. Williams officiating.  Interment followed in the Langley cemetery.

Herschel Lafayette Smith Sr., 95, of St. Marys died on Sunday, Dec. 19, 2004 at the St. Marys Convalescent Home.  Smith was a retired surveyor with the Georgia Highway Department in Atlanta, with 30 years of service.  He was born on April 7, 1909 in Harrison-Riddleville, and was the oldest child of the late Thomas Jefferson Smith and Mamie Ethel Welch Smith.  He is preceded in death by his wife of six years, Helen Clyde Page and their infant son, Bennie; and his wife of 69 years, Okella Belle Josey Smith.  Survivors include his children, Clydie Faye Smith McDonough and husband, Bill, of McDonough, H.L. Smith Jr. of Harrison, Hazel Smith Warren and husband, Robbie, of Waynesville, Mary Jane Smith and husband, Wilmer, of Harrison, Betty Sue Smith Higginbotham and husband, Fred, of St. Marys and David Smith of Harrison; sister, Grace York and husband, Billy, of Coconut Grove, Fla.; 12 grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren.  Allison Memorial Chapel of St. Marys is in charge of arrangements.  Graveside services will be held at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 22 at Washington County Memorial Gardens in Tennille-Sandersville.
